HEADLINE: E.P.A. May Expand Plan To Clean Apartments 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Federal officials said yesterday that the government's new commitment to clean any apartment south of Canal Street in Manhattan, to remove dust and debris from the World Trade Center disaster, might be expanded to include reimbursement for residents who have already had their homes professionally cleaned. 
 They also said the cleanup program, which was officially announced yesterday at a news conference at the Manhattan regional headquarters of the Environmental Protection Agency, could be extended to include apartments outside the boundaries if testing suggests the need for it. Depending on what is found in the residential work, the interiors of businesses may eventually be included as well, they said. 
 "No one should have to live with anxiety about the safety of the air in their own homes," said Jane Kenny, the E.P.A.'s regional administrator.
The cleanup program, which is expected to begin next month, reverses the position that was taken after Sept. 11 by federal, local and state government officials, who insisted that Lower Manhattan residents and business owners were responsible for cleaning their own spaces. 
Under the new policy, the federal government has committed money to the cleanup, apparently without limit. "The most important message is that FEMA, our federal partner, has not said this is all there is," said Christopher O. Ward, the city's commissioner of environmental protection, referring to the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which will pay for the work. 
E.P.A. officials said that according to their initial estimates, 15,000 apartments will be covered by the plan, and that cleanup by a contractor for a typical two-bedroom apartment might cost $3,000 to $5,000. If every resident participates and each apartment is within that range, that would bring the cost to $45 million to $75 million, not including the possible expansion and reimbursement plans mentioned yesterday. 
At the news conference, Ms. Kenny and other city and federal officials strongly rejected any suggestion that waiting eight months after the disaster to begin a cleaning program for New York's interior spaces has put residents at risk. The collapse of the trade center towers blasted dust and ash, some of which contained asbestos or other potentially harmful materials, across a wide area of the city, including parts of Brooklyn. 
In fact, Mr. Ward said, the new cleanup program could validate what health and environmental officials have said all along: that most apartment interiors were not contaminated. 
The degree of participation will probably depend on whether inviting government apartment cleaners into one's home sounds reassuring or intrusive. The cleanups could take two to three days, officials said. The E.P.A. will set up a telephone number for the program by the end of the month, officials said.
Representative Jerrold Nadler, a Manhattan Democrat who also spoke at the news conference, said he would work to see that apartments were cleaned en masse, with every resident participating so that no dust or debris is left over to be tracked back into cleaned spaces.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
A Little Good News Goes a Long Way on Wall St.

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The stock market, encouraged by some good news on earnings, delivered its biggest one-day gain since September yesterday.
 Having shrugged off signs of an economic rebound for weeks, investors finally found succor in a profit report from a leading technology company, Cisco Systems, the report came out after the market closed on Tuesday. 
 Cisco and other technology stocks, which have slumped the last two months, led all the indexes in yesterday's rally, with the Nasdaq composite index jumping 7.8 percent, its biggest gain in more than a year and its eighth biggest ever. The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks had their best days since September, rising 3.1 percent and 3.8 percent, respectively. 
Shares of Cisco, which is the leading maker of networking equipment, surged more than 24 percent after the company said it saw some encouraging signs of recovery in its business and its quarterly profits were higher than expected. Microsoft, Intel, I.B.M. and Dell Computer also rose sharply.
Though technology stocks were the favorites, General Electric contributed to the market rally by announcing that it would probably meet profit forecasts for this year. Its stock jumped 7.2 percent.
"Investors have sniffed a little bullishness here," said William E. Rhodes, chief investment strategist at Rhodes Analytics in Boston. "It is not prudent to look at today's rally and say it is a flash in the pan. But it is not prudent, either, to say the market is ready to take off."
Outside the technology group, Citigroup, Caterpillar, J. P. Morgan Chase and Merrill Lynch were among the big gainers. Stocks of brokerage firms, Merrill in particular, rose on reports that the firm might be close to reaching a deal with the New York attorney general, who has said there are conflicts of interest and deceptive practices among the firm's stock analysts.
Mr. Rhodes said that the rally might have been fueled in part by short sellers, who had been betting that the market, and especially technology stocks, would continue to decline. Short sellers borrow stocks and sell them, hoping their prices will fall so they can buy them back for less and pocket the difference as profit. Many short sellers bought stocks yesterday, he said, to lock in their recent gains.
While institutional investors were the heaviest buyers yesterday, individuals were also snapping up stocks at a lively pace, according to Birinyi Associates of Greenwich, Conn., which tracks market movements.
Good news on earnings is precisely what investors have been waiting to see, and their exuberant response to Cisco showed just how important earnings reports would continue to be to stock market performance.
Stock prices have sagged since March, despite data indicating that the recession ended much earlier than expected. The economy grew at a 5.8 percent annual rate in the first quarter, and worker productivity rose 8.6 percent, the biggest gain since 1983. The surge in productivity should lead to higher profits, economists say. Meanwhile, inflation, outside of gas and other energy prices, remains in check.
"The sharp market response to the earnings release clearly illustrates the extent to which investors are focusing on the economy from the bottom up rather than from the top down," said Tony Crescenzi, chief bond market strategist at Miller Tabak & Company.
Profits at companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 have declined the last five quarters. Their earnings are expected to grow 1 percent in the second quarter, compared with a year ago, followed by sharp gains of 21 percent in the third quarter and 34 percent in the fourth, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
A modest rebound in earnings would lead to big percentage gains because earnings plunged the last six months of 2001, in the fallout from the terrorist attacks and the recession, making the comparisons easier.
But there has been precious little information to make investors believe that the second half will be as strong as projected. Until Cisco on Tuesday, few companies had said anything reassuring about a rebound in earnings.
"After so much bad news on earnings, a piece of apparent good news was enough to spark a rebound," said Chuck Hill, director of research at Thomson Financial. 
Still, he said the Cisco report may not have been as strong as it appeared at first blush, a warning echoed by Mr. Rhodes. "It was not an indication of robust growth," Mr. Rhodes said. "It was an indication of the end of decay."
The Dow rose 305.28 points, to 10,141.83, while the S.& P. 500 climbed 39.36 points, to 1,088.85. The Dow is now up 1.2 percent for the year but almost 500 points below its 2002 high. The S.& P. 500 is still down 5.2 percent for the year and is almost 85 points below its 2002 high.
The Nasdaq jumped 122.47 points, to 1,696.29. It is still down 13 percent for the year and more than 3,300 points from its high. While the percentage gain in the Nasdaq was reassuring, 14 of its top 15 days have come since March 2000, when the Nasdaq peaked. Since then, the index has fallen 66.4 percent in spite of those 14 record days.
As investors jumped back into stocks yesterday, the bond market slumped. The price of the reopened 10-year note auctioned by the Treasury yesterday fell 16/32, to 97 13/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, climbed to 5.22 percent, from 5.06 percent on Tuesday. The yield at the auction was 5.17 percent but rose as the new note was sold during the afternoon.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
TeaLeaves Set As Networks Haggle With Madison Ave.

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
The most telling evidence as to whether a recovery in advertising spending is in sight will come in the next few weeks, as the broadcast television networks and Madison Avenue begin their haggling over the purchase of commercial time worth $7 billion or more to be sold ahead of the 2002-2003 season.
 The annual mix of gamesmanship, posturing and spinning that surrounds the talks -- known as the upfront market -- could be more frenetic and fascinating than ever because of the recent roller coaster ride on ad rates. 
 The best guesses so far from analysts and executives on both sides of the upfront bargaining are that agencies will agree to spend on behalf of their advertiser clients about 3 percent to 6 percent more in the coming prime-time TV season than was sold ahead of time for the 2001-2002 season. 
The expected increase would represent a modest piece of good news for the networks. Last spring, the ad buyers found themselves in the driver's seat because of the sluggish economy and were able to bring down prices from the record they had reached for the 2000-2001 season, when an estimated $8 billion in ads were sold. As a result, the upfront ad revenue brought in by the six networks during last year's market declined by an estimated 15 percent, or $1 billion, to about $7 billion. 
Now the networks are hoping to make up lost ground after the introduction next week of their fall schedules at lavish presentations around Manhattan. History offers some guidance. "We've never had two back-to-back down upfronts, so you would expect some growth," said Joe Mandese, the editor of Media Buyer's Daily, a newsletter published by Primedia. Mr. Mandese predicts a rebound in the modest single digits, as advertising in categories like movies, automobiles and drugs should offset continued weakness in areas like financial services, travel and telecommunications.
There are, of course, no guarantees that the estimated increase of 3 percent to 6 percent, to $7.2 billion to $7.4 billion, will occur. Continuing uncertainties over the strength of consumer demand, centered on the pace of economic recovery and the potential for further threats to national security, cloud the outlook. And the caliber of the new programs and schedules the networks present beginning on Monday will help determine the upfront's outcome.
"To say the market's up, the market's down, is missing the bigger issue in the marketplace: Can we bring Americans back to the TV screen?" said Jon Mandel, co-chief executive for United States operations at MediaCom in New York, the giant media buying agency owned by the Grey Global Group.
"During the upfront presentations, I just want to see one series from each network that shows someone is trying to put on something different," he added.
The upfront always begins with the sellers predicting that robust demand will enable them to raise prices and with the buyers playing down their ardor for the merchandise, which in this instance are 30-second commercials on the prime-time series to be broadcast by ABC, CBS, Fox, NBC, UPN and WB from September through next May.
Each network usually sells about 75 percent of the spots it plans to run, holding back the rest to peddle during the season in what is known as the scatter market. If prices are higher in the scatter market, the networks get more revenue than if the spots were sold in the upfront. If prices are lower, they at least hedged their bets by selling most of the commercial time at higher rates.
The apportioning of sales between the upfront and the scatter markets is part of the strategy-setting that network executives are now pondering, just as their counterparts across the table are determining whether to buy sooner rather than later.
"The economy is still wobbly enough that the networks might want to sell more now," said Gordon Hodge, an analyst who follows media companies for Thomas Weisel Partners in San Francisco. "Last year, they played the game of chicken a little too hard" and were forced to cut prices when agencies balked at paying the higher rates the networks initially sought.
"Taking the money and running would not be a bad idea if the networks can get the pricing they want in this environment," he added. "Asking double-digit increases doesn't make a lot of sense, but it seems to us now that dollar volume could go up 6 to 8 percent."
One issue looming large for this upfront market is that many media conglomerates that own broadcast networks, including AOL Time Warner, the parent of WB, and the Walt Disney Company, the parent of ABC, are under increasing pressure from Wall Street to demonstrate quickly that business is improving.
"That influence on the sellers is making the upfront more complicated than ever before," said Jack Myers, chief economist at Jack Myers L.L.C. in New York, which publishes media and research newsletters.
"Investors are looking to the upfront as a sign of market strength," he added. That means, he said, that "sales executives are under pressure to deliver positive news," like selling more commercial time in this upfront market than last year's even if they might be able to charge higher prices later in the scatter market.
As the early assessments of the upfront market are being made, a consensus is emerging that among the network players, the weaker hands are held by ABC and Fox, which is part of the News Corporation. Both networks suffered steep ratings declines in the 2001-2002 season that forced them to offer compensatory spots to advertisers known as make-goods.
Conversely, the stronger hands are held by CBS, which gained viewers for series like "C.S.I." and will finish the season in second place in the ratings; NBC, which will finish first; and WB, which continues to attract the coveted younger viewers who are typically harder to reach. How NBC sales executives play their cards may provide the key to the market. Last May, when NBC, which is owned by General Electric, reversed course and cut prices after refusing for a month to do so, advertisers suddenly raced to buy commercial time, forcing most other networks to reduce their rates, too.
This time around, "there are factors that could lead to a strong upfront," said Joseph Abruzzese, president for network sales at CBS, which is part of Viacom. Among them he listed the recent "fairly strong scatter market," with some prices 15 percent to 20 percent higher than was obtained in the upfront market, and signs of demand from advertisers like auto and drug makers as well as entertainment and telecommunications companies.
Mr. Abruzzese will be wearing two hats during the upfront negotiations, also selling spots for UPN, a CBS sibling in the Viacom empire. 
The upfront chess match may be somewhat less crucial than in previous years, said Jed Petrick, the president and chief operating officer at WB in Burbank, Calif., because "buying and selling is now a 52-week game." Mr. Petrick added that "more and more advertisers are holding on to their money till the 11th hour and placing buys closer to the air date."
The upfront market usually begins one to four weeks after the fall-season presentations and can last one to three months. Last year, the talks began in early June and ended by the July Fourth weekend; in 2000, they began right after the presentations and concluded by Memorial Day.
After the broadcast networks finish their upfront market, similar negotiations start for cable TV networks and syndicated shows.

HEADLINE: $200 Million May Be Needed For Budget Gap 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 8 

 BODY:
With the end of New Jersey's fiscal year just eight weeks away, an unexpected drop in state tax revenues has forced the McGreevey administration to identify at least $200 million in additional revenues or spending cuts to balance the budget by July 1. 
 Although the treasurer's office would not release exact figures, state officials said that the April 15 tax receipts, which include quarterly payments from businesses, were more than a half-billion dollars less than expected. Since taking office in January, Gov. James E. McGreevey has sought to balance this year's budget by draining surpluses from several special funds, slashing spending and laying off hundreds of state workers. 
 But the shortfall in April tax receipts will eliminate the $500 million Mr. McGreevey had dedicated to the reserve fund, and prompted the governor to ask department heads to prepare for another round of budget cuts. Administration officials said the struggling economy was to blame for the drop in tax revenues. The state also expected to reap an additional $220 million by closing a corporate loophole, but that has brought in only $52 million. 
State Treasurer John E. McCormac said the numbers were still being tallied, and he declined to comment on the matter until the accounting has been completed.
But Assemblyman Louis D. Greenwald, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, said overall tax collections were likely to be $700 million lower than the $20.9 billion the state had been anticipating. The State Constitution requires that New Jersey end the fiscal year with a balanced budget, and Mr. Greenwald said the McGreevey administration apparently intended to find $200 million in new savings or revenues and deplete the $500 million surplus.
"Our requirement is to finish the year with a balanced budget; we need one penny in the bank," Mr. Greenwald said. "The reality is, that is where we are today."

HEADLINE: Impasse on Budget Extends Legislature in Connecticut 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 8 

 BODY:
For the second consecutive year, Connecticut lawmakers have been forced to extend their annual legislative session, because of an impasse between Democrats, who control the Legislature, and John G. Rowland, the Republican governor, over how to spend a $500 million increase in the state budget. 
 The Legislature ended its regular session at midnight tonight, having passed several significant bills on the environment and greater oversight of the state trash authority after its record loss of public money in a failed deal with the Enron Corporation, and stricter prohibitions on coaches and teachers who have sex with school-age minors under their supervision. 
 This evening, the House of Representatives also approved a bill creating tougher punishments for pedophiles, which the Senate amended and passed after a contentious predawn debate. The amended bill would greatly lengthen the statute of limitations on sex crimes against children and forbid out-of-court settlements that prevent defendants from speaking to the police. It would also expand the list of occupations required by state law to report information on sex crimes against minors to the police, adding parole and probation officers and coaches. 
The most contentious portion of the original bill, stricken by the Senate, included a provision that some Catholic lawmakers opposed because they said they believed it would require clergy members to report sexual abuse allegations made to them during confession. Their concern was that the provision would force priests to choose between obeying state law and the Catholic prohibition against disclosure of statements made during confession. 
Mr. Rowland said he would sign the amended bill into law. 
As both legislative chambers plowed through rafts of last-minute bills today, what remained unresolved -- dead in the water, actually -- was a problem that many other state legislators only wish they had: How to spend a roughly $500 million, or 4 percent, increase in Connecticut's budget for the 2003 fiscal year and close a $350 million deficit, which pales in comparison to other states' budget shortfalls. 
Despite indications of a compromise budget last week, Mr. Rowland and Democrats who lead the House and Senate each expressed exasperation with the other over how to bridge next year's budget gap. Democrats favored increasing some taxes and creating a tax on millionaires. Mr. Rowland and Republicans in the legislative minority want to close the gap by reducing spending on key programs, including education aid to cities and towns. 
Kevin B. Sullivan, the Senate president pro-tem, said today that his party tried to meet Mr. Rowland halfway last week, offering $175 million in spending cuts, only to have the governor come back this week and reject the offer.
Mr. Rowland, for his part, criticized legislative Democrats as old-time tax-and-spenders who understood neither what was good for the state's economy nor his unwillingness to begin to negotiate a nominal tax increase. He said he would probably be open to a small tax increase, but not until they offered a more viable package of spending cuts. 
Because Connecticut passes two-year budgets at a time and this is a mid-budget year, lawmakers are not under any constitutional pressure to pass a revised budget. But Democrats acknowledged that another late budget made them look inefficient, and Mr. Rowland warned that "there could be layoffs" of state workers if negotiations dragged on for months, as he said he thought they might. 
Aside from the budget, the Legislature and Mr. Rowland succeeded in creating laws to help protect the environment. The biggest accomplishment, both sides agreed, is a law, similar to a bill Mr. Rowland vetoed last year, that forces Connecticut's six remaining coal- and oil-fired power plants to reduce sulphur-dioxide emissions and phase out the practice of buying emission-reduction credits from other power plants to meet federal clean-air standards. 
Lawmakers also passed new protections for shellfish in Long Island Sound after Democrats failed to temporarily halt the construction of a cross-sound electric cable from New Haven to Brookhaven, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Adelphia to Put Some Cable Systems Up for Sale 

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Adelphia Communications said yesterday that it was putting several of its cable systems on the market in an effort to raise cash.
 The company is offering its Southern California system, with more than 1.2 million subscribers, as well as systems in Florida (750,000 subscribers), Virginia (575,000) and the Carolinas and Georgia (a total of 225,000 subscribers). 
 According to a person close to the company, Adelphia is putting up for sale systems with more than 2.7 million subscribers out of its total base of 6 million, but wants to sell only about 2 million worth.
Adelphia, the nation's sixth-largest cable television company, has been struggling since it acknowledged late in March that it had guaranteed more than $2.3 billion in loans to entities controlled by the family of its chairman, John J. Rigas. The family used some of the proceeds to buy Adelphia stock and bonds. 
Adelphia stock has taken a beating. Last week, the company said it would restate its financial results for the last three years to include on its books more than $1 billion of the loans -- a figure that puzzled some investors. Shareholder suits are pending. A federal inquiry into the loans is under way.
The news that Adelphia was preparing to raise cash, announced after the market closed yesterday, did little to change the view of one institutional investor, who said that the company was not likely to find eager buyers in the current marketplace, where the stocks of many media companies are severely depressed. 
He said that the Los Angeles cable system was the most likely sale, but added that since some 780,000 subscribers in that market were part of a joint venture with AT&T, Adelphia would not keep all the proceeds from a deal.
Besides, he said, the likely buyers there were Charter Communications and AT&T, but AT&T is in the midst of a merger with Comcast and Charter might not have adequate resources. That meant the entrepreneur Paul G. Allen, who is chairman of Charter and who has been building a war chest to expand in cable, might buy the systems directly. There was not likely to be a lively bidding war.
Matthew Harrigan, an analyst at Janco Partners in Denver, said the proposed sale would not really solve Adelphia's problems. He said that by selling, Adelphia was losing value because cable operators are more efficient as they gain economies of scale. In addition, he said, Adelphia is offering its more attractive systems, which generate higher revenue.
Mr. Harrigan said that the family had been "quite recalcitrant" about acknowledging Adelphia's problems, and that "the stock price will always be in the penalty box as long as the Rigases are there."
The Rigas family declined to comment.
In a press release yesterday, Mr. Rigas said, "I am confident that the steps we are taking will enable us to achieve our objectives of reducing debt, deleveraging our balance sheet, and creating a stronger Adelphia."
But both the institutional shareholder and Mr. Harrigan said that any asset sales would not immediately solve Adelphia's problems because it would take at least a year for the sales to close.
The company has yet to file its financial data for 2001. Because it has been both slow to acknowledge the loans and is unclear about the amounts, investors are skeptical about what the financial filings might disclose.
Adelphia has not yet given a specific date for publishing the overdue reports. "They want to hang on by buying time by selling systems at high prices," the institutional investor said.
An analyst who insisted on anonymity said Adelphia had little choice but to sell assets because it could not borrow in the public market, having lost credibility. "They can borrow from the banks, but they first have to pay down existing loans," the analyst said. "And currently, they are coming very close to the limit of their bank borrowing."

HEADLINE: As McGreevey Unveils a Plan For New Arena, Critics Scoff 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 8 

 BODY:
Taking on a project that eluded two of his predecessors building an arena for the New Jersey Nets and Devils in Newark -- Gov. James E. McGreevey announced the outlines of a new financing plan today that he said would not put taxpayers at risk if revenue from the project slowed or dried up.
 But the governor acknowledged that the plan still hinged on several uncertainties: working out a number of details with the YankeeNets, which owns the teams; drafting a redevelopment plan for the state-owned Meadowlands site; and selling it all to a legislature that has seemed cool to any state involvement in building a new arena. 
 And the timing of Mr. McGreevey's announcement, just a week before Mayor Sharpe James faces Councilman Cory Booker in the most hotly contested race in Mr. James's 32-year political career, gave opponents of the plan fresh ammunition. 
Aides to the governor weakly fended off suggestions that the news was timed to help Mr. James, a staunch ally of the governor. But a group of Bergen County officials gathered later in the day to call the project a "pawn in a local political campaign."
The proposed $355 million, 18,500-seat arena, which would replace the teams' current home, the Continental Airlines Arena in the Meadowlands, could open as soon as the 2005 season. 
Mr. McGreevey announced the preliminary agreement with the YankeeNets to much applause from an audience at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here. He was joined by Mayor James, half a dozen members of the Newark City Council, two former governors and a number of state legislators in trumpeting the proposal, which aides said would result in more than $1 billion in economic activity and thousands of construction and permanent jobs. A beaming Mr. James said the project would make Newark "the comeback city of America."
But Mr. Booker later dismissed the plan as "a performance designed to trick Newark citizens into voting for Sharpe James by promising them the same arena that he's been promising them for years."
Under the plan, the state's Sports and Exposition Authority would issue $165 million in construction bonds, to be repaid from tax revenue generated at the arena, an adjacent hotel and a parking complex. To protect the state if the revenue fails to cover the estimated $12 million in annual debt, the YankeeNets would have to buy insurance to make up for any shortfall. In addition, the governor said, the team owners would be responsible for any cost overruns.
The preliminary agreement calls for the YankeeNets to make an initial investment of $120 million in the arena, which the organization would operate and manage for two decades. All along it has been projected that Essex County would contribute $15 million to the proposed arena and Newark would contribute $35 million.
New provisions revealed today allow for about $20 million in loans to make up the difference. George Zoffinger, executive director of the Sports and Exposition Authority, said the money was for planning, design and preconstruction costs.
About $10 million of that amount would come from a loan that the YankeeNets would make to the project; that loan could be repaid only with tax revenue left over after the debt on the bonds was paid. The remaining $10 million, Mr. Zoffinger said, would be made available as a loan from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. That money would be repaid to the state before the YankeeNets repaid itself for its own loan, and the state would in turn repay the Port Authority.
Len Coleman, the chief negotiator for the YankeeNets, called the financing plan "a tough prenuptial agreement." But it is worth it, he said, because the teams want to be in Newark. 
For the last three years, three governors have labored to get a Newark arena started, parsing the economics in a hundred ways and confronting legislators who were wary of any tax-supported sports project or demanded costly projects for their areas in exchange for their support.
These issues bedeviled Gov. Christie Whitman even as she was leaving for a post in the Bush administration in 2000. And efforts by her successor, Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, to satisfy legislative demands ended up sinking a similar arena financing plan that was paired with an ambitious redevelopment proposal for the Meadowlands.
After three months of negotiations with the YankeeNets, Mr. McGreevey is now seeking to decouple the construction of the arena and the redevelopment of the Meadowlands. But most lawmakers said no legislation to authorize an arena plan was likely to pass unless planning for the Meadowlands was well advanced and credible to officials of Bergen County, where the Meadowlands is located. In their news conference today, Bergen officials seemed unimpressed, as County Executive William P. Schuber chided the governor for informing them of the arena plan at the last moment.

HEADLINE: U.N. Session Begins to Tally The Perils of Being Young 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 8 

 BODY:
"We are street children. We are the children of war. We are the victims and orphans of H.I.V./AIDS."
 So declared the small but unshakeable voice of Gabriela Azurdy Arrieta, a 13-year-old from Bolivia this morning at the opening session of the United Nations General Assembly Special Session on Children. 
 It was the first time children were allowed to speak in such august chambers. So Gabriela, along with Audrey Cheynut, 17, from Monaco, both reciting a message drafted by a 300-member children's delegation to the meeting, did not squander the opportunity.
"We want a world fit for children," Gabriela said, her head barely peeking up from behind the lectern, "because a world fit for us is a world fit for everyone."
The three-day meeting, the first General Assembly session to be devoted to the world's youngest citizens, is intended to assess the plight of the world's children over the last 12 years, when the United Nations first set concrete goals to improve children's lives. 
The record spoke for itself: Some gains had been made in health and education, but 10 million children still die every year from preventable diseases and 120 million are not in school. Such a record prompted the secretary general, Kofi Annan, to reproach his peers.
"To the adults in this room, I would say: Let us not make children pay for our failures any more," he said in the opening remarks this morning to heads of state and children from more than 180 countries. "We the grown-ups must reverse this list of failures."
The conference is to produce a new list of goals for 2015 on everything from protecting children from war to caring for those orphaned by AIDS to offering children simple life-saving tools like measles shots. It drew 60 heads of state, 3,000 members of non-governmental organizations and hundreds of children.
But if the halls of the United Nations were awash with pledges about uplifting children, they were also riven with significant debates over their rights and desires.
Members of the United States delegation, noting their disappointment with the draft conference document, said today they would ask for abstinence to be included as part of the sexual education portion of the document.
"As President Bush has said, abstinence is the only sure way of avoiding sexually transmitted disease, premature pregnancy and the social and personal difficulties attendant to nonmarital sexual activity," Tommy G. Thompson, the Bush Administration's Secretary of Health and Human Services and the head of the United States delegation, told the General Assembly. 
"Our efforts include strengthening close parent-child relationships, encouraging the delay of sexual activity, and supporting abstinence education programs."
At a briefing with reporters later in the day, members of the United States delegation said they were also concerned that, among other things, the conference document did not include sufficiently strong language on protecting children under 18 from prostitution and pornography. 
Disappointment aside, members of the American delegation said, this conference is nothing like the Conference on Racism in Durban, where the United States walked out. They said they were optimistic about reaching a consensus. 
Conference documents, particularly on children's issues, are usually reached by consensus, rather than by a vote. The United States, like any other member nation, has the option of spelling out its reservations on specific provisions but accepting the conference document as a whole.
The American delegation has also urged that references to the phrase "reproductive health services" clearly exclude abortion. An American official contended that delegates from other countries had agreed privately that the phrase did not refer to abortion, but that they had not yet agreed to spell it out.
The question of how to handle abortion is a constant thorn on the side of United Nations conferences. Because "reproductive health services" can mean different things in different countries -- in some countries, abortion is part of the menu of options; in other countries it is illegal -- previous United Nations conferences sidestepped the dispute by leaving it to individual nations. 
Many other countries, including most of Europe, want to leave it that way. "It should be up to countries if and to what extent abortion should feature as an element within the constellation of reproductive health services," said a member of a delegation from a European country; he did not want to be named for fear of jeopardizing the negotiations.
The other sticking point for the American delegation is the degree to which the conference document can refer to a landmark 1989 treaty on children's rights. Along with Somalia, the United States is the only country that has not ratified the so-called Convention on the Rights of the Child. The treaty prohibits countries from using the death penalty against criminals under age 18, a practice permitted in many American states.
The treaty spells out a host of political, economic and cultural rights of children, and many children's advocates here said they hoped it would be the standard on which this conference document would be based.

HEADLINE: North Koreans Seek Asylum At Consulates In China 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 8 

 BODY:
Seven people tried to barge into consulates in the northeastern Chinese city of Shenyang today, the latest in a string of attempts by desperate North Koreans to gain political asylum by taking refuge in Western diplomatic compounds in China.
 Two people successfully scaled the wall of the American Consulate in Shenyang and were still inside as of nightfall. Another five, including a family with a 2-year-old, were caught by the Chinese guards as they rushed the open gate at the Japanese Consulate, according to South Korean aid groups concerned with the plight of North Korean refugees. 
 Japanese diplomats in Beijing lodged a protest with the Chinese Foreign Ministry this afternoon, asserting that the Chinese police had actually entered the Japanese compound to arrest two of the people, in violation of consular agreements. 
In a trend that has both angered and frustrated Beijing, 28 North Koreans have gained safe passage to South Korea by forcing their way into foreign diplomatic compounds in Beijing in the last two months. 
Human rights activists in the network that has assisted the North Koreans in these escapes say that such actions will continue, although they acknowledge that they have had to become more creative as the Chinese have tightened security around the diplomatic compounds.
"Others will follow," promised an e-mail message tonight from Norbert Vollertsen, a German doctor who used to work in North Korea and who has championed the asylum seekers. "Think about a flood of North Korean 'boat people' on ships from China to South Korea." 
In all cases so far, foreign diplomats have granted the refugees protection and refused to allow China to repatriate them. The Chinese authorities have reluctantly permitted them to leave China -- ultimately bound for Seoul.
China's official policy is that the North Koreans are economic migrants who come to China in search of food and should be repatriated if they are caught, in accordance with diplomatic agreements with North Korea. In practice, the Chinese police have been unenthusiastic about tracking them down, allowing an estimated 300,000 North Koreans to live illegally in China. 
But that tolerance has dissipated recently as China has struggled to deal with the spate of embassy invasions, which force it to confront a difficult problem.
Ever since North Koreans successfully entered both the German Embassy and American Embassy compounds 10 days ago, the Chinese have been busily stringing barbed wire and police tape around all embassy compounds here. 
Patrols have increased markedly in Beijing, but they had not changed in Shenyang, an industrial city where many countries maintain consulates. Shenyang sits just over 100 miles from the North Korean border. 
In the border region, aid workers say that the Chinese police have been much more aggressive in ferreting out illegal North Koreans. 
Most of the North Koreans first enter China in search of food or other basic goods. But the North Korean police tend to regard them as political criminals if they are arrested and returned. Those who have made repeated trips, or have had contact with South Korean groups, receive the severest punishment. 
The five people who were detained by the Chinese police while trying to enter the Japanese Consulate are all members of a family that has angered North Korean authorities with previous efforts to escape to Seoul, a human rights group said. Last June, other family members walked into the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Beijing demanding asylum and were subsequently resettled in Seoul. 
It is not clear how China will deal with North Koreans arrested while trying to enter foreign compounds. Last month, three North Koreans were detained by the Chinese police while trying to enter the compound of the South Korean Embassy in Beijing. The South Korean Embassy has requested that they not be sent back to North Korea, and they remain in Chinese custody.

HEADLINE: Vitriol of Newark Campaign Seeps Into Debate 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 8 

 BODY:
In their first and only joint appearance before next Tuesday's election, Mayor Sharpe James and his opponent, Councilman Cory Booker, engaged in a spirited -- and at times mean-spirited -- debate this evening, questioning each other's honesty, integrity and ability to govern while painting starkly different portraits of New Jersey's largest city.
 Mr. James, a 16-year-incumbent who is seeking a historic fifth term, attempted to belittle his opponent as inexperienced, naive and dishonest. Mr. Booker, a single-term councilman who was born the year Mr. James first entered City Hall as a councilman, blamed many of the city's woes, including rampant street crime, enduring poverty and failing schools, on Mr. James. He also used the debate to hammer away at one of his campaign's central themes: that the mayor's single-minded focus on reviving downtown has deprived most Newark residents of a better life. 
 "We do not need a mayor that brags about symbols or a renaissance but one that rolls up his sleeves and takes responsibility to make sure there's a substance of a renaissance," Mr. Booker said.
Mr. James returned fire by calling his rival a liar and a stealth Republican, a man who courts conservative dollars and would try to use vouchers to dismantle the city's public schools -- an accusation Mr. Booker denied. "Mr. Booker sounds good, looks good, but does not tell the truth," Mr. James said. "Mr. Booker believes we're the worst city and we're the worst people, and he's the only sane person in the city of Newark. I disagree. Newark's a good place to live, a good place to raise a family."
A third candidate in the nonpartisan election, Dwayne Smith, was also part of the debate, but he has failed to generate much excitement here, and both men largely ignored him. Mr. Smith, a former police officer who campaigns across the city carrying a plastic orange bat, said he would offer tax-paying residents free landscaping services, increase the number of traveling health vans and require young children to wear uniforms in school.
The hourlong confrontation, which was broadcast on Cablevision in New Jersey, was the first time voters here have seen the two main contenders confront one another in a public forum. Both men started out seemingly calm, but as the vitriol increased, Mr. James became flustered and agitated. At one point, he seemed to misunderstand a question, and his answer was unrelated.
Mr. Booker, appearing poised and confident, again and again returned to the same theme, that in four terms Mr. James had failed to bring widespread progress to one of the nation's most troubled cities. "Sixteen years is long enough," he said. "It's time for a change."
The mayor began the debate by extolling the day's announcement by Gov. James E. McGreevey that an arena deal for Newark had been reached. Calling it "a great day for the city," he went on to list the economic benefits of the arena and potential events that might take place there. "Just think about it," he said proudly. "Family entertainment. The Nets, the Devils, Ice Capades, Disney World on Ice. I'll even try to get Tina Turner."
But in his rebuttal, Mr. Booker tried to play down the announcement, saying it was simply a well-timed ploy to win support for the mayor, and he offered his own list: of proposed projects that never materialized.
"We can no longer have election-time performances," he said. "What we need is a mayor that all the time can be focused on improving our neighborhoods."
Until this evening, Mr. James had skipped or canceled a dozen candidate forums and debates, saying he was too busy with the business of running the city to take part. Mr. Booker's supporters said the mayor was ducking his opponent.
A titan of Newark politics for the last three decades, Mr. James, 66, is a skilled fund-raiser and a confident campaigner who until recently was considered unbeatable. But Mr. Booker, 33, who entered the Newark political scene in 1998 by trouncing a Central Ward fixture, has been slowly chipping away at Mr. James's grip on power. Although the mayor enjoys the support of New Jersey's top Democrats and eight of Newark's nine City Council members (all but Mr. Booker), recent polls suggest a tight race. The results of a WABC-TV poll released last Friday showed the candidates in a statistical dead heat, and most political experts say that what once seemed a long-shot bid to unseat Mr. James has entered the realm of possibility.

HEADLINE: Lessons From the Mideast Agony 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Hijacking Mideast Peace" (editorial, May 8):
 Diplomacy leading to an equitable political settlement is the only way to achieve security for Israel's citizens, not the sale of more arms. 
 Israel received more than $18 billion in weapons and military equipment from the United States between 1991 and 2000. This quantity of arms has not brought greater security for Israeli citizens. Instead, Israeli use of American-supplied military equipment has increased the Palestinian desire for revenge and decreased Israel's own internal security by strengthening extremist groups.
The United States should impose an immediate embargo on all military aid to Israel. By doing so, the Bush administration would strengthen its leverage on Prime Minister Ariel Sharon.

CHRIS LINDBORG
Washington, May 8, 2002

The writer is an analyst at the British American Security Information Council.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Robert St. James)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: National Briefing Northwest: Washington: Widening Income Gap 

BYLINE:  By Timothy Egan (NYT)

 BODY:
 The income gap between the Seattle metropolitan area and rural Washington is the widest it has been in 30 years, new Census Bureau figures show. King County, which includes Seattle, accounted for 38 percent of the state's wealth. Officials say that while Seattle's technology and dot-com economy rose and then fell in the 1990's, the state's rural economy remained stagnant or declined.
 Timothy Egan (NYT)

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Witness for Microsoft Sees Wide Harm From Penalties

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8 

 BODY:
Tough antitrust penalties sought by nine states against the Microsoft Corporation would hurt consumers and encourage other companies to use federal antitrust law as a substitute for their own research and development, an economist said today.
 Testifying as an expert witness for Microsoft, Professor Kenneth G. Elzinga of the University of Virginia said the remedies proposed by the states would raise consumer prices and stifle innovation by Microsoft and other high-technology companies. 
 Professor Elzinga said that if Microsoft is required to disclose technical information about its Windows operating system, as the states propose, the result would be "a dampening of incentive" for companies to do their own research and development. 
"Forcing any firm to share its intellectual property with rivals reduces incentives to innovate in the future," he said. 
The nine states have refused to go along with a settlement the Justice Department reached with Microsoft last year. In addition to the disclosure of product technical information, the states want the company to release a modular version of its Windows operating system that will permit computer manufacturers to replace Microsoft features with competing products. 
Professor Elzinga has testified as an expert witness for Microsoft in two previous cases, and Steven Kuney, a lawyer for the states, questioned him extensively about his connection to Microsoft. 
Mr. Elzinga acknowledged that Microsoft had financed some of his early research into the software industry and that he has never concluded that the company "has monopoly power of antitrust concern." 
Asked by Mr. Kuney if he thought consumers were hurt by the anticompetitive behavior that an appeals court found Microsoft had engaged, Professor Elzinga said he was not asked to make such an assessment. Instead, he said, he was asked to compare the states' proposed remedy with the negotiated settlement "through the lens of consumer welfare." 
He said consumers might benefit if computer makers were allowed to remove Microsoft programs that come packaged with Windows and substitute the software of competitors, as the states have proposed. But the professor said such a practice might also curtail innovation by Microsoft. 
"It's like putting everything on a Christmas tree. Sometimes when you put everything on a Christmas tree it's not as attractive anymore," he said. "Sometimes you have to consider the costs." 
In his direct testimony, Professor Elzinga said he had evaluated claims that the negotiated settlement contained numerous loopholes that render it ineffective and found them "not to withstand scrutiny." But under questioning by Mr. Kuney, he said that in several instances he did not have the technical expertise to evaluate the supposed loopholes cited by the states.
Professor Elzinga, who is one of Microsoft's final witnesses, said many of the penalties proposed by the states are unrelated to the findings of antitrust violations and appear intended more to protect Microsoft's competitors than consumers.

HEADLINE: Vote on an Offshore Tax Plan Is Roilinga Company Town 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

DATELINE: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., May 8 

 BODY:
Over the last 159 years Stanley Works has come to dominate this central Connecticut town, producing tools with the yellow logo that has made it a brand well known in every other American town. But if its shareholders approve a proposal in a vote on Thursday, Stanley will become a Bermuda company in address only, with its legal residence in Barbados.
 The company says its plan will slash its income tax bills by at least 28 percent -- $30 million a year -- and predicts that the resulting higher cash flow could by itself raise its stock price by 11.5 percent. Tax experts say the saving could be much higher. 
 That does not sit well with a lot of people here and elsewhere -- with workers, residents and even some large investment funds. Such critics hope to turn this vote into a referendum on whether the growing number of American companies with proposals similar to Stanley's should be allowed to promote the interests of shareholders without also considering the interests of the nation and the companies' home communities. 
"This is really about the future of the corporation in America," said Stephen Sleigh, director of strategic resources for the machinists' union. "Are companies going to stay loyal to our country and grow jobs here, where they made their money? The notion that stock price is the only measure of a company's value is shortsighted."
It is unclear whether Stanley will win this vote -- the proposal requires the approval of two-thirds of all shareholders to be passed. But Stanley's proposal has a lot of support. 
The company says it has no choice, and its situation says a lot about the struggle of American businesses to remain globally competitive and satisfy their shareholders. In the past, many chief executives said they had obligations to a number of constituencies -- not just to shareholders, but also to customers, employees and their communities. But Stanley's chief executive, John M. Trani, is one of a number of executives who, under pressure from Wall Street, have narrowed that definition.
Mr. Trani says his obligation is to his shareholders. "At the end of the day," he told The Hartford Courant in 1997, "it's the final score that counts. In this stuff, I'm paid to make money for the shareholders." (He declined to be interviewed for this article.) 
The 57-year-old son of a Brooklyn longshoreman who grew up in Italy, Mr. Trani played recreational tackle football without pads or a helmet when he was a student at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn in the 1960's. He worked briefly as an analyst on Wall Street and later joined General Electric, where he was among 10 or so rising stars thought to have a shot at the chief executive job, then held by John F. Welch Jr.
Mr. Trani has learned to talk tough and play tough. He says Stanley's plan is not just legal, but ethical. And he says it is necessary because his competitors -- from Taiwan metal-forging companies to Ingersoll-Rand, which itself became a Bermuda company last year -- benefit by paying lower taxes.
But even some big investors that own Stanley stock and would, in theory, benefit from the plan say they will vote against it. Among them are the state pension plan here in Stanley's home state as well as those in New York and California, and various union pension funds.
Sarah Teslik, executive director of the Council of Institutional Investors in Washington, which represents 110 pension funds and other institutional investors, said the group was studying how to advise members during an unexpected wave of such plans.
"We have a lot of members who are disturbed by these moves," Mrs. Teslik said, "because they do benefit shareholders through higher stock prices, but they also affect jobs and everyone's taxes."
Here in New Britain, a city of 71,000 where Stanley has its headquarters, it is hard to find anyone who favors the plan -- not the mayor nor the president of the Chamber of Commerce nor Stanley workers. While the company will still pay some property taxes here, some who understand the details of the Bermuda plan worry that it will lead the company to ship more jobs abroad.
Under Stanley's proposal, the company would not actually move its headquarters to Bermuda; it would merely incorporate there. That requires only a mailing address. Stanley would also register as a corporate resident of Barbados, where it would need to hold only one meeting a year to qualify as "centrally managed and controlled" from there. 
Under this plan, Stanley would no longer owe United States income taxes on profits earned abroad. (Bermuda has no income tax.) More significantly, profits earned in the United States could be shipped abroad and, under a treaty with Barbados, turned into tax deductions. All Stanley would owe on those profits would be a 1 percent tax in Barbados.
Five Houston companies, including Nabors Industries and Weatherford Industries, are asking their shareholders to approve the same move later this year.
Executives of companies that have gone to Bermuda or plan to go say that such proposals will become more common unless Congress fundamentally changes the way corporations are taxed because some profits may be double-taxed and rivals in tax havens pay little or no tax.
Mr. Trani has some important backers. Institutional Shareholder Services, which advises pension funds and other large investors, supports approval of Stanley's plan because lower taxes should mean a higher share price. The organization warned that "there is already fierce and credible opposition" in Congress, though it discounted the threat that Congress might undo the move.
Opponents of such plans make several points. Some say it is just not patriotic to stop paying income taxes and leave the burden to others. Mayor Lucian J. Pawlak of New Britain said, "We will be a much poorer city and America a much poorer country as companies move out jobs and machinery, pay less in taxes and take away the jobs that hard-working people without much education used to get their kids into college." 
Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, has said in Congressional hearings that Stanley "has its heart in Bermuda" and its behind in America. Together with Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, he has introduced legislation to remove the tax savings in such deals, calling them unpatriotic in a time of war.
Others, like Connecticut's treasurer, Denise L. Nappier, and New York's comptroller, H. Carl McCall, say the plan is unfair because it reduces shareholders' rights, like the ability to enforce American court orders. (They do not plan to sell their states' Stanley shares if they lose the vote, however.) The company says the changes are minor.
Still others say the plan will encourage Stanley and other such companies to ship more jobs and money abroad. Once profits are shipped to Barbados, they can be invested tax free in factories abroad, but if the money is returned to the United States, it becomes taxable again.
Many people in New Britain are worried because in the past decade Stanley has eliminated 90 percent of what had been 5,000 blue-collar jobs here, replacing union machinists with less expensive workers in China, Mexico and other countries.
Donald D'Amato, president of a machinists union local representing the last 500 production workers here, said: "Trani said he will always go to the lowest-cost producer, and that means he is out of the U.S. because we can't compete with China." Union wages in New Britain are $10 to $20 an hour, he said.
At a small grocery across from City Hall, the owner, Iftekhar Siddiqui, said his business had declined as Stanley eliminated jobs. 
Mr. Siddiqui, who has a master's in business administration, said people here were angry because they thought Stanley's manipulation of tax and labor laws could spell economic ruin for themselves but riches for the 10 percent of Americans who own 86 percent of all stocks.
"The C.E.O.'s job is not just profit," Mr. Siddiqui said. "He has to think about the welfare of society. You have to have a country that is healthy to have profits. If Stanley does this, a lot of other companies will follow, and they will invest the money they made here in China, and a lot of our labor force in this country will become unemployed. Fewer and fewer people will have disposable income. You have to have balance." 
Over on Broad Street, Gregory Adamski, who came from Poland 18 years ago and runs the Cracovia Restaurant, said, "When Stanley Works moves out, they ship the machinery to China, and that means our taxes will increase so they can pay less." 
Herb Holter, who owns a hair-cutting salon, said that when he arrived in 1957, at 16: "New Britain was a buzzing place, and everybody was working to get ahead. Now Stanley just wants to make a lot of money for shareholders and the C.E.O. Soon there'll be no jobs, and then who is going to buy Stanley tools?"
Mayor Pawlak said he would be surprised if anyone in New Britain spoke favorably about the company, which he said had seemed focused only on its stock price since Mr. Trani took charge five years ago.
"All those guys walking around with missing fingers and hunchbacks made Stanley," the mayor said, "but Trani doesn't want to hear that."

 BODY:
Andersen Reaches Deals To Sell Parts of Its Business
Arthur Andersen announced separate deals with KPMG Consulting, Deloitte & Touche and Ernst & Young to sell various parts of its business.
 Andersen is expected to try to rush to conclude a series of transactions before the criminal case against it goes to a jury at the end of the month in Houston. Page C8. 

Lawyers for a former Arthur Andersen partner who pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice asked a federal judge to halt the firm's efforts to subpoena their notes of their client's interviews with government officials. C8.

Qwest's Yellow Pages Draw Bidders
Qwest Communications International received at least three bids worth more than $8 billion for its yellow pages business. The sale could become the biggest leveraged buyout since Kohlberg Kravis Roberts bought RJR Nabisco in 1989, executives close to the auction said. Qwest is trying to reduce its debt load of $25 billion. C6.

Global Crossing burned through nearly $140 million of its cash in March but still met the expectations of its creditors by reporting revenue of about $281 million for the month. C6.

Adelphia Communications said that it was putting several of its cable systems on the market in an effort to raise cash. C9.

The Regal Entertainment Group, a nationwide group of movie theaters, offered 18 million Class A shares in an initial public offering after the market closed. Demand for the stock, which was priced at $19 a share, vastly outstripped the available supply. C4.

Stanley Works hopes to become a Bermuda company in address only, in an effort to save significantly on income tax bills. A1.

Polaroid's Chief Executive to Resign
Polaroid said that its chief executive, Gary T. DiCamillo, would resign effective July 1 to become president and chief executive of a staffing services firm. C4.

Measure to Extend Farm Aid Passes
The Senate passed and sent to the White House a farm bill that greatly increases spending on agriculture and reverses a six-year decision to wean farmers from subsidies. President Bush has said he will sign the measure. A35.

Kirch Pay TV Unit Seeks Protection
The Kirch Group's pay-television company filed for bankruptcy after negotiations with creditors collapsed. Its Premiere pay television network, which lost nearly $900 million last year, may not have enough cash to cover losses beyond this summer. But Georg Kofler, chief of KirchPayTV, said it would continue to operate as the company looks for new investors. World Business, Section W.

British Push to Open Media Sector
Investment bankers said the proposal by Britain to abandon many restrictions on media ownership would probably touch off a heavy round of courting among media companies, both in Britain and across the Atlantic.
World Business, Section W.

Debate Over Valuing Stock Options
In the last decade, options have become a significant component of executive compensation in many industries. The debate surrounding options is how to value them in corporate accounts. Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. C2.

Shareholders of Mentor Graphics supported a plan that would allow them to have a say when the company makes plans to hand out stock options. Market Place. C9.

HEADLINE: Canaries' Signal On Environment 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Bush to Allow Mining Industry to Fill Streams" (news article, May 4) brought to mind the old tradition of using canaries to warn miners of toxic gas. We are witnessing the modern-day equivalent of those canaries, and it is time for President Bush to recognize the message our environment is sending. 
 A new Environmental Protection Agency report indicates that nearly half of America's coastal waters are polluted. The East Coast is facing a record-breaking drought. Virus and disease threaten oysters and rockfish in the Chesapeake Bay. 
The administration's response has been to push for oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and to roll back the Clean Water Act. President Bush is operating as if economic growth and the environment are competing interests. In fact, neither can survive without the other. 
Mr. President, the environment has sent a signal. It is time to pay attention to these 21st-century canaries.

PARRIS N. GLENDENING
Governor
Annapolis, Md., May 6, 2002

HEADLINE: Bush Names 2 for Federal Reserve Posts 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8 

 BODY:
President Bush has selected a Princeton economist and an adviser to Alan Greenspan as his nominees for vacant positions on the Federal Reserve, the White House said today.
 Mr. 
Bush chose Ben S. Bernanke of Princeton and Donald L. Kohn, a longtime Fed staff member in Washington. 
 Mr. Bernanke, 48, was nominated for the nearly two years remaining on the term of Edward Kelley Jr., who resigned in December. The term will run until Jan. 31, 2004.
Mr. Kohn, 59, was nominated for a 14-year term through Jan. 21, 2016. His seat became available with the departure of Laurence H. Meyer, who left in January after deciding not to seek another term.
With the two nominations, Mr. Bush will have picked five of the seven Fed board members.
Both nominees require Senate confirmation.
Mr. Kohn has been Mr. Greenspan's closest adviser on interest rate policy, serving for 14 years as director of the Fed's division of monetary affairs, the group that prepares briefing books for interest-rate-setting meetings.
In addition to his teaching duties at Princeton, Mr. Bernanke serves on the National Bureau of Economic Research's business-cycle dating committee, the panel that determines the dates when recessions begin and end. He has focused much of his research on monetary policy.

PERSON: Larry Aber 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
For City's Schoolchildren, the Healing Starts Here

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
THE reaction of Larry Aber's children to the 9/11 terrorist attacks sounds comic-book familiar. His 14-year-old son, Nick, took a page right out of the playbook of President George W. (Enemy of Evil) Bush. He was "determined to catch bin Laden and dip him in hot oil and crack the skin off him in a public square," Dr. Aber recalls.
 His 10-year-old daughter, Emma, focused on the victims, rather than the perpetrators. "Her empathy was so aroused she was not clear what to do with it," Dr. Aber says. "Baking cookies did not seem to her like a big positive thing." 
 With apologies to Nick and Emma, it can be hard to be the child of a psychologist. All too often, you are the convenient target of his well-honed scientific curiosity, an interesting diversion away from the office. But these days, J. Lawrence Aber has a bigger fishbowl to ponder than his own family. He is, in effect, the therapist for all 1.1 million New York City schoolchildren, and he has declared a large portion of them in need of healing.
Dr. Aber was the investigator, with his colleague, Dr. Christina Hoven, of a research project commissioned by the New York City Board of Education, to learn the impact of the attacks on the mental health of city schoolchildren. The study, released last week, found that as many as 200,000 children may suffer from mental health problems related to the attacks, exhibited in symptoms like depression, separation anxiety, agoraphobia, panic attacks, loss of interest in the future and bad dreams. He is an expert in what he calls "the epidemiology of development." Rather than studying mental illness in individuals, he studies it in entire populations.
Dr. Aber is the first to admit that there are built-in hazards to drawing sweeping conclusions about the data. To be accurate, he acknowledges, the results after Sept. 11 would have to be compared with results of a similar study conducted before Sept. 11, and there is no such baseline analysis for New York City schoolchildren.
"The things we found in this study about the level of children's mental health problems are not all caused by 9/11," Dr. Aber said the other day in his Columbia University office in Washington Heights. "I'm confident they have gone up, but we can't know for sure what level they were at before. It takes science a long time to learn how to reliably and sensibly measure things people want to know about in large populations."
This may come as some relief -- and perhaps little surprise -- to parents whose children suffered from nightmares before 9/11, and (like 17 percent of those in Dr. Aber's study) still wake up screaming now.
The point of comparison with New York was the so-called MECA study of 1996, which sampled children in metropolitan San Juan and Atlanta, inner-city New Haven and Westchester County.
Common sense, Dr. Aber says, suggests that New York City schoolchildren might be likely to suffer a higher than average rate of agoraphobia (15 percent in the Board of Education study, compared with 5 percent in the MECA study), because of preterrorist fears of stray gunfire and curb-jumping taxicabs. For New Yorkers, agoraphobia may not be an illness at all, but a perfectly rational defense strategy against the hazards of daily life.
"What's the old joke?" Dr. Aber says. "You're not paranoid if they really are after you."
The main lesson from the study, Dr. Aber says, is that there are a lot of festering psychological problems among city students, and it would be a good idea to deal with them every day, rather than reacting to an extraordinary situation.
Dr. Aber's main interest is not terrorism but how to mitigate the effects of poverty and violence on children's psychological development. His desk is stacked with books like, "Growing Up Fast," "Schools with Spirit" and "Understanding Poverty." He is director of the National Center for Children in Poverty and Professor of Public Health at the Joseph L. Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia.
Dr. Aber's own childhood was not without hardship. "My family's economic status changed frequently," he says. At various times, they were comfortable, lived on welfare, were working poor or lived on Social Security.
NOW 51, Dr. Aber was the eldest of six children. Born in Memphis, he went to eight grade schools in eight cities, moving to Pittsburgh when he was 12. He graduated from Harvard in 1973, and received his master's and Ph.D. in psychology at Yale.
When he was 19, his father died; when he was 24, his mother died. He had married Christine Pendry, a lawyer, six months earlier. The two of them raised the three youngest of Dr. Aber's five siblings, who were 16, 14 and 9. "They came to live with us," he says. "I was 24, my wife was 23." All six siblings are still close, Dr. Aber says. They have conference calls every Sunday.
It is a story that Dr. Aber, mild-mannered and somewhat timid, tells reluctantly. "I told you only because I wanted you to know," he says, "that I feel like I come by this interest honestly."

HEADLINE: At Least 14 Die in Attack on French Group in Pakistan 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND BONNER

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 8 

 BODY:
At least 14 people, most of them French, were killed and more than 20 seriously wounded today when a suicide car-bomber pulled a red Toyota alongside a shuttle bus in front of the Sheraton Hotel in downtown Karachi and exploded it. 
 The bus, operated by the Pakistani Navy, had stopped at the hotel to pick up the French civilians working on a submarine project for the Pakistani government. 
 Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, called the bombing an "act of international terrorism," and President Jacques Chirac of France said it was a "murderous, cowardly, odious terrorist attack." 
There was no claim of responsibility, but Western and Pakistani officials said the bombing had all the markings of an operation of the sort carried out by Al Qaeda, and they warned of more attacks. 
The attack, coming two months after a suicide bomber killed five people, including two Americans, in an attack on a church here in the capital, represented an ominous shift in the method, magnitude and targets of terrorist attacks in this country. 
Sectarian violence has been nearly endemic here -- a lawyer, a high-school principal and a doctor have been killed in the latest wave of killing -- but suicide bombings have been extremely rare. 
Moreover, in the past, the targets have been Pakistanis, Iranians or Americans. Today's attack, along with the attack on the church, which is in the diplomatic compound, were aimed "at the Western community," said a Western diplomat.
"Any place where foreigners gather is now vulnerable," he added. 
The two attacks appear to be linked, Pakistani officials said. The Western diplomat referred to them as "a one-two" and called today's attack "very well planned." 
The American Embassy in Islamabad warned American citizens in the country "to maintain a low profile and avoid predictable patterns and behaviors." 
There was no apparent link between the bombing and the trial of four men who are accused of the kidnapping and murder of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl, which resumed today in Hyderabad, about 100 miles northeast of Karachi. The trial had been moved from Karachi for security reasons. 
Once again, the trial, which prosecutors had originally said would be finished by mid-April, was put off, as defense lawyers sought to have the case moved back to Karachi.
There were fears that more attacks were likely here, aimed at foreigners and at the government of General Musharraf, who has sided with the United States in the war on terrorism.
"This may not be the end," Pakistan's minister of information, Nisar A. Memon, said at a news conference here this evening. "It appears their nefarious designs will continue."
He said he was not basing the warning on any specific intelligence but on the "historic facts in the last few months."
Today's attack raises fundamental questions about security here, and serious challenges for General Musharraf, diplomats and Pakistani political analysts said.
"If the government of Pakistan can't protect workers in the defense industry, what does it say for its security?" said one diplomat. 
The diplomat said General Musharraf must act decisively, within in the next two or three days. "If I were him, I would crack down with a vengeance," the diplomat said.
In an impoverished country already on the ropes economically, today's attack has caused "enormous damage," he said.
"Who is going to invest here now?" he said.
A senior Pakistani official agreed. "He has to act and act quickly," the official said, referring to General Musharraf. "We have to do more than issue a press release." 
But the measures announced by the government after General Musharraf met with his security advisers seemed modest and suggested how difficult it will be to prevent suicide attacks in this country, which has a long, porous border with Afghanistan and whose police officers are poorly trained and underpaid.
The government said that it was beefing up its intelligence gathering and security at places where foreigners gather, which is what the government said after the church attack two months ago. 
Today, the government also established a toll-free hot line for people to report suspicious terrorist activity, and a Web site: www.geocities.com/wantedforterrorism.
Today's attack would also seem to underscore questions that have been asked recently about just how effective General Musharraf has been in his declared war on violent Muslim groups here. 
The president has banned several groups, and authorities have rounded up about 2,000 men suspected of links to terrorist organizations.
But nearly three-quarters of those arrested have been released and not a single person has been charged. "This raises fundamental questions about his follow-up," one diplomat said.
After the church bombing, the government promised a swift investigation and a report that was to have been finished by early April. But the report has not been released, and the authorities appear no closer to solving the crime. The identity of the man who blew himself up remains a mystery. 
Parts of his body have been sent to the United States, and Pakistan has asked for help in recreating his face and body. 
"The investigation is resting there," the senior civil officer in the Ministry of Interior, Tasnim Noorani, said at today's news conference.
