HEADLINE: 100-Year Flood, for the Second Straight Year 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES

DATELINE: KIMBALL, W.Va., May 8 

 BODY:
The business of undertaking was never more vital along storm-racked Main Street in this old Appalachian mining town as Jim Widener mucked out the casket display room of his funeral home today.
 "We're managing to handle the wake of Shirley Faye Mitchem," Mr. Widener said as this remote coal hollow reeled under the devastation of its second deadly flood in 10 months. 
 "Mrs. Mitchem was killed when the storm took down a tree on Route 52 that smashed into her car," said Mr. Widener, who had just finished restoring his funeral home from the effects of the flash flood last July when the second one swept through Main Street last Thursday and deluged his business once more. 
"Her husband, Edgar, is still on the critical list," added the undertaker, doing his best to clean up the premises so victims could properly grieve over a storm that has swept lives and homes to oblivion in the funnel-like confines of the area's steep creek-side hollows.
Rainstorms continue to besiege mountainside dwellers left isolated by flood damage here in McDowell County, in the southernmost reaches of West Virginia. The storm of last week killed six people in the county while destroying close to 200 homes and flooding more than 2,000 others. Five other flood-related deaths have been reported in a multicounty swath of hamlets along the winding Virginia and Kentucky borderlands of Appalachia. 
"Last July's storm was called the 100-year flood," noted Kimball's mayor, Jack Premo. "I guess this is a 101-year flood. We lost everything last time, including City Hall, and we've lost it all again with this one."
The town shuddered anew as Elkhorn Creek once again thickened with a flash storm and roared above its banks down Main Street, bursting the doors of restored businesses.
Residents here and in a half-dozen other coal hollows complain that the 100-year flood timetable of folkloric tradition has been dangerously accelerated by modern timber cutters and strip miners on the surrounding steep mountainsides. Industry maintains that its work here is accompanied by restoration efforts ensuring that no environmental damage is permanent. But stunned residents say natural runoffs, and trees that would otherwise help absorb the downpours, have been obliterated, so that flash rains roar down on towns like unimpeded avalanches. 
"The logging has been going on indiscriminately, and no one will help us control it," said Jean Battlo, a writer whose Main Street home and elaborate flower garden were deluged once more by the latest torrent. 
"Even Senator Rockefeller was asking about the timbering," Ms. Battlo said of Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, who toured the damage on Monday and asked repeated questions about the effects of timber clear-cutting on the land's ability to absorb and channel runoffs. 
"I rebuilt after July's flood; how stupid was that?" Ms. Battlo said as the town spent another anxious day under flash-flood warnings. "I've been writing a play about the Hatfield shootouts in the mining days, but I can see the fresh tragedy to be written here is all about the flooding," she said, vowing to stay and capture the story.
As they shoveled, hosed and mopped, the few Main Street merchants left in this town of 500 residents were vowing to clean up and reopen, if only because they had no alternative way of surviving.
"Everybody down this part of the country is tough," said Jimmy Gianato, the hardware dealer descended from Italian immigrant coal miners who settled Kimball when King Coal boomed along the Elkhorn.
"Our parents were tough, our grandparents tougher, and toughest were the old-timers from the old country," said Mr. Gianato, a member of this town's stalwart mercantile clan.
The Gianato hardware and grocery stores were ruined in the flood last July. At the time, Mayor Premo openly raised the question of closing down the town. The Gianatos and other leaders stayed and reopened last summer, only to be at the mops and shovels this morning.
The McDowell County region, one of the poorest in Appalachia, has been in a downward spiral for 50 years, with young people emigrating and welfare replacing coal as an economic force. The county now has only about one-fourth the population of 100,000 it had in busier days, when, long before machine-intensive strip mining, manual labor was at a premium. But retired miners like Mayor Premo, who worked 40 years underground, remain addicted to the beauty of the mountain hollows.
So when the flooding returned last week, "the older people just sat in their houses and cried," said Fran Lambert, a resident who pitched in to rescue aged neighbors.
"We couldn't get them to stand up and go to the cars," Ms. Lambert said. "It was hard for all of us to believe that this was happening all over again a year later."
It may take a week or more to even reach the more remote hollow communities like Avondale and Barton No. 3, disaster officials said.
"It breaks your heart to see a third of the houses in Coalwood gone, destroyed," said Jay Wilson, director of McDowell Mission, a Methodist charity. He is hoping for the return of hundreds of volunteers from across Appalachia who helped rebuild impoverished McDowell County hamlets last summer.
"Recovery truly depends on people pulling together," said State Senator John R. Unger II, who is coordinating the state disaster-relief effort. "And I have to marvel how people are doing just that, rising above their homes' being destroyed."
Residents complain strongly about the effects of lumbering and strip mining, noting in particular the Bush administration's new decision to ease coal waste restrictions on mountaintop mining. This process involves the decapitation of mountaintops by giant machinery that now will have more leeway in pouring wastes into nearby streams that environmentalists say are vital for storm management. A state study on the effects of mining and lumbering on the Appalachian hollows is expected this summer.
The Bush administration contends that the new policy on coal waste will be tightly controlled by the Army Corps of Engineers. But Mr. Widener, the undertaker, firmly insisted: "Timbering and mining have raped and ruined us. A hundred families left after the July flood, and now here's the fresh storm, the ground bursting open with nowhere for the water to go. We're left all scared and hesitant." --------------------

Judge Bars Mountaintop Permits
CHARLESTON, W.Va., May 8 (AP) -- A federal district judge ordered the Army Corps of Engineers today to stop issuing new permits for mountaintop coal mining.
The judge, Charles Haden II, said the Environmental Protection Agency and the corps had overstepped their authority by making recent changes to the definition of the types of materials that could be dumped in nearby waterways by the mining operations. He said only Congress could change the definition.
A spokesman for the corps, Steve Wright, said its officials had yet to read the ruling, which stemmed from a suit brought in February by an advocacy group, Kentuckians for the Commonwealth.

HEADLINE: Senate Passes Major Expansion of Farm Subsidies 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8 

 BODY:
The Senate today passed and sent to the White House an election year farm bill that greatly increases spending on agriculture and reverses a six-year-old decision to wean farmers from subsidies.
 Although the administration had resisted many of the subsidies in the legislation and a majority of Senate Republicans voted no, President Bush has said he will sign the measure. 
 Along with expanding big payments for grain and cotton farmers, the measure would also expand the food stamp program and restore the right of legal immigrants to receive them. The legislation also increases money for conservation and other environmental measures. 
The House-Senate conference report, which the House passed last week, was adopted today, 64 to 35. Voting for the bill were 43 Democrats, 20 Republicans and 1 independent. Seven Democrats and 28 Republicans were opposed.
Senator Tom Harkin, the Iowa Democrat who is chairman of the Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry Committee, said the bill restored a safety net for farmers that the 1996 Freedom to Farm bill had weakened. 
"This farm bill," Mr. Harkin said, "marks a new beginning by investing in the security and success of our farm families and in the economic future of our rural communities." 
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, said, "For the first time in many years, we will be able to send a message of hope to the farmers and ranchers of this country."
But the senior Republican on the committee, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, sharply disagreed. He said it would cause farmers to overproduce and would drive down prices and provide large subsidies to a few large farmers. He called the bill "an attempt in a closely divided Congress to try to help individual Senators and House members, with the thought that party control of either body may be a much more important objective than careful economic analysis or maybe even careful stewardship of the funds for which we are responsible."
The estimated 10-year cost of the bill is $180 billion, $70 billion more than the cost of current programs, and it would include $40 billion in subsidies for large cotton and grain farms.

HEADLINE: More Worry Over Loans By Big Banks In China 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 9 

 BODY:
Financial experts are expressing grave worries about the solvency of China's banking system, which may have a bad-loan problem several times as bad as Japan's.
 The head of China's central bank said recently that 25 to 30 percent of all bank loans were not being repaid. Today, the credit-rating agency Standard & Poor's estimated that the situation may be twice that bad, with half of all loans classifiable as nonperforming. And the agency found signs that the banks were busily making matters worse. 
 Without a robust banking system, it will be increasingly difficult for China to sustain rapid growth, attract foreign investment and develop the modern economy it needs to provide jobs and maintain social stability at a time of widespread disillusionment with the Communist ideology that united the country for 50 years. 
Standard & Poor's warned today that Chinese banks appeared to be trying to prop themselves up by issuing new loans at a furious pace, in many cases financing vaguely described projects with little discernible effect on China's overall economic output. This approach could yield even more bad loans, and may be creating a financial bubble of wasteful and mismanaged overspending of the kind that led to crises in many other East Asian nations in the late 1990's, according to Terry E. H. Chan, the ratings agency's director for Chinese and Southeast Asian financial institutions.
"Is the bubble building?" Mr. Chan asked at a news conference here today. "We are concerned. Where is the money going?"
Though a few privately owned and foreign banks have gained small footholds, China's banking system is dominated by four giant commercial banks, all state-owned. Questions have arisen periodically for a decade about the banks' viability, mainly because of the evident pressures on them to make uneconomic loans for various political reasons.
Beginning in 1999, the Chinese government sought to resolve these concerns by relieving the four big banks of $170 billion worth of bad loans -- 12 percent of loans outstanding -- and then writing off the loans or reselling them, following the same general approach that worked for the United States after the savings and loan crisis. 
But those efforts do not appear to have succeeded, Chinese and Western officials now say. Dai Xianglung, the central bank governor, said in a recent speech that even under the most generous accounting rules, one-quarter of the loans left on the books of the country's banks were nonperforming. New, more stringent rules being introduced will push the figure above 30 percent, other Chinese regulators have said.
The banks are gradually earning profits to offset the bad loans, Mr. Dai said in his speech. He called on the banks to get the bad-loan number down to 15 percent within five years.
By comparison, the highest estimates of the bad-loan situation in Japan, where banks have been in desperate straits for a decade and are very slow to write loans off, put the size of the problem at 15 percent or less of outstanding loans.
In the United States, banks are much more aggressive about writing off loans on which they are not receiving interest payments. At banks with assets of more than $1 billion, just 1.5 percent of loans were more than 90 days overdue on Dec. 31, according to data from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
Standard & Poor's is far from alone in its assessment of China's problems. Wei Yen, vice president for Chinese banking at Moody's Investors Service, also say that the bailout has failed. But he was less pessimistic than Standard & Poor's about the potential for Chinese banks to grow their way out of their problems by finding creditworthy new borrowers.
Mr. Yen said the four main commercial banks had made considerable progress in centralizing control over lending and in imposing strict risk controls. The goal of these measures is to insulate local branch managers against pressure from local politicians and factory bosses to make ill-considered loans.
"We don't dispute that the Chinese banking system has terrible problems, but if you take a long-term perspective and look at what they have done in the last five or six years, it's tremendous," Mr. Yen said, adding that Moody's would soon release its own report.
In the Mao Zedong era, Chinese banks were not businesses in the Western sense. They were conduits for distribution of state subsidies to local enterprises, and for collection of taxes and other contributions to national revenue from those enterprises. How much borrowers received had little to do with how much they repaid.
Beijing tried to put the banks on a commercial footing in 1994 by setting up three new institutions to take over the job of financing big state-owned enterprises, the ones that employed so many people that for the sake of social and political stability they could not be allowed to fail. The commercial banks were supposed to stick to making loans strictly on the financial merits from then on. But they do not appear to have done so.
China plans to open up its banking sector to international competition over the next five years as part of its entry to the World Trade Organization, which will put more pressure on domestic banks. Foreign banks now have less than 2 percent of all deposits and loans in China.
The four big domestic commercial banks -- the Bank of China, the China Construction Bank, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China and the Agricultural Bank of China -- are in various stages of preparing to sell minority stakes to public shareholders, in the hope of raising money to offset their bad loans.
The Bank of China is furthest along, and it had been expected to issue stock this year in China, Hong Kong and possibly New York. But its plans have been set back by several scandals in the last five months involving allegations of fraudulent loans to friends of bank managers.
Mr. Chan of Standard & Poor's predicted that the level of bad loans at Chinese banks would discourage international investors from buying any of their shares.
Moody's and Standard & Poor's usually agree on most credit ratings, but they have sharply divergent assessments of the four big banks. Moody's puts all four at Baa-1, three grades above the minimum to qualify as investment grade. But Standard & Poor's does not rate the Agricultural Bank at all, and rates the other three at BB+, a speculative rating four notches below Moody's.

HEADLINE: Regulate Casinos Fairly 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Court Decision Raises Question of Legality of New York Casinos" (news article, May 3): Indian casinos, operated by sovereign nations and separately governed by the federal Indian Gaming Regulatory Act of 1988, are essentially not subject to the laws, regulations and taxes covering everyone else in the country. 
 We in the non-Native American gaming industry face a regulatory system that is more stringent, which results in an unfair, anticompetitive marketplace. 
Even with equal regulation, Indian casinos would have an advantage since they can operate in states where legalized commercial casinos cannot. 
But stronger state and federal oversight of them would ensure that all casinos compete on a level playing field, remain free of illegal influence and are effective economic engines for all Americans.

JOHN M. GALLAWAY
President, Isle of Capri Casinos
Biloxi, Miss., May 9, 2002

HEADLINE: Japan Protests China's Arrest Of Koreans At Consulate 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 9 

 BODY:
With television relaying images of Chinese police officers dragging five North Korean refugees from inside a Japanese Consulate compound in China, Japan protested strongly today, seeking to head off a nationalist reaction against its powerful neighbor.
 After meeting with Wu Dawei, China's ambassador here, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said he believed that China had violated the Vienna convention governing diplomatic relations. "That's why we are lodging a protest," the prime minister added. "We are seeking a sincere response from the Chinese side." 
 Separately, a Japanese Embassy official in Beijing visited the Foreign Ministry there today to demand the release of the five detainees.
The news video shows two North Korean women screaming for help as they clung to the inside of a gate at the Japanese Consulate compound in Shenyang on Wednesday. Chinese police officers wrested the women away, detaining them along with a 2-year-old girl and two North Korean men who were inside the consulate.
In a separate incident on Wednesday, two North Korean men successfully took refuge in Shenyang's American Consulate. Today a third North Korean scaled the consulate wall and joined them.
The five detained North Koreans are members of the extended family of Jang Gil Su, a defector whose amateur sketches have brought home to many Americans the privations and police abuses in North Korea. With rights workers preparing an exhibit of the sketches in Washington this summer, a group of United States Congressional leaders urged China in a letter not to send the North Korean detainees home. 
"We strongly urge your government not to forcibly return any of them to North Korea, where they would face certain danger," read the letter from Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois and the chairman of the House International Relations Committee. Addressed to Yang Jiechi, China's ambassador to the United States, the letter was signed by three other members of the committee.
The State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said today in Washington that negotiations on the Koreans' fate were under way with China, adding, "We don't believe that North Koreans should be returned to face persecution in North Korea."
With as many as 300,000 North Koreans living illegally in northern China, Beijing fears that granting them refugee status would start an exodus from North Korea.
The asylum bids started in March, prompting the Chinese authorities to ring the main neighborhood for embassies in Beijing with barbed wire and to mount police patrols.
Yet another case, which occurred last week, highlights China's reluctance to draw bad publicity over the issue: a North Korean family detained while trying to enter the South Korean Embassy have reportedly escaped from a Beijing hotel where they were being interrogated by the Chinese police. The family included a pregnant woman. The Chinese may have been reluctant to deport her in light of rights workers' repeated descriptions of forced abortions in North Korean prisons.
Japan is celebrating 30 years of diplomatic relations with China, and officials fear that the detentions could provoke a nationalist outcry.
Sankei Shimbun, a conservative newspaper, attacked the detentions today as "a serious situation of violation of extraterritorial rights by the Chinese police" and faulted "the more than lenient attitude of consulate staff."
The video, which has been broadcast in China and is expected to be broadcast here on Friday, showed Japanese consular officials talking with North Korean women as they resisted arrest by the Chinese police officers. But, according to the Kyodo news agency, the video does not show Japanese officials moving to stop the arrests. The Japanese can be seen picking up the Chinese officers' hats, which had been knocked off.
"Foreign Ministry officials at the consulate could have taken different action if they had properly felt Japan's sovereignty was being infringed on," Kosei Ueno, deputy chief cabinet secretary, said today. "I think the staff should have taken the incident more seriously."
A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, Kong Quan, defended the police action as part of the war on terrorism.
"In the greater context of the global war on terrorism, the Chinese armed police on duty took away the people who rushed into the Japanese Consulate General illegally and whose identities are unclear," he said. Today, South Korea joined Japan and the United States in urging China to let the detainees leave China. So far this year, South Korea has taken in 312 North Koreans, twice the number for the same period of last year.

HEADLINE: Russia Delays U.N. Vote on Iraq Penalties 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 9 

 BODY:
Russia has asked for a delay until next week of a United Nations Security Council vote on an overhaul of sanctions against Iraq aimed at easing the flow of goods to Baghdad, according to diplomats.
 The five permanent Security Council members with veto power, including Russia and the United States, introduced a resolution on Monday and had hoped for a vote on Wednesday. 
 First Syria, a Council member, wanted a delay, and then Russian envoys told colleagues that President Vladimir V. Putin wanted to take a final look and sign off on the new plan. 
Russia, which helped negotiate the new plan, asked for the vote to be postponed until Monday but raised no new objections, the diplomats said late Wednesday night.
Central to the new program is a 160-page "goods review list" of items that may have dual military and civilian use and have to be evaluated separately before they can be exported. Goods not on the list can go to Iraq after review by United Nations officials. Military items continue to be banned outright.
Currently, any Council member can block a contract to Iraq, and the United States has put $5 billion worth of goods on hold. Russia, among others, has made sure many of its contracts are not on the list. The new plan promises to be the biggest change in sanctions procedures since the United Nations oil-for-food deal began in December 1996 to ease the effects of embargoes imposed when Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990.
This program allows Iraq to export oil and buy food, medicine and a host of other goods, with the proceeds placed in an escrow account from which suppliers are paid. The program, renewed every six months, expires on May 29.
Syria also raised misgivings about the new plan, with its diplomats saying they needed further instructions from officials in Damascus, who were studying the resolution that includes hundreds of pages of attachments.
But privately, diplomats said Syria cited the crisis between Israel and the Palestinians, questioning why it should vote quickly on Iraqi sanctions when the Council refused to condemn Israel for its offensive in the West Bank.
Although the vote can go ahead without Syria, which does not have veto power, the United States and others wanted to preserve Council unity. Paradoxically, Syria itself has been cited by diplomats and oil analysts for violating sanctions by illegally importing Iraqi crude oil.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Puzzling Out The Logic In Living Wage

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
PEOPLE who call themselves advocates for the poor are all for reducing the poverty rate in New York City, but it's not clear how they want to do it. Do they want the poor to climb the ladder to higher-paying jobs? Or would they rather reduce the poverty rate by keeping poor people out of town?
 No one, of course, likes to explicitly endorse the keep-them-out-of-town solution. You will not hear proponents of the City Council's so-called living-wage bill promising to reduce the number of jobs for the poorest and least skilled workers, even if that's what would happen. 
 The proposed law, which would mandate wages of at least $8.10 per hour at companies with city contracts, would help some workers while hurting those at the bottom of the ladder, like immigrants who can't speak English and have little education or work experience. These immigrants might find work as janitors if the pay is only $7 per hour, because employers have a hard time keeping those low-paying jobs filled. But if the pay increases, so does the competition. 
"When wages go up, employers look for better workers," said Richard Sander, a professor of law at U.C.L.A. who has studied the effects of living-wage laws in Los Angeles and other California cities. "Not only do some jobs disappear, but some of the lower-skilled workers are replaced." In Northern California, he noted, low-paying airport jobs were readily available before the living-wage law, but afterward the jobs became harder to get because there was less turnover and more competition from better-qualified workers.
If you want a specific example of the workers who would be affected in New York, look at the street cleaners wearing the blue uniforms of the Ready, Willing and Able program. These men and women, most of whom have been homeless and have criminal records, start out working for $5.50 per hour.
"The living-wage bill would raise the first rung of the economic ladder higher than our people should be reaching at this moment in their life," said George McDonald, president of the Doe Fund, which runs the program.
"Most of our people have been incarcerated many times. They get out of jail and have a hard time finding any job until we hire them. Then they graduate to a job in the private sector that pays more than the living wage as defined by this bill. We've gotten 1,200 people into jobs with living wages in the private sector at the same time we're making New York cleaner. It gets my Irish up to think that something could impede all that."
Mr. McDonald might manage to get an exemption for his training program, thereby sparing his workers and keeping some sidewalks clean. But other workers and services would be affected. There would be fewer jobs for the unskilled, and companies doing business with the city would either charge more or provide less. 
You could argue that, even with reduced services, the city as whole would be better off with a living-wage law because it would mitigate New York's extreme income inequality. With fewer low-paying jobs here, some of the least skilled workers would go elsewhere. Those particular workers would presumably be unhappy, but perhaps most New Yorkers would prefer living in a city with fewer people at the bottom of the economic ladder.
BUT that's not an argument that the "advocates for the poor" make when another issue comes up: gentrification. They can be quite forthright in desiring more poor neighbors, as I discovered from the reaction to a recent column describing some surprising research into gentrification.
The research showed that poor and working-class people in a neighborhood tended to benefit when it gentrified. Instead of being displaced, as popularly assumed, they become more likely to stay than they would be otherwise. They want to stay because the neighborhood's getting better, and many of them can afford the higher rents because of the new jobs that come with gentrification.
But those benefits weren't enough to satisfy some "advocates for the poor." Even if the poor people living in the neighborhood might not be displaced, the critics warned of "secondary displacement" caused by the rising rents. The people already in the neighborhood might be climbing the economic ladder, but other poor people wouldn't be able to move into the better neighborhood. 
By that logic, it's more important to keep poor newcomers arriving than it is to help the poor already living in the neighborhood. If you're confused by now, you're not alone.

HEADLINE: Factory Jobs, Then Workers, Leaving Poorest Southern Areas 

BYLINE:  By DAVID HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: KINGSTREE, S.C. 

 BODY:
This old farming and factory town in the rural South Carolina lowlands still has its charms, but they are lost on Sonya Alston, 22. She is planning to move to Charlotte, N.C., any day now.
 Ms. Alston had lucked out after graduating from high school in 1998 and landed a job at a latex-glove plant, where she turned wet gloves inside-out for $7.94 an hour -- enviable wages in Kingstree. 
 But in the fall of 2000, the company closed the factory, saying finished gloves could be made in China for less than what the company was paying for raw latex. After months on unemployment, Ms. Alston found a temporary job at a Tupperware plant 25 miles away. Her pay there is nearly as good as on her old job, but her hours have gotten pitiful.
"The last two weeks, we worked one day out of the week," she said. "They say there's just not enough orders."
That is the lament in Kingstree, the seat of Williamsburg County and the epicenter of the storm that has swept the manufacturing sector throughout the coastal Southeast. County officials say the exodus of people like Ms. Alston has shrunk the work force by more than 5,000 in recent years, but the unemployment rate -- 14.1 percent in March -- remains the highest in the state. The able-bodied workers who have not left their homes and families behind in Williamsburg -- or in Marion, Clarendon, Orangeburg and half a dozen other ravaged Black Belt counties -- often say that they would, if they could only figure out where the jobs are.
The recession's effects on manufacturing have been well documented in the sprawling, suburbanized industrial corridors of Georgia and the Carolinas -- places like Albany and Atlanta, Greenville and Spartanburg, Raleigh-Durham and Asheville. But they have been felt most sharply in the predominantly black, persistently poor coastal lowlands, where small and medium-sized factories began cropping up in old cotton, tobacco and peanut fields back in the 1950's to escape the unions and higher wages of the North.
Now, one weed at a time, nature is reclaiming many of those now-deserted industrial plants. Rural factories still employ fewer than half of all manufacturing workers in Georgia, North Carolina and South Carolina, federal labor statistics show. But in the 15 months that ended in March, factories in rural areas accounted for nearly 7 out of 10 manufacturing jobs lost in the three states.
The disparity was bluntest in South Carolina, where rural counties are home to only 47 percent of the manufacturing work force but absorbed 72 percent of the 29,400 jobs lost from December 2000 to March, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. In the production of durable goods -- things like electrical equipment, auto parts, appliances and countless widgets sold to factories further up the industrial food chain -- rural areas represented just 45 percent of the labor force, but accounted for 87 percent of the 12,200 jobs lost.
Jason Gray, policy director at the Southern Rural Development Initiative, a coalition of community groups based in Raleigh, said the latest recession had just accelerated the decline of an already weakened, if not dying, manufacturing base. "These counties have anemic economies," he said. "And when you're anemic, somebody else catches a cold and you get pneumonia.
"These were unhealthy places to begin with because they're undiversified economies that are relying on manufacturing sectors, which are not competitive in a global economy," he added. "All those textile jobs that have been lost in North and South Carolina? They all went somewhere else. They didn't just close, they closed and went to Guadalajara or Indonesia or China."
Many of the factories that have closed in Williamsburg County in recent years did produce textiles -- from the four Kingstree Knit plants that put 860 people out of work in 1995 and 1996, to the Tip Top Tees plant that stopped turning out T-shirts in December, idling 80 workers. But others included furniture, packaging and chemical plants.
Mr. Gray said many factories were simply reaching the end of their useful lives. Still other manufacturers that have come to the rural areas, perhaps hoping to take advantage of the local air of desperation by reaping local government incentives, often rest on shaky financial footings and thus are more vulnerable in a recession, he said.
Hilton McGill, Williamsburg County's economic development director, acknowledged the dilemma. "We realize these may not be the highest priority jobs or the most financially stable," he said. "But what we're trying to do now is put a tourniquet on a difficult situation."
So Mr. McGill dutifully prints glossy brochures promoting an ever-growing list of newly available -- i.e., abandoned -- industrial buildings. Pictures of his few big successes -- the Taiwanese plastics factory, the landfill-liner maker, the telemarketing operation -- hang on the wall of his office, which doubles as the terminal of the county airport. But the newer companies typically employ a small fraction as many workers as the ones they replace, he said.
"It's kind of like the gentleman who bought the Cadillac, but had to turn it off to fill it up with gas," Mr. McGill said. "We're bringing them in, but we're losing them out the back door."
Each loss only deepens the look of hopelessness in the eyes of people like Willie Tisdale, who worked for the old Colonial Rubber Works before its new owner shut it down last fall. "It used to irritate your skin, but was good work," he said. Mr. Tisdale hoed tobacco last summer season for $30 a day or less. Now that it is out of season he is living off his brother, a town maintenance man. "What we need is someone to open up a big plant," he said.
That is about as likely as manna falling from heaven, officials say. "Industrial developers are looking elsewhere," said Representative James E. Clyburn, the lone black congressman in South Carolina's six-person delegation, whose district includes many of the poorest and most heavily African-American counties. "So what trained, educated black people do is go where the jobs are." Wherever that is.
For those who stay, there are few choices. About 800 workers board county buses before dawn each morning for a two-hour ride to Myrtle Beach, where they flip burgers or clean hotel rooms for $6 or $7 an hour, returning home 12 or 14 hours later having earned perhaps $50 before taxes and the $5 fare.
At least there is still the Tupperware plant. Keith McFadden, 47, took a job there five years ago. He works full time. But he is still a temporary worker with no benefits. Waiting for a shuttle bus to take him to his night shift -- his old Mercury is not up to any kind of commute -- Mr. McFadden said he harbored little hope of getting a permanent job, but had no idea where else to look.
"I'm sticking with it because jobs are so hard to find," he said. "I'm between a rock and a hard place. For my age, and for the years I've been there, I don't want to give it up."

PERSON: Joel B. Leff 

HEADLINE: Joel B. Leff, 67, Co-Founder Of Investment Management Firm 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Joel B. Leff, a founder and co-chairman of the investment management firm Forstmann-Leff Associates, died at his Manhattan home on Tuesday. He was 67 years old and had suffered from cancer.
 Mr. Leff combined an eclectic approach to investing with an equally eclectic approach to collecting and selling antiques from the Oblique Gallery, which he owned on East 60th Street in Manhattan. 
 Since its founding in 1968, his investment firm, Forstmann-Leff, has grown to have more than $4 billion in assets under management and a client base that includes corporate and public pension funds as well as wealthy individuals.
At the same time, he filled his shop with an array of Art Deco and Far Eastern antiques and paintings that he and his fourth wife, Jeanne, acquired on their travels and later re-sold. He kept a computer at the gallery so he could continue with his financial transactions as he supervised the placement and sale of his antique finds.
He was also a William Cullen Bryant Fellow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, part of a group of major donors to the museum's American Wing.
The son of a successful businessman, Mr. Leff was born in New York City on April 4, 1935, and attended the Barnard School for Boys and graduated from the Wharton School's undergraduate program at the University of Pennsylvania in 1957. He graduated from Harvard Business School in 1961, where he wrote the Odd Man Out column for the business school newspaper. After graduating, he stayed on as a teacher in advanced economic theory at Harvard and was a member of its faculty.
Before starting his partnership with Anthony Forstmann, Mr. Leff managed investments for several families and became a partner and research director for Hawkes & Company, a Wall Street firm.
At the beginning of Forstmann-Leff, Mr. Leff attracted money from union pension funds and private individuals to his firm. Throughout his years, Mr. Leff focused on his institutional clients and continued to expand his firm's financial product line. At all times, he followed a growth strategy, whether it was in the firm's hedge funds, its various stock funds or as part of the firm's overall portfolio mix.
In 1986, a British firm, the Guiness Peat Group, bought Forstmann-Leff, but later went bankrupt. Mr. Leff negotiated to buy the firm back. In 1997, Forstmann-Leff was sold again, to the Refco Group, a commodities firm, with Mr. Leff and his management team remaining to operate it under a management contract.
As co-chairman, Mr. Leff's was a member of his firm's investment committee, developing the firm's strategy and writing a monthly newsletter to clients.
With a house in Southampton, N.Y., many years as a bachelor and a love of the opera, tennis and the arts, Mr. Leff was a popular person at Upper East Side dinner parties and social events in the Hamptons. In his single years, he said that he received as many as 15 dinner party invitations a week and developed the technique of extricating himself from late-night events with the excuse that he had to leave to walk his two King Charles spaniels, Edison and Smudgin. He attributed his popularity to being a bachelor and being wealthy.
After his 1999 wedding -- at the chapel in the Bellagio Hotel in Las Vegas -- he agreed to let his wedding video be auctioned for charity.
Mr. Leff is survived by his wife; his mother, Zena L. Leff of Palm Beach, Fla.; his son, Adam B. Leff of Los Angeles; and his brother, Richard Leff, who lives in New Hampshire.

HEADLINE: New Data on Unemployment Question Health of Labor Market 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9 

 BODY:
Worker claims for jobless benefits fell less than expected last week, and the number of Americans collecting aid rose to a 19-year high, government figures showed today, suggesting that the labor market is not improving rapidly as the economy recovers. 
 States received 411,000 new applications for unemployment benefits in the week ended Saturday, the Labor Department said. Though that figure was down 11,000 from the previous week, it was more than the 407,000 that economists had expected. About 3.8 million workers collected unemployment benefits in the week ended April 27, the most since April 1983 during a recovery from back-to-back recessions. 
 "The economy isn't growing fast enough at this time to absorb workers," said Chris Rupkey, senior financial economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York. "There are real questions about the health of the labor market right now. The way continuing claims continue to go up suggests economic weakness."
The unemployment rate, which rose to 6 percent in April, a seven-and-a-half-year high, may climb as high as 6.5 percent in coming months as companies are slow to hire, Mr. Rupkey said.
A labor market that shows few signs of improving helps explain why Federal Reserve policy makers this week left the overnight bank lending rate at a 40-year low of 1.75 percent, where it has been since December.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said job growth was vital because consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the economy. "Perhaps most central to the outlook for consumer spending will be developments in the labor market," he told Congress last month.
Retailers reported today that their April sales gain was the smallest since September. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 0.8 percent last month, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index.
At the same time, inflation remains tame. A separate government report showed import prices were 3.9 percent lower in April than a year ago. Not including petroleum, the costs of imported goods were down 3.3 percent from April 2001.

HEADLINE: Archdiocese's Crucial Fund Drive Turns to the Parishioners 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN 

 BODY:
He came to town with a reputation for a golden touch at raising money and for being a tough, cost-cutting administrator.
 Cardinal Edward M. Egan has done his part for this year's Cardinal's Appeal, bringing in a professional fund-raiser to run the campaign, imposing a tougher burden on his pastors to bring in donations and personally tapping wealthy Roman Catholics for more than $2 million. 
 But with only two weeks left in the appeal and nearly half the goal unmet, the Archdiocese of New York is now looking to make up the rest from the men and women in the pews, a place where anger at the Catholic hierarchy is running high over evidence that for decades bishops looked away while child-abusing priests were kept in parishes.
Whether they will come through is a big question for Cardinal Egan, who was seen as the best hope to rescue the archdiocese's sinking finances when he was appointed archbishop in 2000 but who has rarely been credited with having the pastoral touch of his predecessor, Cardinal John O'Connor. 
The archdiocese said that it had raised $8.2 million as of Wednesday in its annual fund-raising campaign, which has a goal of $15 million and ends May 26. The archdiocese says it is confident that a mail solicitation of modest givers starting in mid-April and appeals by pastors at Masses this month, the final phase of the campaign, will make up the difference. And officials point out that donations continue after the campaign formally ends. 
There are plenty of anecdotal indications that the scandal has dampened the enthusiasm of New York-area donors, but no clear evidence that Catholics in the archdiocese, which includes Manhattan, Staten Island, the Bronx and five counties to the north, are broadly punishing the church. 
"Are there some people who are angry?" asked Msgr. Charles M. Kavanagh, the archdiocese's vicar for development. "Yes. Are there people who are voting with their pocketbook? I'm sure there are." But, he said, he was satisfied with the results and expected that the goal would be met. The small-donor solicitation amounted to $8 million or $9 million in past years, he said.
But Cardinal Egan is facing pressure that his predecessor did not. Documents cited in news reports have suggested that the cardinal, while bishop of Bridgeport, knew that some priests had been accused of sexually abusing minors but allowed them to keep working in parishes and did not pass on information about them to law enforcement authorities.
New York City's other diocese, which covers Brooklyn and Queens, has not been immune to the trouble but officials say donations from a similar appeal have not dropped. Bishop Thomas V. Daily of Brooklyn has been criticized for failing to act while he was a top official of the Archdiocese of Boston in the early 1980's, and for allowing a priest accused of serious sex abuse to keep serving.
Despite reports about the bishop's role in Boston and reports of abuse in the Brooklyn diocese, pledges to its Annual Stewardship Appeal since Feb. 3 have reached about $5.9 million, well above the goal of slightly more than $4 million, said Frank DeRosa, a spokesman for the diocese. "We're on track to do as well as we did last year," he said.
In the New York Archdiocese, Michael Elmore, a 48-year-old librarian who attends St. Joseph's Church in Greenwich Village and has always contributed to the Cardinal's Appeal in the past, said he would give to Catholic Relief Services this year instead.
Referring to Cardinal Egan, he said, "His behavior has been reprehensible and I do not trust him, because of the way that he behaved when he was bishop of Bridgeport in covering up scandals."
The Rev. Walter F. Modrys of St. Ignatius Loyola Church on the Upper East Side, who has had a disagreement with the cardinal over renovation at his church, said he did not expect to reach his church's goal of $225,000. 
"There is a lot of feeling out there, negative feeling among Catholics, that's making it increasingly hard to raise money for the Cardinal's Appeal," he said. He also blamed a more troubled economy.
And at Holy Name of Mary Church in Croton-on-Hudson, where two pastors have been removed over allegations of sexual impropriety, the new pastor, the Rev. Michael Keane, said he expected his parish would barely raise half of its $66,000 goal. "It's hit home, twice in a row," he said. 
To respond to worries that donations may go toward settlements or legal fees to defend sex abuse allegations, officials in the New York Archdiocese have shaped their message. "There was a much greater emphasis on our clear-cut needs and where the money was going to go," Monsignor Kavanagh said.
The New York Archdiocese says all of the $15 million will go to Catholic schools and religious education programs, help for poor parishes, social services and pastoral outreach, St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers, and support for retired priests.
The appeal is critical to the operations of the archdiocese. Last year, Cardinal Egan reorganized the financing system. Before, parishes were assessed a lump sum, which included both general assessments on parish income and a goal for the Cardinal's Appeal. Parishes that reached the goal received a 25 percent rebate, and half of any excess. Now, parishes are assessed 7.5 percent of collections and given a goal for the appeal. There is no rebate, and the parish gets 60 percent of any excess. The effect, pastors say, is to increase the amount of money parishes are asked to raise.
Cardinal Egan brought in an outside fund-raiser, Community Counseling Service, last year to run a new kind of campaign for the Cardinal's Appeal. It focused on the biggest donors in the early months of the campaign, in February and March. Pastors, bishops and Cardinal Egan himself attended cocktail parties, large dinners and intimate meals.
By last Friday, the archdiocese had raised $5.8 million from donors who gave more than $1,000 each. Cardinal Egan was personally involved in appeals to a dozen who pledged more than $100,000 each, including one over $1 million, the monsignor said. None had given more than $50,000 before, he said.
Cardinal Egan, in closing schools and offices, has declared fiscal order to be one of his main goals. Monsignor Kavanagh said the deficit had dropped from about $20 million to about $9 million.
Cardinal Egan's predecessor came from a working-class background and was reluctant to ask for donations. One diocese official recalled a meeting at which Cardinal O'Connor told a donor he did not want his money, just his advice. "Can't you take both?" answered the incredulous donor.
Cardinal Egan, by contrast, moves easily in wealthy circles and feels no embarrassment in asking for money. While he was in Bridgeport, the diocese said, it reached or surpassed its appeal goal every year.

HEADLINE: Newark's Competing Visions of Itself; 
Reborn or Struggling? Each View Is Reflected by a Mayoral Candidate

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 9 

 BODY:
If this hard-luck city had a slogan it would be a single word: renaissance.
 The word has been adopted by scores of businesses here -- a hairdresser's, a candle shop, an apartment building -- and it invariably peppers the speeches of Mayor Sharpe James, the man who has spent 16 years selling the notion of Newark as a phoenix finally rising from the ashes of the 1967 riots that left this city a symbol of urban despair. 
 But Britney Ramsey, 19, has her doubts. Standing on Broad Street across from the shell of the unfinished Renaissance Mall, Ms. Ramsey said that after a lifetime of hearing about Newark's renaissance, she was still waiting for it. "What renaissance?" she said, nodding to the skeletal remains of the mall, left by a developer who ran out of money in the mid-1980's. "I live on one of the worst drug blocks in the city. Sometimes I hear gunfire at night. Yeah, I see improvements, but not enough to make me want to stay in Newark." 
Around the corner at the Renaissance Cafe, however, the manager, Anthony Cupo, sees an entirely different city. His view may be dominated by parking lots and the back end of the abandoned mall, but Mr. Cupo likens them to fallow but fertile fields awaiting a burst of new growth. "You can feel the excitement," said Mr. Cupo, referring to the recent spurt of downtown development and the even greater promise of a downtown arena, whose most recent version was proposed by Gov. James E. McGreevey on Wednesday.
"I see nothing but potential and opportunity," he said. 
When Newark residents go to the polls on Tuesday, they will be choosing between those contrasting views of Newark when they choose between the 66-year-old incumbent who has led this city for a generation and Cory Booker, a suburban-bred, Ivy League-educated newcomer half his age. The two strikingly different candidates are billing the election as a referendum on how real the renaissance has been. 
Mr. James is campaigning on his record of downtown development and bringing Newark back from an urban disaster to "America's comeback city." Mr. Booker's campaign slogan, "It's time for a renaissance for the rest of us," reflects his argument that Newark's comeback has been shallow, spotty and a benefit to only a few.
Both men can cite some convincing evidence. 
The downtown skyline, once ominously dark at night, is a brightly lighted collection of renovated office towers. Starbucks has even given the city its stamp of approval by opening its first store here, and several nights a week suburban concertgoers crowd a glittering performing-arts center and white-tablecloth restaurants that didn't exist five years ago. Even the tundralike stretches of the devastated Central Ward have flowered with middle-class housing and a multiplex theater.
Gone are crumbling high-rise projects that led to Newark's ranking as America's worst city for housing. Violent crime is down, the population numbers have stabilized, and optimism is on the rise. 
But much remains unchanged. The high school dropout rate has not moved below 40 percent since Mr. James won office in 1986. Unemployment is little changed and at 9.2 percent is nearly double the state average. A third of the city's 274,000 residents still live in poverty, and despite a gain of 4,300 housing units between 1992 and 2000, the home ownership rate actually fell by 3 percent during the same period. Newark still ranks among the worst cities in the nation for AIDS, lead paint poisoning and tuberculosis.
Given the mixed picture, few urban experts buy the notion that Newark has completed its rise from decades of poverty and neglect.
"There are discrete pieces of progress, but a new performing arts center does not make for a renaissance," said Stephen Goldsmith, a former mayor of Indianapolis who teaches public management at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
Others say that it would be a mistake to minimize Newark's progress and how far it has come. The last census showed that Newark's population, after declining precipitously for decades, was stable between 1990 and 2000. The city has also become more ethnically diverse in recent years. Newark's population is now about half black, almost a third Hispanic and just over a quarter white. 
"Considering its massive problems, what's most impressive is the fact that people are no longer walking away from Newark," said Thomas Bender, who teaches urban history at New York University. "They're reaffirming that the city is worth saving, that it is no longer viewed as a trap, but a place of opportunity, a place where people's lives are improved."
Even residents of the same block have conflicting perspectives. 
Take Barbara Williams and Leon Johnson, two longtime residents who look at their West Ward block and see two entirely different worlds. Mr. Johnson, a 43-year-old drug counselor, sees hope in the vinyl-sided homes that began arriving on South 18th Street last year. "We used to call this block Vietnam," said Mr. Johnson, who recalls looting supermarkets as a 9-year-old. "I used to wake up to gunfire, and you didn't walk around here unless you knew how to fight." Mr. Johnson has no doubts about the changes. "The renaissance is real," he said.
To Ms. Williams, 57, the new homes are shoddy replacements for the wood-frame beauties that once lined her block, and they cannot hide the depressing ruins of adjacent homes that await demolition. She cannot forget the vanished neighbors, a racially mixed assortment of middle-class strivers, or the century-old shade trees that, one by one, succumbed to neglect.
"The city used to take care of the trees, and the street cleaners used to come by twice a week," she said, standing in front of her weathered but well-kept home. "I can't remember the last time I saw one come down here." 
At night, the drug dealers stake out positions along the block, and when Ms. Williams returns from her job working with disabled adults, she has her brother escort her inside. "It was such a beautiful street," said Ms. Williams, a South Carolina native who arrived here as a teenager. "Now I'm afraid to go out at night." As for the renaissance, she said she was still waiting for its arrival on South Orange Avenue, the West Ward commercial spine that remains a landscape of liquor stores, storefront churches and vacant lots. "We're stuck in the dark ages," she said.
Even the celebrated resurgence downtown has its detractors. Many residents resent the heavy police presence they say is desperately needed in the wards. New jobs, they complain, often go to better-skilled suburbanites, and many say they cannot afford tickets to performances at the arts center or baseball games at Riverfront Stadium, home of the Newark Bears. Mr. James cites the stadium as one of his greatest achievements; Mr. Booker likes to point out the $34 million it cost to build, money he says could be better spent on youth recreation programs. 
Msgr. William Linder, founder of the New Community Corporation and the city's most accomplished nonprofit developer, has become one of the most prominent critics of the city's focus on downtown. Monsignor Linder, who arrived here when the Central Ward was still smoldering from the fires of 1967 and 1,000 businesses lay in ruins, has created an empire that houses 8,500 people and employs 2,300. The public money spent on the arts center, he said, would have gone a long way toward repairing the city's tattered neighborhoods. "So far I haven't seen much spinoff value," he said. "We could have built a lot of homes with $180 million."
Of course, for every naysayer, there is a bubbly optimist. The city's real estate leaders are reveling in a boom unimaginable a few years ago. Financial giants like Morgan Stanley, Citigroup and Lehman Brothers have begun sinking money into downtown portfolios, and small-time home builders are snapping up lots in even the city's most foreboding streets.
"We can't put houses up fast enough," said Manuel Rosa, a broker and builder who can sell homes for $195,000 in marginal neighborhoods and $525,000 in the thriving East Ward, the heavily Portuguese and Brazilian enclave better known as the Ironbound. "It's an amazing story. I'm even amazed by it myself."
Miles Berger, a veteran developer, can recall a time when city real estate auctions drew one or two people. "If the minimum bid was $20,000, you got it for $20,000," he said. The auctions now are held in the 700-seat ballroom of the hotel he owns, and the crowds often spill out the door.
Community leaders say buyers are paying high prices for houses in neighborhoods coping with drugs, gang violence and ailing schools.
"You get a big new house, but you're not getting the amenities of a healthy community," said Monsignor Linder. 
Still, new homeowners like Daniel and Ogo Nwosu are believers. Nigerian immigrants who currently rent in Irvington, a nearby town, the Nwosus stood in front of their nearly completed home in the South Ward last week, talking breathlessly about plans for their generous backyard, their suburban-sized family room and the future of their adopted city. Never mind that nearby Clinton Avenue, the neighborhood's once vital shopping hub, is a menacing shadow of its former self. "People say the neighborhood is bad, that Newark is bad," said Mr. Nwosu, an electronics salesman at P. C. Richards who came to this country three years ago. "But if you read a lot, you know it's going to change." 
His builder, Many Goncalves, nodded enthusiastically. Mr. Goncalves, who has 36 homes under construction, said he was having trouble finding additional lots in the neighborhood. "This is the future over here," he said, showing off the oak flooring and brick-faced balconies with a view of Manhattan. To drive home his point, he gestured to a mirror-image house on a neighboring lot that is selling for $310,000. Mr. Nwosu, who paid $295,000 for his, couldn't help beaming. "You see," he said. "You have to have foresight. This here is really the American dream."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: COMMERCE; 
An Anti-American Boycott Is Growing in the Arab World

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: CAIRO, May 9 

 BODY:
Doughnuts may not be quite as American as, say, apple pie, but they come close enough to make Samir Nasier, a Saudi fast-food king, nervous. 
 So nervous, in fact, that Mr. Nasier and his brothers are offering roughly $300,000 to anyone who can prove that their House of Donuts chain has any connection to the United States. 
 For good measure, their slogan "the American pastry" is being jettisoned, with Mr. Nasier musing aloud that doughnuts might qualify as traditional Saudi fare, given that he started making them 21 years ago. 
"We share the same outraged feelings of the Saudi public toward the attitude of the American administration," Mr. Nasier said, speaking by telephone from the Jidda headquarters of his 180-outlet chain. "We are deleting anything that relates to America." 
American support for Israel, especially during its recent military offensive in the occupied territories, is driving a grass-roots effort to boycott American products throughout the Arab world. With word spread via the Internet, mosque sermons, fliers and even mobile phone messages, the boycott seems to be slowly gathering force, especially against consumer products.
Purchases of American goods generated by 300 million Arabs form such a small part of American exports that even a widespread boycott would not cause much of a blip. Most trade consists of big ticket items like airplanes, with total American exports to the Middle East amounting to $20 billion in 2000, just 2.5 percent of America's total exports.
But a long boycott could retard the spread of franchises and other products, experts say. Sales at most American fast-food outlets in the Arab world are already off somewhere between 20 and 30 percent on average, American diplomats and industry analysts say, and consumer products face a similar decline. 
The boycotts have largely been the effort of individuals and small groups without government involvement, like student organizations and such civic organizations as are allowed to exist. They reflect a growing sentiment that Arabs should distance themselves from the United States, and they want their governments to do likewise. 
"They are beginning to feel that shouting slogans in reaction to what the U.S. is doing is not enough," said Kamal Hamdan, a Lebanese economist. A Marlboro smoker, he said that whenever he pulls out a packet, somebody invariably now reproaches him with, "What, still smoking American cigarettes?" 
He went on: "They want to design detailed programs against specific goods and services that might involve the banking system, insurance, financial markets. They want to find some pressure points that can have an economic impact." 
The attitude is everywhere. Scores of lists circulate suggesting non-American substitutes for things like Lays potato chips and Head & Shoulders shampoo. The research does not always seem that rigorous; Domino's Pizza was listed as non-American on one list apparently on the strength of sounding Italian. 
Al Montazah, a supermarket chain in Bahrain, enforced the boycott on all its roughly 10,000 daily customers by replacing some 1,000 American products with alternatives. A few parents lacking Pampers diapers grumbled, but Abdulmonem al-Meer, the general manager, said the move had boosted sales at some stores. 
"I know it will not do much in terms of putting pressure on the American government, but whatever I can do I should do," Mr. Meer said. 
The boycott calls have thus far prompted little violence toward American companies, although an empty Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet in the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli was bombed overnight Thursday. 
Even places like Syria, where American products have long been barred, are trying to get into the act. Billboards around Damascus show horrific scenes of Israeli troops razing Jenin refugee camp, with the slogan, "Boycott American products -- Don't be an accomplice," in Arabic and English. 
"No Americans Allowed," reads a yardlong wooden sign in the window of Mondo restaurant, incongruously an American-style diner decorated with icons like the Statue of Liberty. "The American people should feel that they have a problem," said Ahmed Diab, the 38-year-old owner. 
The Arabs established a boycott office in Damascus in 1951 against companies that did business with Israel, and that kept products like Coca-Cola and Ford vehicles out of the Middle East for decades. But it gradually faded as major markets like Egypt signed a peace treaty with Israel. 
Boycott support in the region's government-run newspapers has been almost universal, although outright endorsements by senior officials have been rare, given that it could hurt foreign investment. The Syrian government is among the few encouraging the boycott. 
More typical is a speech by Sheika Fatima al-Nahyan, the wife of the ruler of Ajman in the United Arab Emirates, telling a women's group, "Start by boycotting all makeup and clothes made by the enemies and prevent children from buying their products, too."
The idea has gained the whole-hearted support of many religious figures, with myriad Friday prayer sermons devoted to the issue. Worshipers at one Jidda mosque were so fired up when they emerged that they converged on a hapless grocer next door to demand that he tear down a Coke sign. He demurred. 
Sheik Yusuf al-Qaradawi, the influential Muslim cleric on Al Jazeera satellite network, displays a blinking banner on his Web site that reads, "Boycott America from Pepsi cans to Boeing." 
Indeed, the flood of e-mail and Web sites sets this effort apart from all previous ones. Calls for boycotting three American corporations -- McDonald's, Starbucks and Microsoft -- gained rapid momentum through the Internet. 
In the case of McDonald's, the rumor erupted that it donated a part of every meal's cost to Israel. Local franchises from Morocco to the Persian Gulf issued statements denying it, stressing that they were locally owned and operated. The Lebanese McDonald's even paid for an instant message to be flashed on 60,000 cellphones, but in some cases the damage had been done. 
After a McDonald's opened a year ago at the end of her street in Taif, Saudi Arabia, Lama Muhammad's 5-year-old daughter insisted on one Happy Meal a day. But recently she started watching the news with her mother. "I told her we are not supposed to buy from there because they support Israel," her mother said. The child has not asked for a Happy Meal since. Saudi parents report that their children vie in the schoolyard to list all the American things they avoid. 
In the case of Microsoft and Starbucks, word bombarded across the Internet after the Israeli Microsoft branch sponsored a billboard supporting the Israeli Army, as did remarks reportedly made by Howard Schultz, chairman of Starbucks, at his Seattle synagogue. 
A local news article forwarded endlessly quoted him as saying that Jews needed to confront rising anti-Semitism worldwide and that the Palestinians needed to do more to fight terrorism. The remarks about the Palestinians prompted the boycott call, even though the company issued two statements saying Mr. Schultz did not believe terrorism was representative of the Palestinian people and that he thought Israeli and Palestinian states should live together peacefully. 
"Everybody is addicted to Starbucks -- it's the hip place," said Kholood Khatami, a 25-year-old Saudi journalist. "It's not empty, but it is not as crowded as it used to be. I'm boycotting. Of course, there are some things you cannot avoid -- technology and software is all American." 
Many companies, especially fast-food restaurants, are fighting back with huge advertising campaigns saying the boycott will only hurt locals. Burger King, in a typical advertisement this week in Saudi Arabia, pointed out that it bought everything from bread to lettuce to mayonnaise from Saudi producers.
Others with American products like Kellogg's breakfast cereal or Hershey's chocolate are hoping that the United States will change its Middle East policy fast enough for old consumer habits to return. 
"Our sales are suffering, but I am not concerned about the loss of sales," said Sheik Wahib S. Binzagr, the patriarch of a Jidda merchant family that has imported a wide variety of American goods for decades. He was nonplused to find the clan's own name on the boycott list. 
"I laugh from desperation because I cannot do anything about it," he said. "There is damage, and I think efforts should be mobilized to rectify the bad relationship, and then the other things will correct themselves."

HEADLINE: Fed Releases March 19 Minutes 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9 

 BODY:
Federal Reserve officials saw "strong evidence" that the economy was recovering from recession at their March 19 policy meeting and sent a signal to investors that interest rates would have to rise at some point, minutes of the meeting showed today.
 The rebound in growth allowed members of the policy-making Federal Open Market Committee to shift their assessment of risks to the economy to neutral, from concern about weakness, even as they left the federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks at a 40-year low of 1.75 percent. 
 "Members commented that the decidedly positive information received over the inter-meeting period provided strong evidence that an economic recovery was under way," the minutes show. "Economic activity was expanding briskly in the early months of the year after having turned up and increased modestly in the fourth quarter."
In a statement released after the March 19 meeting, members of the committee said monetary policy was "currently accommodative." According to the minutes, that phrase was a deliberate signal to financial markets. "A reference to the committee's currently accommodative policy stance in the press announcement to be issued shortly after this meeting would alert the public to the need to firm policy at some point in the future," the minutes show.
According to the minutes, as the members "gained confidence that the recovery was becoming better entrenched," interest rates would have to rise "to provide less stimulus" to the economy.
F.O.M.C. members said the "neutral" stance they were taking "did not preclude" a move to higher interest rates should it seem warranted by evolving conditions.

HEADLINE: Reimagining A Downtown 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
For urban planners and elected officials, the destruction of the World Trade Center has provided an almost unfathomable opportunity to reconsider and reshape the future of one of the most distinctive neighborhoods in the world: 16 acres of land in the heart of downtown Manhattan.
 And with the site virtually cleared, some officials are speaking of bold strokes and grand opportunities in describing a vision for a new downtown, a sweep of land that, from this ambitious perspective, starts at Chambers Street and extends south to the tip of Manhattan Island and from river to river. 
 "We're going to make Lower Manhattan a far stronger and better community in every sense than it was on the morning of Sept. 11," Gov. George E. Pataki said in an interview. Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, said the events of Sept. 11 "took the lid off downtown's potential." 
Still, for all this language of transformation and opportunity, the contours of a reconfigured downtown that are emerging, as described in conversations with political and civic leaders over the past two weeks, are notable more for their caution and adherence to tradition than for any attempt at innovation or experiment.
For better or for worse, there is no talk, for example, of using the hand of government to push the frontier of conventional urban planning, or to distinguish downtown with a pioneering if unconventional work of architecture. Instead, the emerging consensus would permit Lower Manhattan to continue along the tracks of transition that it was following well before the attack.
Many decisions remain to be worked out, including the precise mix and density of residential development and offices. But the overall vision, as described by everyone from community leaders to planners to Mr. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, is of Lower Manhattan as a neighborhood of office buildings, to reclaim corporations that fled the area; apartments and converted lofts, to accommodate a growing residential population; and stores and restaurants, to ensure a lively neighborhood presence after dark. 
The most distinctive element in the mix would be the memorial erected to the victims of the attack, and consequently the way the neighborhood adjusts in its transformation to, inevitably, one of the most visited historical sites in the nation.
It is a matter of debate whether this conservatism is a good thing or not, whether a city that has been so traumatized would want to embark on any kind of experiment in urban planning at this of all places, and at this of all times.
There are, on one hand, some people who suggest that if this really is an opportunity -- the cleared plot of land surrounded by downtown skyscrapers is twice the size of Bryant Park -- it may someday be remembered as a missed one. 
But the extent to which there is already agreement about the broad picture is striking. And while there are surely some political considerations at play -- Mr. Pataki is not particularly eager for a fight over this site in the midst of his re-election campaign -- it seems clear that the most powerful force here is the common judgment of elected officials, community leaders and planners that this is the ideal and natural way to develop the tip of Manhattan.
"You shouldn't be surprised that there is a broad consensus," Mr. Bloomberg said in an interview yesterday. "All the city planners have been saying the same thing. And it makes sense."
Louis R. Tomson, president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said that when he attended a meeting of the local community board in January, "there was a great uniformity of outlook, even then."
"There is a common feeling of all the people down here," he said, "that after all the years that this was talked about as a vibrant 24-hour community, and a lot of people came down here seeking that, that it really was not."
In fact, many city planners suggested that the tragedy of last fall had in many ways eased the transformation that urban planners had foreseen for decades. Given its sheer bulk and windswept isolation, the trade center had long been viewed as an obstacle to the kind of downtown that planners had been envisioning for more than 10 years.
"It may be blasphemous to say, but the World Trade Center was an anachronism both in scale and the architecture it represented," said Meyer S. Frucher, former president of the Battery Park City Authority.
It is notable that one of the first decisions about how to prepare the area for development was one to rectify what many people saw as an unfortunate byproduct of constructing the towers: the elimination of the street grid. And two other critical moves that are now being examined -- burying West Street, and bringing commuter rail lines from either Long Island or Westchester into the financial district -- have gone from being far-fetched planning exercises of the 1990's to realistic possibilities.
"The issues that we focused on in '92 are very much the issues that we are focusing on today," said Richard L. Schaffer, who was chairman of the City Planning Commission when it issued a plan for developing Lower Manhattan in 1992. "When we looked at it in 1992, we saw that the transportation issues, the broader infrastructure issues, were critical."
"Obviously, you weren't going to get the grid driven through the World Trade Center while it existed," Mr. Schaffer continued. "Some of these things were just prohibited by cost. But now, you have a cleared site."
Immediately after the attack, some spoke about simply rebuilding what had been destroyed, and of protecting the continued existence of New York's financial district. But in truth, it has been a long time since the financial district could rightfully claim to be the financial district of New York. Businesses had been settling in Midtown since the opening of Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station, to accommodate commuters from the suburbs.
"A cynic would say, 'What are you talking about, rebuilding?' " said Mr. Bloomberg, whose own corporate headquarters is at Park Avenue and 59th Street. "It wasn't really there before."
And if Lower Manhattan was losing its distinction as the city's financial district before the attack, the number of people who were making Lower Manhattan a place to live had been rising. In 1970, it was home to a mere 833 people; as of September, its population was 25,000. The residential population in Lower Manhattan jumped 60 percent over the past six years alone.
If there are disagreements in the future -- and surely, there will be some -- they will be on the margins: the precise balance between office and residential development.
Even here, though, there is general agreement between what might seem to be potential adversaries.
"I don't think we should look at just replacement of commercial space," said Madelyn G. Wils, the chairwoman of Community Board 1. "I think we should absolutely look at more residential."
Charles A. Gargano, vice chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and New York's top economic development official, said that while he expected that the vast majority of the buildings on the site itself would be office space, there would be nowhere near the number of square feet there was before.
Similarly, government leaders are talking about the mix of businesses in a reconfigured downtown New York. Gifford Miller, the speaker of the City Council, said, "Part of the city's fiscal problems is that we're run so cyclically on the basis of the financial sector, and we ought to be making a commitment to new types of industries, so we have a broader base and a more stable overall economic structure."
For many planners, these are relatively minor concerns, which will be resolved less by the city than by the marketplace. For them, the real question is what, if anything, New York might or should do to shape its future. "This is the kind of thing that happened in Chicago in the 1870's when the fire burned it down: It gives you a chance to think afresh," said John H. Mollenkopf, director of the City University of New York's Center for Urban Research.
The question, though, is whether anyone in this still very shaken city is ready to seize the opportunity.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Current plans for the area south of Chambers Street, where the World Trade Center stood, draw on its past and long-held ideas of what it should be. (Richard Perry/The New York Times)(pg. B6)
