HEADLINE: Decline and Fall 

BYLINE:  By John B. Judis; John B. Judis is a senior editor of The New Republic and the co-author, with Ruy Teixeira, of "The Emerging Democratic Majority," to be published this summer.

 BODY:
 WEALTH AND DEMOCRACY
A Political History
of the American Rich.
By Kevin Phillips.
473 pp. New York:
Broadway Books. $29.95.
 WHEN future historians want to understand the politics of the last half of the 20th century, they will treasure Kevin Phillips's books, particularly "The Emerging Republican Majority" and "Post-Conservative America." Phillips's latest book, "Wealth and Democracy," has its moments, principally as a jeremiad against the financial excesses of the late 1990's, but it lacks the force and clarity of his earlier works. It is annoyingly repetitious and contains what seems like needless detail about things like how many millionaires lived in Philadelphia in 1845. And to the extent that it has a central premise, the premise is not one that commands assent.
As he has done before, Phillips argues that America is the latest victim of the cyclical rise and fall of great imperial powers -- from Greece and Rome through Britain and the United States. He portrays the United States "against the warning backdrop and decline symptoms of its three predecessors -- Britain, Holland, and Hapsburg Spain." This view of history, which was popular among the nation's founders, was revived in the late 1980's by Phillips and the historian Paul Kennedy. (I also did my bit in "Grand Illusion: Critics and Champions of the American Century.") The idea fell into disfavor during the boom of the 1990's, but Phillips insists that what many Americans took for symptoms of a new economy were further signs that the United States is about to suffer the same dismal fate as its imperial predecessors.
Phillips focuses on the similarities between the United States now and the 17th-century Netherlands and early-20th-century Britain. Among other things, he cites "financialization," a preoccupation with success in "finance, technology and services" and the neglect of "basic manufacturing," speculation and the recurrence of bubbles and manias (from Dutch tulips to America's dot-coms), the export of capital and jobs, the reliance on foreigners to fill domestic jobs, growing inequality of wealth and income and the "exposure . . . to war." The trouble is that similar symptoms don't necessarily reflect similarity in causes and conditions: the fact that the British had to enlist "foreigners to aid or run chemical and electrical industries" may have been a sign of their imminent decline, but the influx of skilled Asian workers, many of whom have become American citizens, into Silicon Valley during the 1990's has contributed to the United States' economic vitality.
If you look at the actual causes of decline in the Netherlands and Britain, they do not seem present in the United States today. The Netherlands was felled by European tariffs against its textiles, British discrimination against its ships and its vulnerability to military attack from its neighbors. Britain declined in the early 20th century because it lagged behind the United States and Germany in making the transition from owner-operated manufacturing companies to large-scale corporate capitalism. In the late 1980's, it did seem that the United States would suffer a similar fate at the hands of Japan and West Germany, but just as they began to catch up in basic manufacturing, the locus of growth and innovation changed from industrial to postindustrial capitalism -- from hardware to software (much of which is misleadingly labeled services). The United States was better suited for this new phase of capitalism, and has once again pulled ahead of its rivals.
Phillips could have benefited from a quick glance at the statistics. He writes that "the United States of 2000 was roughly as distant from its post-1945 peak share of world production as the Britain of 1910-14 had been from her own." The facts are these. In 1950, when Europe and Japan had still not recovered from World War II, the United States accounted for 27 percent of the world's output; 50 years later, with Europe and Japan fully recovered, the United States accounted for 23 percent of the world's output, with America's gross domestic product almost double that of Germany and Japan combined. By comparison, Britain in 1914 accounted for only 8.3 percent of the world's G.D.P., with its total already less than half that of the United States. The United States is obviously not without problems -- most notably, the growing economic inequality that Phillips cites -- but its flaws cannot plausibly be attributed to a dynamic of imperial decline.
In the book's last chapters, Phillips introduces a different cycle of history. With a nod to Will and Ariel Durant and Arthur Schlesinger, he suggests that the United States has alternated between periods of "wealth laudation" and "democracy." For the last two decades it has been in the throes of the former and could move still farther toward establishing "plutocracy by some other name." But it could also undergo a Schlesingerian reaction against plutocracy.
The reaction, Phillips says, could take one of two forms, "progressive" or "radical." The progressive reaction would consist of a mobilization like that of Theodore Roosevelt "against corruption, polarization and market Darwinism," reviving America and prolonging its ascendancy atop the pyramid of nations. The radical reaction would reflect American decline, recalling the politics of the Dutch Patriot Revolt of the late 18th century or the situation of the British Labor Party after World War II. Dreams of international pre-eminence would be abandoned; "economic nationalism" would be stressed. Among other things, America would impose "import duties to recapture the U.S. internal market for domestic producers and workers."
Like Phillips's schema of imperial decline, this theory of cycles doesn't entirely fit the facts, especially the facts of the politics of the last decade. Phillips, for instance, puts Theodore Roosevelt's administration squarely in the camp of democracy and progressivism and the Clinton administration in the camp of plutocracy and conservatism. But in fact the two administrations were similar both in what they attempted and what they accomplished.
Phillips sees the T.R. years as countering "Gilded Age wealth and income trends." He asserts that "farmers and workers seem to have gained ground between 1900 and 1914." Statistics from the turn of the last century are hard to come by, but one estimate -- cited in George W. Mowry's "Era of Theodore Roosevelt" and echoed by other historians -- is that the average real wages of urban workers was lower from 1900 to 1912 than from 1890 to 1900. Corporate consolidation and the destruction of the older craft industries also proceeded apace during the T.R. years. That doesn't mean T.R. wasn't a progressive reformer, only that he was frustrated by underlying economic trends as well as by political opposition.
Very similar conclusions can be drawn about the Clinton years. Phillips says that "the top percentiles became richer than ever while the lower portions of the society lost ground." The first part of this statement is correct, but the second isn't. During Clinton's second term, real wages finally began to rise, the result of low unemployment and of Clinton's earned income tax credit. Clinton was certainly not in T.R.'s class as a reformer, but he was by no means a friend of plutocracy. His administration was much more a reaction to than a continuation of Reagan's conservative policies.
Phillips's division of American politics among plutocrats, progressives and radicals is not altogether mistaken. It's just that the tripartition has been going on since at least 1992 and has been central to every subsequent presidential election. The two Bushes and Bob Dole represented, with appropriate reservations, the party of business and the market; Clinton and Gore were, for better or worse, representatives of a new T.R.-style progressivism; and Pat Buchanan and Ross Perot (and to some extent Ralph Nader) represented an angry economic nationalism. The terrorist attack of 9/11 has postponed the final resolution, but it will probably occur before the decade is over. Phillips deserves credit for laying out the alternatives, but his analysis is clouded by simplistic models of cyclical change.

HEADLINE: SUMMER MOVIES; 
What Ever Happened to Fun in the Sand?

BYLINE:  By STUART KLAWANS 

 BODY:
A PIANO booms and tinkles, deep in the shadows of Hollywood's collective memory. Sometimes the keys are out of tune; sometimes a paper roll makes them thump mechanically. But the song is forever the same: "By the sea, by the sea, by the beautiful sea."
 On a screen that need be no grander than a bedsheet, young women flicker into view, dressed for the beach. They are Mack Sennett's Bathing Beauties. It is not clear why they have chosen to go swimming together, how the laws of physics have brought them into alignment or whether they will avoid, for long, the gentle attention of Mack Sennett's Keystone Kops. No matter. The Bathing Beauties inhabit early American cinema with a monarchical self-assurance. Vast tracts of the medium belong to them. 
 Were we to probe the nearer regions of Hollywood's memory, we would confirm the legitimacy of the Bathing Beauties' reign. When audiences take their seats in a near-black, windowless room, they love to watch actors frolic on the beach. Think of Burt and Deborah in "From Here to Eternity," Elvis and anybody in "Blue Hawaii," Annette and Frankie in anything. Hollywood means fun in the sand.
Or rather, it used to. In contemporary Hollywood, the beach has turned into a site of isolation, anxiety and horror. I do not think it coincidence that this change dates from 1975. With "Jaws," the movie industry entered the blockbuster era, and the Bathing Beauties ran screaming from the water, chased from their domain by a razor-mouthed killing machine.
If you scan the Variety list of all-time top-grossing movies, you will see that it is composed almost entirely of pictures released after "Jaws." We live in a period of fantastically lucrative films, which sail triumphantly into theaters, one after the other, on a flood of venture capital and marketing dollars. These films consistently evoke a dread of water.
Here, for example, is "Cast Away": No. 26 on the Variety list, with a domestic box-office of $233 million. The beach, in this picture, is a place where you get skinnier and crazier, with nobody to befriend you except for a single airhead. It's a situation strikingly reminiscent of the coked-out early blockbuster-era Hollywood that the late Julia Phillips described in her memoirs.
Turn to Variety's No. 32 movie, with its $216 million gross, and the terror intensifies. Colors turn to mud; fragments of flesh, bone and blood spray everywhere. We are in "Saving Private Ryan," where a day at the beach is an eternity of violent death. On what emotional reserves did Steven Spielberg draw when he mounted his indelible re-creation of D-Day? Maybe he was showing us how it felt to launch the campaign for a failed blockbuster -- for example, his own "1941."
The terminology of financial failure may suggest why moviemakers envision the swirling of water whenever they sink huge resources into a make-or-break project. Producers risk taking a bath, getting washed up, going down the drain (or its ruder equivalent). Think of an outsize, insanely expensive movie, which conceivably could have foundered like an outsize, insanely expensive vessel, and you will have the name of the No. 1 picture on the Variety list: "Titanic." As it happened, James Cameron's film floated; the reported domestic gross was $600 million. But no one could have guaranteed this success. The rich investment might have plunged, like Kate Winslet's jewel, into the depths -- or, to cite a costly misadventure of Cameron's, into "The Abyss."
The fortunes of Ms. Winslet's co-star may underscore the danger. When Leonardo DiCaprio returned to the screen after "Titanic," he ventured onto "The Beach," where he suffered terribly at the hands of armed thugs, and also reviewers.
No further examples should be needed (though I can't resist citing No. 39 on Variety's list, "Pearl Harbor," with its domestic take of $198 million). Still, there may be more than economics behind modern Hollywood's fear of the beach. I turn for guidance to someone who works in the industry and knows well the ways of horror: Stuart Gordon, director of "Re-Animator." Mr. Gordon confesses that he, too, finds water scary, though for practical reasons. He shot much of his recent horror movie, "Dagon," in and around the water, and he found that "it kills you."
"Steven Spielberg learned that with 'Jaws,' and Kevin Costner learned it with 'Waterworld,' " Mr. Gordon says. "It's complicated and expensive to make a movie with water. If one of your electrical cables falls in, everybody's fried."
What about the beach?
Mr. Gordon points to a segment from the recent HBO series "Project Greenlight," which tracked a first-time writer and director during the making of his film, "Stolen Summer." "The filmmakers are shooting on the beach in Chicago, and it looks like the most hellish experience ever. The actors can't swim, the water's freezing because it's April, the sand gets in everything and everybody. It's a nightmare. I mean, what about 'On the Beach'? That's the ultimate horror movie."
Is there no hope, then, of Hollywood's returning to the simple pleasures? Other national cinemas still know how to romp on the sand. Look at France, and "Pauline on the Beach." Look at Tunisia, for that matter, and "A Summer in La Goulette." Are Annette and Frankie gone forever?
"There's 'Baywatch,' " Mr. Gordon says. "That's all about the beach. MTV has a beach show where the kids hold wet T-shirt contests, and there's a bit of the beach in 'Dawson's Creek.' "
So even now audiences may sit indoors and enjoy fun in the sun. They just have to do it through the cheaper, quicker medium of television. That's where they can find present-day counterparts to the cheap, quick Bathing Beauties movies.
With thanks to Mr. Gordon, I return to economics as my explanation, and so look more deeply into Variety's list. I have to drop down to No. 159 before I find a film where people at least try to enjoy themselves in the water: "On Golden Pond." Suddenly, I feel old -- not as old as Henry Fonda and Katharine Hepburn, but creaky enough. Have beach movies disappeared because the investors are paunchy baby boomers? Is that what they really fear -- having to admit that they slacked off in their workouts and can't match Jane Fonda's way with a swimsuit?
Hypocrite reader! My look-alike! My brother! You want to escape this glare of self-knowledge and flee into the pleasures of the dark. But now the summer season is upon us, with its latest flotilla of blockbusters. Just when you thought it was safe to go back into the movies.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Final Grade for the Future

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WHITE; Richard White, Ph.D., is director of Career Services at Rutgers University in New Brunswick.

 BODY:
LAST May, when more than a million college seniors were donning their caps and gowns, I was asked by a reporter how I would grade the entry-level college job market. "B plus," I replied, "down from a solid A in 2000." The news -- not only economic, but also political and cultural -- has not been very good since then. 
 Members of the class of 2002, who entered college in September 1998 during a booming economy and with the world generally at peace, are graduating into a jittery reality. Their senior year was defined by 9/11, the anthrax scare (especially in New Jersey), declining job prospects and budget cuts at many schools around the country, all contributing to students' feelings of anxiety, procrastination, fatalism and even fear. The grade for this year's job prospects for graduating seniors? No better than a C. 
 The news is not all bad. Some Rutgers students have conducted successful job search campaigns and landed good, solid jobs. They were the early birds who used on-campus resources and personal networking to generate leads, interviews and offers. On the other hand, many other students, who two years ago would have produced a couple of offers, faced the stark reality of a 40 percent decline in online job postings and campus interviews -- 40 percent fewer opportunities to be noticed, interviewed and hired. Of course, this does not translate into a 40 percent unemployment rate or a 40 percent decline in actual jobs, but it does significantly increase the time and effort that students must commit to their job searches.
Meanwhile, the economic numbers coming out of Washington tell a different story. The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, has essentially declared the recession over. The New Jersey Department of Labor also presents a fairly rosy scenario. For example, in the last quarter of 2001, while the nation lost 933,000 jobs, New Jersey actually had a net gain of 9,000. For the past 25 months, New Jersey's unemployment rate has been lower than the nation's. Currently, the state's rate is hovering around 5.5 percent.
So why do things feel so uncertain on college campuses in New Jersey and the rest of the country? For one thing, there is the lag between increased economic activity and hiring. But the deeper and more troubling issue is an underlying wariness to hire on the part of many employers.
Maybe life has returned to some semblance of normalcy -- the "new normal," as some commentators have put it -- but look around our towns, cities, campuses, schools, Little League baseball fields and especially in newspaper and television news reports, and there is a very uneasy feeling about the state of our nation and the world. Maybe some of those same uncomfortable feelings that have pervaded college campuses since Sept. 11 are more pronounced on Main Street and Wall Street than we actually realize.
We are an optimistic people by nature, forward-looking, flexible and willing to change. As a nation, we live by the business principle of "continuous improvement." Yes, the job outlook will get better, probably by the fall. While the current economic picture does not translate into lots of good job prospects for the class of 2002, graduates will survive and eventually thrive. As we tell our students at Rutgers, who will graduate May 23, it takes a lot of work to get work, especially in this job market.
Our good old-fashioned advice is more relevant than ever -- prepare a strong one-page resume; do lots of networking with friends, neighbors, local merchants and college alumni; start the process early; and use a multifaceted approach to finding a job, including career fairs, the Internet, on-campus interviewing and volunteer work.
And what about prospects for the class of 2003? My hope for these graduates is twofold: a B for the job market that they will enter a year from now and a senior year free from the tragic events and unsettled feelings that have seared this year into our memory forever.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1847 words

HEADLINE: They're Thinking of a Number . . . 

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA GROARK 

 BODY:
THE plan was hatched four years ago over breakfast at the Diamond Pizza Family Restaurant in East Hampton. Four men, then between the ages of 50 and 65, decided something had to be done about the town budget. After all, town officials were proposing an 8.9 percent tax increase.
 So the men, who knew each other from church, came up with a plan. How about a top-down budget approach? Instead of complaining about individual line items, like the cost of police officers' uniforms, why not just give the town an overall spending cap and then let town officials decide where to spend the money? 
 For example, the group, the Common Sense Citizen/Taxpayer Group of East Hampton, said it decided last year that the town needed $26,570,817 for the 2001-2002 fiscal year, a $978,000 increase from the previous year. The group came up with the number by using a formula that takes into account such things as cost of living increases, bond payments, and the growth of the grand list. 
The group eventually ended up supporting a compromise budget about $100,000 higher, which was then approved by voters. The group, which has gotten taxpayers' attention by holding its own budget information meetings and putting information on its Web site, said it was the fourth year in a row that voters approved a budget the group had supported. Common Sense will next be tested on Tuesday when the town's proposed 2002-2003 budget, of which the group disapproves, goes to referendum.
Peter Arcidiacono, one of the group's founders, acknowledged that it was difficult to determine whether the group caused the past budget referendums to turn out the way they did. But, he said, the point is that they have tried to take a reasonable approach to what can be emotional debates. "You certainly hear enough complaints about taxes," Mr. Arcidiacono said. "And I think we just gave voice to the people who felt that something is wrong and I should say that we try to empower them with information." 
The philosophy seems to be spreading. In nearby Hebron, where taxpayers are in yet another difficult budget season that is exacerbated by the recent property revaluation, a group has adopted the East Hampton organization's approach.
"We set down some ground rules, basically that we will look at the money and try to determine whether or not these proposals that keep coming up are affordable," said Ronald Winter, co-chairman and co-founder of Hebron Dollars and Sense. "But we are not going to be the old-fashioned taxpayers association where the only goals seem to be slash and burn and to get up in public meetings and call people names and get all angry and raise a lot of noise and stuff."
Just how far this movement will go is unclear. The East Hampton organization, which has eight members on its governing committee, has talked about starting a statewide taxpayers group, but has not moved forward with those plans.
And, it was clear at a recent Common Sense budget information meeting in East Hampton that not everyone agrees with the group's approach. "I think it's stupid," said Eric Henzy of East Hampton, who has three children in the local school system. "I don't think any government anywhere can or does budget that way."
William Simonsen, professor and director of the master of public administration program at the University of Connecticut, said that while taxpayer groups can be effective in accomplishing their goals, they may not necessarily reflect the attitudes of a town. "The question is, Do these groups represent the populace generally? And the answer to that is, Probably not," Mr. Simonsen said.
But the philosophy has added a new page to budget battles that are waged each spring in various communities around the state.
"The idea of taking a percentage of the grand list and making some assumptions and taking some of the fixed costs out of the equation and assuming some of the efficiencies, it's unique to me," said Robert Lee, the town manager of Hebron who has worked in municipal government since 1978. 
Municipal budget battles are a common rite of spring. For years, residents of cities and towns have turned out at budget meetings, either advocating for spending cuts or increases. Depending on that year's revenue stream, the budgets can be passed without a hitch or, in extreme cases, can be repeatedly defeated, leading to summers filled with emergency budget sessions, contentious meetings and referendums.
With the recent downturn in the economy, an increasing amount of taxpayers are becoming concerned about government spending, said Susan Kniep, vice president of the Federation of Connecticut Taxpayers Organizations and a former mayor of East Hartford.
"I think people are getting a little bit wiser," said Ms. Kniep, whose organization consists of about 25 groups around the state.
In communities like Hebron, an outer ring suburb of Hartford whose population has increased by 22 percent in the past 10 years, the budget seasons have come to reflect the growing pains of the town, where new subdivisions are sprinkled among farmland.
"The town has really been blowing up since the 70's," said Brian Lessard, chairman of the Hebron Board of Finance and a town resident for nine years. "It's largely a farming community that's getting developed, so as the farms turn into homes, the schools need to grow."
Just down Route 66, East Hampton saw its population jump 28 percent in the past 10 years, increasing from 10,428 to 13,352, according to United States Census figures.
Though East Hampton has a different character than Hebron -- it has a rich manufacturing history and was a prominent vacation spot -- they have at least one thing in common: Proposed budget increases have concerned some taxpayers.
In East Hampton, Common Sense decided to tackle its members' concerns by developing its formula. It asks that the town not spend more than 80 percent of its new grand list growth and it subtracts a half percentage point for efficiency.
"We feel that the professional managers that implement and oversee the budget should be able to, during the course of the fiscal year, find areas of savings," said James Mathias, chairman of Common Sense.
So what made these Common Sense members experts on budget issues? Though Mr. Mathias is a former tax examiner for the state, none of the original four is an accountant. But, Mr. Mathias said, they developed their knowledge by sifting through reams of state reports, like per pupil spending rates, and attending many municipal meetings.
"Since 1998, we have attended as many of the town council, board of finance and board of education meetings as we could," he said.
At a recent meeting of the group, Mr. Mathias expressed frustration that town leaders have not used a "top-down" approach in preparing the budget. But Alan Bergren, the town manager of East Hampton, said Common Sense has had some influence. The Town Council budget policy statement, for example, mentions a "top-down" approach. But, he said, while the town has tried to apply the formula in some places, sometimes it's difficult to do. "You have to take a look at the details also," Mr. Bergren said. "Formulas work only to a certain degree. And I think the council and the Board of Finance has tried to focus on a top-down approach and look at overall spending and see where you can control it, but there's some things that you can't control because you don't have direct control," such as the cost of insurance.
"There's got to be a balance," he added. "You can use these tools to kind of get an overall focus, but you've got to be careful and you've got to get a balance in there."
However, he said, the group has managed to increase the amount of dialogue on the budgets, so that more attention is paid to it. And, he said, "it's not acrimonious."
The civil dialogue is one reason why the Hebron group decided to take the East Hampton approach. The idea was welcomed, especially after last year's budget season, which some said was the most contentious in recent memory. For the first time in at least a decade, the town budget was rejected at a town meeting. In addition, the regional school budget went to three referendums before it was passed. 
The heated rhetoric spilled over to the town green, where signs dotted the grassy strip. Residents wrote letters to the local weekly newspaper and name calling was not unheard of. "People would have signs and others would drive up on their lawn and drive over them in daylight in front of children," said Victoria Avelis, chairman of the Hebron Board of Selectman. "When people encountered each other that were on the opposite side of the issue it was very tense."
Consequently, she said, people didn't want to repeat the same situation this year.
"After last year, everyone agreed that we couldn't do it with signs and neighbor versus neighbor yelling," she added. "You had to get more professional and I think that's what Hebron Dollars and Sense is doing, trying to be more professional, coolheaded. We all live together and we'd like to be able to disagree and agree to disagree and not end up not speaking to each other or anything worse than that." 
And this year could prove to be an especially difficult budget season. A recent property revaluation could lead to a significant increase in taxes. Combine that with the school budget increases, where fixed costs like salaries and insurance as well as the cost of opening the new high school, and the average tax increase could be as high as 9.48 percent, Mr. Lee said.
To help people adjust to the potentially large increase in taxes, Mr. Lee has put binders in the library and at the local supermarket, Ted's Foods, that show the new assessed value of every property in town, the current taxes and the proposed tax increases according to the latest budget proposal. The data also breaks down how much of the tax increase is due to the revaluation and to the proposed budget.
The same figures are also on Hebron Dollars and Sense's Web site, which it advertised with hand-painted signs that dot the town's rural roads. The Web site, which Mr. Winter said has received more than 3,000 hits, also explains the group's top-down approach and its formula, which is modeled on the one used in East Hampton. 
However, not everyone has welcomed the group's approach. For one, William Silver, superintendent of schools for Hebron and Regional School District No. 8, cautioned that it is not wise to present numbers without putting them context.
"It doesn't take into account any factors within the system," Mr. Silver said. "It can't account for a 21 percent increase in health insurance rates or the fact that kindergarten enrollment is going to be 25 percent higher than we anticipated or that a new building is opening and obviously there are going to be increased costs.
"There's a big difference between ability to pay and willingness to pay," he said, referring to the town's taxpayers.
The true test will be tomorrow, when the town budget goes to a vote. 
In the meantime, one thing is clear. At the end of April, the only sign on the town green was advertising a book sale.

HEADLINE: A Parched Job Market Greets New Graduates 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOEPPEL 

 BODY:
RAJIAH WILLIAMS, a senior at Barnard College, thought she had done everything right to set herself up for a career in television. She got all A's and B's and was a producer for Columbia University's television station, a Head Start volunteer and a member of the French club. More important, she worked summers at Black Entertainment Television, CNN and Fairchild Publications, assuming that the experience and contacts would practically guarantee her a job after she graduated.
 It hasn't worked out that way. Over the last few weeks, ordinarily prime scouting time for employers on college campuses, Ms. Williams has landed only one interview for a job that actually existed, at NY1, the 24-hour news channel. Now, she is seriously considering riding out the hard times by moving to Paris to be an English tutor. 
 "I'm especially discouraged," said Ms. Williams, 21. "I've interned every summer since high school and always recognized the importance of the foot in the door and paying your dues. I never thought it would be a problem. I never thought I'd be in the position I'm in now."
With graduation only days away, Ms. Williams and thousands of other highly qualified job seekers in the New York City area are facing what recruiters, personnel executives and college career counselors agree is one of the most competitive job markets in more than a decade.
And they are advising graduating seniors who haven't found work to redouble their efforts and lower their expectations. In the current labor market, they say, students should scale back their salary demands, be willing to work for smaller companies and even consider relocating far from home.
"You have to use all your resources," said Trudy Steinfeld, the director of New York University's Office of Career Services. "Sitting around in your slippers, searching on the Internet is not going to cut it."
Specialists blame the usual suspects -- the sluggish economy; hard times on Wall Street and in the manufacturing and technology industries, and the reverberations of Sept. 11 -- for the bleak outlook in New York. But something of a more existential nature might be at work, too, in the view of one career manager. "The situation is made more complicated by the world picture," said Betty Feehan, senior manager of career services for the American Institute for Chemical Engineers, a trade organization. "People are edgy about making decisions."
Employers certainly are. Those who were surveyed last month by the National Association of Colleges and Employers said they expected a 36 percent decline this year in their hiring of college graduates; in the Northeast, they foresaw a 39 percent drop.
In such a buyers' market, students who just a couple of years ago watched companies tripping over themselves to entice graduating seniors with fat salaries and other perks are grateful to get even a single job offer. Others are opting out of the job market and heading off to graduate school.
"It's a stark turnaround: high supply and lower demand," said Dan Black, the area director of campus recruiting for Ernst & Young, one of the Big Five accounting firms. "In the recent past, it wasn't unusual for students to have three, four or five offers."
Mr. Black says Ernst & Young has already filled most of the 300 positions for its New York office, the same number as last year. But this year, it interviewed 10 to 15 percent more candidates and turned away many qualified applicants, he says.
He also noticed a shift in attitude in this year's crop of graduates. "In years past, students were saying, 'What can Ernst & Young offer me?' " he said. "Now applicants are more eager. They're saying, 'Hey, I can do whatever it takes.' "
Baruch College's director of career development, Patricia Imbimbo, believes there is another reason for the job drought besides the uneven economy: foolish overhiring in the boom years. "There was a war for talent," she said. "There were signing bonuses, offers being made to sophomores. It was a frenzy." As a result, many companies are now laying people off, not hiring them.
Stephanie Cohen, a senior at New York University who majored in secondary education, has broadened her job search to include marketing, public relations, human resources and publishing. She is currently working as an intern at Kenneth Cole, the leather-goods retailer, and was hoping that job would lead to full-time work in the marketing department.
In April, though, she was told there were no positions available. Now, she has set up a series of interviews, one with Kenneth Cole's international department and others for a marketing job at the Scholastic Corporation, a New York publisher, and for the position of community-service coordinator at a West Village community center.
Ms. Cohen, 22, has also been networking with friends and family members, and meets regularly with one well-connected acquaintance who has provided her with contacts at Conde Nast and American Express. "I worry about it every day," Ms. Cohen said of her job prospects. 
Career counselors think Ms. Cohen is on the right track. Ms. Steinfeld, the career-services director at New York University, advises students to master the nuts and bolts of job hunting, especially networking with everyone they know, attending professional association events and following up on resumes they send to potential employers.
John Challenger, chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm, says college seniors should consider careers in government, insurance, health care and nonprofit organizations, where jobs may be more plentiful. Indeed, the survey by the National Association of Colleges and Employers shows that the federal government and the insurance industry are two of just a handful of sectors that are expected to step up hiring this year.
For all the obstacles, of course, many students are being hired. Abraham Salcedo, a New York University senior who completed an internship with PricewaterhouseCoopers last summer, has been offered a job as an accountant with the firm. And Meredith Silverberg, a senior at Barnard, has accepted a job as a legal assistant with Cravath, Swaine & Moore, the Manhattan law firm.
But other graduating seniors have concluded that looking for a job right now just is not worth the effort. After Teisha Covino, a New York University senior, saw her friends jumping through hoops, she scratched her plan to work for a couple of years before going to law school. Instead, she will attend the University of Pennsylvania Law School in the fall.
Likewise, says Ms. Feehan of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, many top engineering students are heading straight to graduate school rather than spending a year or two in the field, a common practice in flush times. One student at Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., even abandoned his ambition to become a chemical engineer and joined his family's seafood business, she says.
Ms. Feehan says engineering students have a rough time looking for work because they tend to be introverts. Her advice: they should overcome their inhibitions and network like everybody else. "They need that New York chutzpah," she said.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Top 4 Floors in Chelsea to Be Above the Adjacent Structure; 
Condo Shaped Like Inverted L

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
At first glance it might seem as if it's going to be one building, but it's really two. The one on the left is a new nine-story condominium going up at 211 West 18th Street in Chelsea -- and its upper four floors hang over and are attached to the adjacent old five-story commercial building.
 When completed this summer the new building, shaped like an inverted L, will have eight loft apartments, including two duplexes. It replaces a four-story lumber store and warehouse that formerly stood on the site, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. 
 By buying air rights over the adjacent building, at 209 West 18th Street, and merging the two 25-foot-wide lots, the developer, G & S Brown Investments of Manhattan, was able to build a structure taller than the 60 feet that current zoning allows on one narrow lot. It could also make the building wider in spots. "It was the only way to make the project viable from a zoning and economic perspective," said Steven Brown, a partner in the company with his brother Gary.
The brothers acquired 211 West 18th Street two and a half years ago from the estate of Alan Bernstein, whose father, Max, had begun the lumber business in 1935. They had bought lumber there for years. 
The brothers worked out an agreement with the owner of the adjacent structure to buy the air rights, combine the lots and refurbish that masonry building, which has a ground-floor plumbing supply store with a warehouse above. The brothers said that the total cost of the project, including construction and the purchase of the building and the air rights, would be just under $10 million.
John Cetra, a principal at Cetra/Ruddy Inc. of Manhattan, the project's architect, said that while the 211 building was strong enough to hold the new floors, hollow air shafts in its easterly wall had been filled and capped with reinforced concrete to provide even more support. Its roof was replaced with the additional floors, which were anchored to the new portion's structural steel frame, Mr. Cetra said, adding that the new building's westerly wall and the steel central columns in the 50-foot-wide floors are other anchors. 
Sales of the units, with one to four bedrooms and 1,140 to 2,995 square feet, are to start today. Insignia Douglas Elliman is handling sales. Prices for the units are $850,000 to $2.9 million. The new building is clad in glass and metal with a masonry trim on its westerly edge. Where the building spans over its neighbor it steps back and curves, to create "a harmony" between the two, Mr. Cetra said. This is the first new construction project in Manhattan for the company, which owns 20 buildings with a total of 200 rental apartments. An affiliate, Furnished Quarters, owns 425 more Manhattan apartments used as extended-stay residences. RACHELLE GARBARINE

GRAPHIC: Photo: Part of new condo, left, covers neighbor. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/903 Park Avenue, at 79th Street; 
1914 Apartment House Once Called World's Tallest

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE scaffolding is going up -- and up and up -- on 903 Park Avenue, built in 1914 as the tallest apartment house in the world. The owner says the work is just routine, but the 17-story building was anything but, a sumptuous multiple dwelling designed to attract millionaires.
 By the early 1910's, the lawyers Alexander M. and Leo S. Bing had just entered the real estate business. By the 1920's they were among the most active apartment developers in New York, often working with Emery Roth on buildings like the Alden, at 82nd and Central Park West, and the Southgate complex of apartment houses on the south side of 52nd Street between First Avenue and the East River. 
 For one of their earliest projects, begun in 1912, they chose the northeast corner of 79th Street and Park Avenue. At that time Park was evolving from a wide boulevard of middle-class five- and six-story apartment buildings to one of mansions and tall luxury buildings. 
For 903 Park Avenue they hired Robert T. Lyons, who had designed the picturesque St. Urban, at 89th and Central Park West, and Warren & Wetmore, who had just finished co-designing Grand Central Terminal and had designed swank clubs and mansions. Unlike most other structures, apartment buildings were governed by fairly detailed laws, and buildings more than 150 feet high required a higher standard of fire-resistant construction. Thus that height, translating to about 12 stories, became the default standard along West End, Park and other avenues where apartment developers were active. 
But the corner of 79th and Park presented an unusual opportunity. Multiple-dwelling heights were also governed by the width of the street, through rules similar but not identical to the provisions that would be adopted in the 1916 Zoning Resolution, which applied to all building types. If the Bings would spend more on fireproofing, their corner could go up one and a half times the 140-foot width of Park Avenue, or 210 feet -- 17 stories, as construction practices indicated at the time.
"World's Highest Apartment House," The New York Times said in 1912, although the newspaper did not mention which building held the previous height record. 
The Times remarked that the Paterno Brothers, another development firm, had contemplated a 16-story building on the west side of Broadway between 115th and 116th Streets but had decided that the economics did not justify it. But Bing & Bing did, and Leo Bing ventured a revealing opinion to The Times: "Mr. Bing believes that the upper floors of the new 17-story house will be in greater demand than the lower floors and the price of the five top floors will be slightly higher than the middle and lower sections." These were super-apartments, full floors, some with 18 rooms and 5 baths, renting for around $10,000 a year. A period floor plan shows a 13-foot-wide circular foyer and living rooms of 20 by 26 feet, with the largest bedroom measuring 20 by 23 feet. Each apartment had its own laundry, six servants' rooms and a servants' dining room.
An account in Real Estate Magazine in 1913 gives an idea of how the developers aimed at their market. The dining room walls were finished in blue and gold silk, the master bedroom in "French gray" silk. The bedroom hallway had a mosaic floor, with a six-inch-high marble baseboard. The bathrooms had showers, tubs and bidets, and all the apartment window frames were bronze -- apparently a fireproofing measure.
If the four bedrooms were not enough, new tenants could arrange to make up or down connections to more bedrooms from adjacent apartments. Although most servants' rooms were at a distance from the bedrooms, there was a "personal maid's room" leading on to the main hall. Each kitchen had its own silver safe and garbage incinerator, and there was also a steam-cleaning apparatus in the basement for garbage pails. But most revealing was a separate scullery, set apart from the kitchen, "it being intended that no rough work shall be done in the kitchen," the magazine said.
The exterior was described as being in "tapestry brick," which usually indicated a soft, mottled mixture of green, gray and buff; the building is now so soiled it appears to be a monochrome gray. But there wasn't a lot of art to this new breed of apartment building; The Times noted that the solid walls were "relieved by a few artistic balconies."
Apparently Bing & Bing planned this building for sale, and in February 1914 they sold it to Maria DeWitt Jesup, the widow of the banker Morris K. Jesup, who had been president of the American Museum of Natural History. She had inherited $9 million from her husband in 1908, and she gave the museum multiple gifts, including the 34-ton Ahnighito meteorite, still on display there. Perhaps it was a financial advisor who arranged the purchase of 903 Park -- Mrs. Jesup was 80 when she died in June 1914. 
The tenants attracted to 903 Park Avenue included William Seward Webb, a physician who had forsaken medicine and become rich enough in railway investments to build an expansive estate in Vermont now known as Shelburne Farms. He lived at 903 with his wife, Elizabeth, and 11 servants; most were of Scottish and English birth and had arrived in the United States in the previous 10 years. When he died in 1926 his obituary in The Times noted that he "became one of the first owners of an old Fifth Avenue mansion to move into a Park Avenue apartment."
A tenant in the 1930's was Walter Hoving, president of Lord & Taylor and later head of Tiffany & Company. In November 1938 he was involved in a minor dispute about a simulated blizzard in Lord & Taylor's Christmas windows. The Fifth Avenue Association, of which he was a director, protested that the imitation snowflakes violated the association's ban on moving displays. Mr. Hoving immediately complied, although he pointed out that the Christmas windows were not designed to sell merchandise. 
IN 1917 the Jesup estate sold 903 Park Avenue to the investor Vincent Astor of the real estate family. A few years later, Astor built a town house around the corner at 130 East 80th Street. 
By the 1920's, other, taller apartment buildings had gone up. Sometime after 1940 most of the apartments were cut up, although there are three floors left more or less intact: a doctors' suite, and two residential units. Perhaps 20 or 30 years ago, the ornamental balconies were shaved off.
Last month, workers began putting pipe scaffolding up around the facades. The building is still a rental, and Marianne Dziuba, senior vice president of Stahl Real Estate, the owner, said that the firm was planning normal maintenance and needed the pipe scaffolding because the overhanging copper cornice projects so far out that scaffolding hung from the roof will not work. 
She said that the copper cornice, which is sagging in some parts, would be repaired, and that other pointing work would go on, although the firm was not certain whether it would clean the building. Stahl Real Estate declined to respond to questions about current rents.
She said that in the last few years the firm had begun to restore the circular entry foyers that remain on most floors and that, unlike many rental building managers, she had not replaced the old windows but had stripped and shined the bronze. 
"They don't leak, they're still in good shape," she said. "They were really built to withstand the centuries."

LENGTH: 1515 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Carroll Gardens; 
Area of Gardens and 19th-Century Charm

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
A CENTURY ago, Carroll Gardens was a working-class neighborhood in Brooklyn, home to thousands of Irish immigrants. In the decades before World War II, the Irish moved out and first-generation Italians moved in.
 The neighborhood kept its Italian-American character for decades and to a large degree retains it still. But in recent years a new group has begun to settle in the area -- young urban professionals. 
 "They're from Iowa, Oklahoma, Nebraska, Kansas, all over the heartland of America," said Salvatore J. Scotto, known as Buddy, the president of the Carroll Gardens Association and the informal mayor of the area. "When they come here into the neighborhood, they feel great because everybody's looking after everybody else. They realize that people around here care about them. They don't get that feeling in Manhattan because Manhattan is just too busy." 
For the moment, the usual order of property transfer in this urban neighborhood of three- and four-story brownstones and federal brick town houses has undergone a reversal. People are moving in when they attain a certain degree of wealth, rather than the other way around.
An urban renaissance has led people of means to stay put. Mr. Scotto, for example, was ready to leave in 1964. "Like everybody, it was time to move to the suburbs," he said. But his parents encouraged him to stay, and he founded the association.
The neighborhood took its name from the new civic association that Mr. Scotto had founded. Carroll Gardens was formerly just a section of a larger area called South Brooklyn, which also included what is now Cobble Hill and Boerum Hill. The most recent indication of the neighborhood's changes has been the transformation of its main commercial street, Smith Street, from a dreary gray strip to a rejuvenated row of cafes, boutiques and clubs that draws people from outside the neighborhood.
"When I first moved here, you wouldn't walk on Smith Street at night," said Laurie Alicea, 38, who moved to Sackett Street 30 years ago with her family. "Now, it reminds me of the Village."
The neighborhood's two commercial streets run north and south through its center. In addition to Smith Street, which lies above the F and G subway lines, Court Street, one block to the west, has also experienced a recent commercial growth.
Real estate agents say that residents are attracted to the area for its 19th-century charm and quiet tree-lined streets, its shops within walking distance and its location not far from the offices in Downtown and Midtown Manhattan.
The areas to the west of Court Street are the most sought after in the neighborhood, especially the blocks where the row houses have deep, verdant front yards. It is these gardens from which the neighborhood got its name. They exist between Court and Henry Streets, from First Place to Fourth Place. On this side of the neighborhood, the poplars are so thick with leaves that one cannot see the upper floors of the buildings without crossing the street.
The name Carroll comes from Charles Carroll of Maryland, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. During the Revolutionary War, he led a regiment of 400 men that tried to regain from the British a strategically placed farmhouse on the Gowanus Creek, now the Gowanus Canal. About 300 of his men were killed in the attacks, which took place in August 1776. A street, a park and then the neighborhood were named after him.
Between Court and Smith the buildings are similar to those to the west, but the trees are fewer and smaller. Between Smith and the Gowanus Canal, the neighborhood's eastern border, the buildings too are smaller and some blocks are devoted to industrial use. This side of the neighborhood also has blocks with front-garden lots, from President Street to Second Street between Smith and Hoyt Streets.
In the past, the blocks near the canal frequently suffered from putrid smells emanating from the stagnant, polluted canal. But in 1999 a long-unused flushing propeller was reactivated to circulate the water, and in the years since, the smell has vanished and birds and fish have come to the canal, as have weekend kayakers, said Craig Hammerman, district manager for Community Board 6, which includes Carroll Gardens.
Mr. Scotto said he hoped that with the changes, some of the industrial blocks, which had formerly housed businesses that used the canal for shipping, could now be converted to mixed-income residential use.
Over the past 10 years, prices for homes have steadily climbed, real estate agents said, until about a year ago, when they leveled off as the recession began to take hold. A multifamily brownstone or brick town house typically sells for $650,000 to $1.3 million, depending first on size, then location and condition. In multiple-family buildings, the owners often live in a garden apartment and rent the upper floors, or live in an upper-floor duplex or triplex and rent out the lower floors.
Neighborhood rents are about $1,000 for a studio, $1,200 to $1,600 for a one-bedroom apartment and $1,800 to $2,500 for a two-bedroom apartment, said Michael Mayo, manager of Carroll Gardens Realty, which specializes in rentals. There are few co-ops or condominiums in the area, but those that are available, like the newly built Carroll Gardens Condominiums on the south side of Degraw Street, are usually about $400 a square foot, which for a two-bedroom unit translates to about $400,000 to $450,000, according to Christopher Thomas, the director of the Brooklyn office of the William B. May Company.
The neighborhood is in many ways similar to Cobble Hill and Boerum Hill, the two other former slices of South Brooklyn that lie to the north of Degraw Street. "It's the same thing, the exact same thing," Mr. Mayo said with a wave of the arm at his office at Degraw and Smith Streets encompassing all the neighborhoods nearby.
But there are subtle differences. While subway service in Carroll Gardens is limited to the F and G trains, the other neighborhoods each have at least 10 lines within walking distance. And while the long blocks of Boerum Hill seem to stretch on as far as the eye can see, in Carroll Gardens at many intersections with Smith and Henry Streets, the corners of the east-west streets often do not quite line up with one another. The ability to see the end of a street a few blocks away creates a feeling of, if not exactly coziness, manageability. And on the streets that are affected, there is less traffic, Mr. Hammerman said. 
PRICES in the neighborhood are similar to neighboring regions. "The bigger brownstones are going to sell in the same range as anything you're going to get in Boerum Hill or Cobble Hill," said Sal Capozucca, a lifelong Carroll Gardens resident who has a real estate office on Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill, where he uses the name Sal Cappi.
Mr. Thomas said Cobble Hill's slightly higher prices might be attributable to the fact that the area was desirable for doctors and others who wanted to be located near Long Island College Hospital in Cobble Hill.
There is one public elementary school in the neighborhood: P.S. 58, the Carroll School, on Smith Street, where 51 percent of all students read at or above grade levels last year, about 6 percentage points above above the citywide average, 45.3 percent. Students often advance to Intermediate School 293 in Boerum Hill. 
The neighborhood is also home to Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary and St. Stephen Roman Catholic Parish School on Summit Street, which has an enrollment of 220 students from prekindergarten through eighth grade.
On the church itself, just east of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, weather-worn letters under the steeple clock spell out the words "Drive Carefully."
There are two other Roman Catholic churches in the area, St. Mary Star of the Sea, on Court Street between Nelson and Luquer Streets, and St. Agnes Church on Sackett Street at Hoyt Street. There is also an Episcopal Church, St. Paul's, at the corner of Clinton and Carroll Streets. Another church, Old Westminster, at 450 Clinton Street at the corner of First Place, with wrought-iron gates, antique-style street lamps and stone Romanesque architecture, has been turned into co-op apartments.
A stroll down Sackett Street shows the dynamic at play in Carroll Gardens. Ms. Alicea, the 30-year resident, said she appreciated the new commercial vigor on Smith Street but said that she felt the neighborhood had lost some of the friendliness she remembered growing up and that most of her friends had moved to Staten Island.
She confessed to staying because her grandmother owned her building and charged below-market rent. Reflecting on the appeal of the greater space and privacy that attracted many of her former schoolmates to other neighborhoods, she said, "Maybe it's because I grew up here, but the brownstones don't do anything for me."
A few doors down, Doug Klosterman, 32, an architect from St. Louis, unloaded a truck as he moved into a fourth-floor walkup that rents for $1,400 a month. He had no such brownstone fatigue. "Everyone had great things to say about the area," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 2, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 12 about living in Carroll Gardens omitted an elementary school in the neighborhood. It is P.S. 146, the Brooklyn New School, at 610 Henry Street.



GRAPHIC: Photos: President Street has numerous gardens and trees. One of two main commercial streets in the neighborhood, Court Street has experienced a recent revival. But on May 3, 1999, the canal was transformed when the propeller that sits at its head was activated for the first time since it broke in the early 1960's. While the bottom of the canal is still tainted with a century of industrial waste and, legend has it, a few Mafiosi, the propeller circulates the once-stagnant water. The odor is gone, said Jeanne DiLascio, executive director of the Gowanus Canal Community Development Corporation. Because of that, she said, she expects real estate prices along the canal to increase. "I think Carroll Gardens and Park Slope will be connected in the near future," she said, "with a body of water that's not a separator, but a connector." SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2994 words

HEADLINE: The Odd Couple 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA FITZGERALD 

DATELINE: MADISON 

 BODY:
TEN minutes before the cameras begin to roll, the two former governors are huddled like unflappable executives debriefing each other before a board meeting.
 The conversation between the two, Tom Kean and Brendan Byrne, is relaxed as they stroll the corridors of Mead Hall at Drew University, awaiting a signal that it is time to start taping a television interview on Governor McGreevey's evolving budget in the face of a gaping $5.3 billion deficit and a testy Legislature. 
 The pair need little time to prepare. After all, they have both juggled billions of dollars -- each having had to manufacture his own budget in two consecutive terms. Mr. Kean knows what he is going to say, and though Mr. Byrne is carrying a briefing book, he tosses it aside as they take their seats and begin the interview. There is a chemistry, formed by years of moving in the same political circles, observing each other's tennis serve and sharing stories only the small circle of former governors would understand. 
After about five minutes, Kent Manahan, the anchorwoman for the New Jersey Network, asks the obvious: whether the budget at this point is not just a work in progress. Certainly some deals will be cut with the Legislature, won't they?
Mr. Kean and Mr. Byrne look at each other and say simultaneously in mock disbelief, "Deals? . . . Deals? . . . In Trenton?"
The two are on a roll. They're entertaining. They're informative. They are A-list invitees, on the speed dial of the current governor, James E. McGreevey. In addition, they have a regular column that appears in The Star-Ledger.
They are, in short, the antidote to two grumpy old men. And they could not have come from more diverse backgrounds. Mr. Kean, who is 67, is a moderate Republican from Far Hills, and the 78-year-old Mr. Byrne is a scrappy Irish-American Democrat from West Orange -- yet they act and move almost as brothers. 
True, both graduated from Princeton, the state's premier university. But while Mr. Byrne financed his education through the G.I. Bill after serving in the Army Air Corps in World War II, Mr. Kean of the broad vowels was the product of a family steeped in wealth and politics, and four years at Princeton was a natural progression. After all, his grandfather had served in the United States Senate, and his father was a member of the House of Representatives for 20 years.
As for Mr. Byrne, his family was involved in politics on the local level -- his father was the police and fire commissioner in West Orange and his grandfather was an alderman -- but none of the land his family had owned was a gift from the King of England, a boast that Mr. Kean could make.
After graduating from Princeton, Mr. Kean taught history at St. Mark's, an elite prep school in Southboro, Mass. But he left to earn a master's degree at Columbia. Mr. Byrne, on the other hand, went to Harvard Law and began practicing in 1950. There is more than just a shared political experience, however; there is that chemistry. Mr. Byrne, who is outgoing and witty, plays well against the reserved, articulate Mr. Kean.
In the post-Newt Gingrich era, putting a Democrat and a Republican together on television is almost as likely to draw blood as it is civil discourse. Yet the two elder statesmen serve as a reminder of how the game was played in a gentler time. While others talk over one another and -- as often as not -- scramble for the low ground, Mr. Kean and Mr. Byrne might disagree, but they don't stake their claim at 10 paces.

'A Very Deep Affection'
"There is a very deep affection," said Carl Golden, who was Governor Kean's press secretary. "They have become the elder statesmen of New Jersey politics -- not their party, but New Jersey politics as both of them would like to see it practiced. That is, with vigor, but with not such a partisan edge and coarseness to it."
The state's two other living governors -- Christie Whitman and Jim Florio, are not nearly as close, and they do not enjoy the same popularity.
To be sure, their approaches are vastly different, which widens their appeal. Mr. Kean has never given a political interview in his home; Mr. Byrne has never had an unlisted telephone number. When asked to be interviewed, Mr. Kean chose his office at Drew University; Mr. Byrne arranged lunch at a Chinese restaurant that featured live jazz. Mr. Kean was alone; Mr. Byrne arrived with his wife, Ruthi, and invited nearly as many people as he ran into along the way to join them, debriefing guests about the best selections on the menu.
In 1973, when Mr. Byrne decided to run for governor, he had never before held elective office. Rather, his career had been propelled by mentors who brought him along and appointed him to important positions. On the other hand, Governor Kean -- although born with a plethora of social and political connections -- worked his way to the State Legislature in 1969, eventually becoming Assembly speaker in 1972 before running for governor five years later.
Unlike Mr. Byrne, however, Mr. Kean was not elected his first time out. After a successful run in 1981, his popularity soared. Indeed, last year he was asked by several leading Republicans to take on the incumbent Senator Robert Torricelli -- tarnished after years of federal investigations into his campaign finances -- but he chose to stay out of today's rough-and-tumble world of partisan politics.
Mr. Byrne, who was responsible for enacting the state's first income tax law, did not enjoy as much popularity while in office but was candid enough to win a second term. He has remained active in political circles, all the while cultivating his humor and wit.
To lift a line from the mayor of Newark, Sharpe James, they seem like "the real deal," unblemished by pollsters telling them what positions to take. Even when in office, the two acknowledged that they often did not listen to the political wisdom of the day. For Mr. Byrne, that meant no apologies for a statewide income tax. For Mr. Kean, it meant ignoring Republicans who told him to stay out of the troubled cities. Mr. Kean, who made "the politics of inclusion" a major theme of his campaign, remains one of the last statewide Republican candidates to have won black and minority votes handily.
Yet although he enjoys great popularity, he jokes that he is sometimes mistaken for Mr. Byrne. "Just yesterday, the guy who was pumping my gas came up and said, well, he called me Governor Byrne," he said, " 'Governor Byrne, I love your column. I read it every week.' That happens to me, and I know it happens to him. We get confused a little bit by the public."
One time, Mr. Kean joked, he even signed an autograph as Brendan Byrne. "Somebody came running up to me and said, 'Governor Byrne, Governor Byrne, I'd love to meet you; I admire you and the column and everything else' and he said, 'Can I have your autograph?' " Mr. Kean recalled. "So I signed Brendan Byrne."
As for the spirited Mr. Byrne, he readily acknowledged that his popularity took a longer time to cultivate.
"He was always popular," Mr. Byrne said. "For me, it's distance. I put through that income tax and was roundly booed. My popularity when I was re-elected was in the high 30's; it never got to be 50 percent."
In fact, he said, a big reason he won re-election was that people realized that his income tax program made sense.
"It was really the last election decided on issues and not popularity," he said. "My campaign was classic. It was on the issue of do we need an income tax or don't we need an income tax. I would stand up and debating my opponent and say, 'If you want to elect a nicer guy, vote for him, but if you want this and that and want soundness of fiscal policy, you've got to look at me.' "
Luck and circumstance initially thrust Mr. Byrne into politics. He was working for a lawyer named Joseph Weintraub, who became counsel to Gov. Robert Meyner in 1954. As it happened, Mr. Byrne was brought along as an assistant. It was a time of celebration for Democrats, since Dwight D. Eisenhower, a Republican, was president, and a Democrat had not been elected governor since 1940.
"Meyner took a liking to me," Mr. Byrne recalled. "Then I became secretary to Governor Meyner, which is now like chief of staff, and I stayed with him for almost two years." Toward the end of his second term, the governor -- "he was sort of a father figure to me" -- asked Mr. Byrne what he wanted to do next.
"I've always been a lawyer," Mr. Byrne said he replied. "I'd love to be prosecutor of Essex County."

Reputation for Integrity
By "sheer luck," he said, there was an opening in 1959, so "they could do it without my paying political dues."
As prosecutor, Mr. Byrne earned a reputation for integrity, a trait that would position him well during his race for governor in 1973, an era dominated by fallout from the Watergate scandal.
"When I was prosecutor, the F.B.I. was doing some wiretaps," he recalled. "On one of them, they picked up a conversation about me in which they were saying, 'This guy is a Boy Scout . . . you can't get to him . . . he can't be bought.' Now Watergate comes along, and the prime quality is honesty. And so I was certified."
While Watergate was good for Mr. Byrne, it was a difficult time for Republicans like Tom Kean, who eventually retired from the State Legislature. "I was speaker of the Assembly during the beginning of Watergate," Mr. Kean said. "Right in the middle of Watergate we had an election and I came back as minority leader of 14 Republicans."
He recalled: "I remember walking down the street in Livingston and somebody shouted at me and said they wanted to say hello to me. And they said, 'You know, you're the best legislator we've ever had and I just want to thank you for that . . . but he said I'm going to tell you I'm going to vote against you because we've got to send a message to Nixon.' "
Nonetheless, Mr. Kean won re-election to the Assembly. And even though Republicans bounced back somewhat in the next election, they remained in the minority, prompting him to eventually retire from the Assembly in 1978 because he "couldn't take the minority any longer."
"I'd been so used to being in the majority -- not only the majority but I'd been majority leader and speaker and all that so you could really craft legislation and feel good at night when you got home because you got this and that done," he said. "But in the minority, it's fun for a while because you throw rocks into the process and slow things down, but it's not as much fun."
Mr. Kean had decided to run in the gubernatorial primary against Ray Bateman, who at the time was Senate president. He did not think he had any chance of winning -- which was an accurate assumption -- but he realized that the experience would be good and he wanted the bully pulpit.
"I wanted to say what I thought was important in the state, and what I thought was wrong," he said. "You can do that when you run for governor. You don't have to win. But if you're a serious candidate, what you say gets paid attention."
He said that "while everybody else was talking about the income tax, I was talking about education."
Though Mr. Kean did not win the primary, he established a core group of supporters who urged him to run again. The second time around, he only had three county chairman supporting him. 
"From the time I declared in the primary until the time I was elected governor, not a single poll said I would win either the primary or the general," Mr. Kean said.
But he did have one advantage over his opponents: He had done this before. "I knew what was important and what wasn't, politically," Kean said.
Mr. Kean emerged victorious from the primary and went on to win in November.
Even in their younger days, these two old warriors were on each other's radar screen. While Mr. Byrne was governor, he appointed Mr. Kean -- who was Assembly speaker -- to the Highway Authority. And when Mr. Kean was later elected governor, he appointed Mr. Byrne to the Sports and Exposition Authority. But it was not until Mr. Kean was elected governor, and Democrats controlled the State Legislature, that their relationship deepened.
"He and I used to get together very often in my early years as governor," Mr. Kean recalled. "We'd get away from the State House, usually prior to a tennis game, and I'd ask him very frankly things that you can only ask people who have had the same job before you. He was enormously free and helpful with his advice."
"We had the worst recession going on since the Great Depression, and I had a budget deficit that approached a billion dollars," Mr. Kean recalled. "I asked him all sorts of advice about ways to save money . . . I had a Democratic Legislature, so he was very helpful as I asked him questions about how you deal with certain members, how you could communicate with them, get across your point of view."
Listening was how Mr. Kean got his start in politics. One of the first people he listened to was a professor at Princeton, who had told him that one of the most exciting things he had done was work for a presidential campaign that did not have a chance of winning, because it enabled the staff to get closer to the candidate.
Mr. Kean said he took the advice and joined the presidential campaign of William Scranton. At the time of his presidential bid in 1964, Mr. Scranton, the governor of Pennsylvania, said he was drawn to the race because of the battle over the Civil Rights Act. His campaign was largely about making the Republican Party more inclusive, a theme Mr. Kean would continue to preach. Bill Bradley, who was still a Republican, also worked on the Scranton campaign. But while Mr. Kean became energized and worked within the party to try to make it more inclusive, Mr. Bradley, who would go on to become a United States senator from New Jersey, decided to switch parties.
"I got very excited by the process," said Mr. Kean, adding that he was told that if he was serious about pursuing politics he needed to get involved on the local level.
With that, Mr. Kean called Webster Todd, Christie Whitman's father, who was then chairman of the state Republican Party. Mr. Todd made Mr. Kean the party's youth coordinator for the state. After two years, Mr. Kean decided to run for the Assembly.
Despite their love of politics, both Mr. Byrne and Mr. Kean concede that if they had to run in today's political climate, with such a heavy emphasis on raising money, they might not have entered their races.
"I have never made a phone call in my life asking people for money," Mr. Byrne said. "You only had to raise a little bit, and we raised no money between elections. I got elected in 1973, served four years and never asked anybody for a dime. But we ran campaigns for almost nothing."
He added, "If when I had run in 1973, they said you have to have $25,000 of your own money, I could not have run."
In fact, when Mr. Byrne left office in 1982, he said, he had to borrow money from his children to pay for a house.
As for Mr. Kean, he also did not use any of his own money when he ran for governor.
"People consider me thrifty," Mr. Kean joked. "Brendan considers me cheap."
On a more serious level, however, Mr. Kean said that he did not believe that it was fair for candidates to pump much of their own money into a race. "I think you should be in the same competition as everybody else," he said.

A Nastier Political Process
Of course that notion of campaign finance -- as well as the whole political process -- has changed since Mr. Kean and Mr. Byrne were involved.
"It's nastier," Mr. Kean, which may explain why he chose not to run for the Senate this year against Mr. Torricelli, who is known to be a tough campaigner. "The kind of ads that people run against each other now are pretty outrageous in their inaccuracies as well as their innuendoes."
Yet life goes on, as does the next generation of Keans and Byrnes; both men have sons who have entered the political arena. Mr. Kean's son Tom is a member of the Assembly. And Mr. Byrne's son Tom is a former chairman of the state Democratic Party. But they both concede that with the vast amounts of money now required to run for office, and the system favoring incumbents, it is much harder for their children to seek public office than it ever was for them. 
That said, the two remain loyal to the reasons that first drew them into politics: shaping and giving voice to issues they believe are important today. And so through their column and their television appearances, they remain at the forefront of political discussions throughout the state.
"Through the years," Mr. McGreevey said, "Governor Byrne and Governor Kean have served as mentors and have been invaluable to me with regard to their insight and wisdom."
Jim Willse, editor of The Star-Ledger, said he knew immediately that he should ask the two men to do a column for the newspaper after he saw them on NJN News during an election night seven years ago.
"I was taken by the chemistry between them, how smart they were, how knowledgeable they were and how they enjoyed each other's company," Mr. Willse said.
Ms. Manahan of NJN feels the same way. "It's just been a terrific opportunity, really, for the people of New Jersey to hear from two former governors, who obviously have a relationship with one another but have different perspectives on different issues," she said. "The governors will get into it with one another, and sometimes they may differ sharply . . . yet there is a certain gentlemanly civility here."
And they are still doing in their own inimitable way.
A perfect example is an exchange between Mr. Kean and Mr. Byrne during the last gubernatorial election. Mr. Byrne was making the point that Mr. McGreevey had successfully defined his Republican opponent, Bret Schundler, on two issues: abortion and guns. For his part, Mr. Byrne thought the race was over when Mr. McGreevey kept hammering at "guns and girls."
"Tom Kean said you can't say guns and girls," Mr. Byrne recalled. "O.K., women and weapons."
