SECTION: Section 11; Column 2; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 3127 words

HEADLINE: In Hell's Kitchen, a Changing Skyline 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
WHEN the star-crossed lovers of "West Side Story," Tony and Maria, longingly sang, "There's a place for us," they could hardly have conceived what would become of their gritty neighborhood -- tower after tower of sleek luxury residential buildings casting shadows across their low-lying warren of 19th-century tenements.
 Certainly, today's rents of up to $5,600 a month for a penthouse in those richly appointed high-rise buildings -- even if adjusted downward for decades of inflation -- would have proved prohibitive for late-1950's denizens of a community that is still referred to by some as Hell's Kitchen and by others, more genteelly, as Clinton. 
 And besides, not one of the glistening facades has a zigzag fire escape bolted to it -- though there are terraces.
Over the last three years, like widespread fingers reaching skyward from West 34th to 59th Streets, close to a dozen residential buildings have opened their doors to new tenants, recently topped off construction or are still filling in their skeletal girders. Others remain, for now, gaping excavations waiting to be steel-fed by looming cranes. 
The burst of residential development -- most of it in a westward corridor along 41st, 42nd and 43rd Streets from Eighth Avenue to the Hudson River, with other sites scattered to the north and south -- is rising above a community of stooped and corniced walk-up buildings, their halls lined by railroad flats. The tenements, some dating to the 1850's, are scattered among body shops, car washes, parking lots, warehouses, factories and regiments of tractor-trailers behind razor-wired fences. Not to mention an ample supply of saloons.
And while real estate executives see great potential for further residential development of the area, and city planners envision a westward expansion of office-dominated Midtown into what they consider one of the few remaining underused expanses of Manhattan, there are local officials, longtime residents and community curmudgeons who like things much as they are. They fear for the extinction of another New York neighborhood with its vintage character and colorful, if somewhat seedy, past.
"Fifty-story skyscrapers are out of character, out of line," said John Fisher, president of the Clinton Special District Coalition, a local civic group. "They are not good, just not good." 
The forces for change disagree. "This was a rundown area ravaged with prostitution," said Lisa Silverstein, vice president for residential development for Silverstein Properties, which already has one luxury tower well occupied in the community, and another in the works. "This is one of the unsaturated pockets of New York, and things are happening and will continue to happen over there in terms of development."
In December, the New York City Planning Department released a document titled, "Far West Midtown: A Framework for Development," a plan that calls for the transformation of the southern portion of Clinton -- from 28th Street to 41st Street and Eighth Avenue to the river -- into office towers, some residential buildings and parks. At the same time, the Jets of the National Football League are pressing a $1 billion plan for construction of a sports and entertainment complex over the rail yards between 30th and 33rd Streets and 10th to 12th Avenues, a project that could also be a component of the city's bid for the 2012 Olympics.
All of which would be dependent on a $1.5 billion extension of the crosstown No. 7 subway line, farther west from its Seventh Avenue terminus and south to 34th Street.
"The plan," said Richard Barth, director of the City Planning Department's Manhattan office, "is a recognition that the city needs space to grow, particularly the central Midtown business district. It recognizes that this area offers one of the prime opportunities for the city to meet its economic needs over a 20-, 30-year horizon." 
The residential towers along that 42nd Street corridor and sprinkled, mostly, to the north all the way to the 75-story AOL Time Warner residential and office complex now rising at Columbus Circle, along with the city's far west office visions, the sports complex proposal and the possible extension of the No. 7 line, are all proving a bit unnerving for Simone Sindin, the chairwoman of Community Board 4.
"This is scary," said Ms. Sindin, whose board covers Clinton and Chelsea. "This is having your world changed and the rug pulled out from under your feet."
Mr. Fisher of the Clinton coalition insisted: "The city has to realize that maintaining neighborhoods is important. They're claiming that the area below 42nd street is not built out. But there are neighborhoods down there, and businesses that the city needs."
THE block between 41st and 42nd Streets and 11th and 12th Avenues could be seen at the symbolic, if not quite geographic, core of all the change. There stands, at the western end of the block, Riverplace I, a 40-story, 920-apartment luxury rental building with ribbon windows wrapped around its curved corners, offering views of the spikes and spires of Midtown and glorious sunsets.
While Ms. Silverstein's company bought development rights to the entire block 14 years ago, Riverplace I -- with its health club and tennis courts and rents ranging from $1,600 for a studio to $5,600 for a penthouse -- opened only a year ago. It is 76 percent occupied. 
"We have a mostly young, professional crowd who walk to work in Midtown," Ms. Silverstein said.
At the eastern end of the block, along 11th Avenue, is a parking lot. And attached to the chain-link fence surrounding the parking lot is a large-lettered sign proclaiming, "Future Site of Riverplace II."
If Silverstein Properties realizes its dreams, Riverplace II will be a 53-story tower, sleeker and more expensive than its elder sibling. Its 882 apartments will have "higher ceilings, higher finishes, a lot of marble and limestone and porcelain in terms of the bathrooms; highly amenitized," Ms. Silverstein said. The company plans to seek preliminary construction bids by the end of summer.
"By the time we are all done," Ms. Silverstein said, "we hope to have close to 5,000 people living on that block. And that is because most of the units at Riverplace I are young people sharing the expense of that apartment."
"I think we are the anchor for what's going to proliferate in the area," she said. 
Actually, what is already proliferating.
Not even counting dozens of less dominating projects -- midblock buildings required by zoning ordinances to maintain the heights of their longstanding neighbors, renovated tenement buildings with penthouses suddenly plopped on top -- these are just some of the major residential developments currently under way in the community:
*On the north side of 42nd Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, beside Holy Cross Church, the Ivy Tower has risen.
Two weeks ago, a topping off ceremony was held for the 43-story, 270-unit building developed by Friedman Management on a 22,000-square-foot site that used to be a parking lot. But a courtyard is coming behind the tower -- 4,000 square feet of rock garden, waterfall and abstract sculpture in a midblock belt connecting to the smaller piece of the same complex -- a seven-story, 50-apartment building on 43rd Street. Occupancy in the smaller building is expected to begin in July, and in the tower by November. Studios will start at $1,800, one-bedrooms at $2,700 and two-bedrooms at $4,000.
*On the northwest corner of 10th Avenue and 41st Street, long the site of four tenements and a parking lot, stands the Victory.
The 45-story building with 417 apartments has a masonry facade with bay windows up to its 26th floor. But from there, said Hal Fetner, president of Sidney Fetner Associates, the developers, "it grows into a glass tower, a progression of less brick and more glass, which forms a V-shape in the corner of the building at 41st and 10th."
The 24-hour doorman building, said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, the rental broker for the Victory, will have a health club, an indoor half basketball court, a sun deck, a landscaped garden, a golf driving range, a tenant's lounge and "a vending center, so, at night, people can get their munchies, juices and waters." The rental office, Ms. Packes said, is scheduled to open by the end of this month. Studios will start in the high $1,800's; one-bedrooms around $2,400, two-bedrooms at about $3,900.
*Beside the long-dark Biltmore Theater, on the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and 47th Street, the Parker family is developing a 51-story, 464-unit residential building with three commercial floors that incorporates unused air rights from the theater and the firehouse at the corner of 48th Street. It replaced six tenement buildings.
The building will be 20 stories taller than zoning formulas would originally have allowed, a bonus granted by the city because the developers are rehabilitating the Biltmore Theater -- home to "Hair" and "Barefoot in the Park" -- which has been dark since it was damaged by fire in 1987.
*With a ramp wrapping around it and leading into the Lincoln Tunnel, the lot at the southwest corner of Ninth Avenue and 37th Street was a huge pit two months ago. Now, cranes are lowering girders into place.
What is coming is a 14-story, 259-apartment building, developed by the Dermot Meridian Corporation. The building, the first major construction on Ninth Avenue below 42nd Street in the Clinton area in 30 years, is replacing a Burger King and one of those quadruple-decker parking lots that lift cars, piggyback style, on open steel frames.
*It won't be open to the public, but on the south side of 43rd Street near 11th Avenue, a 23-story building with 106 apartments began welcoming residents on May 1 -- all of them employees of the Chinese government.
Called the Residence Tower of the Chinese Consulate General, the $28 million building bears an arched, ribbed roof with a curved facade of frameless glass held in place by cables threaded through pinholes. The 20th and 21st floors, reserved for the ambassador, have stainless steel and granite exteriors. Construction started a year and a half ago, with finishing touches expected by July.
An eight-story factory building had been on the site. "They bought it for $8 million," said Joseph Maggio, vice president of Princeton General Construction, the builders. "Twenty years ago, it could have sold for a couple hundred thousand."
"I'm very familiar with the area," Mr. Maggio said. "When I was with Colby Construction, we rented a full floor on West 44th Street for $3.50 a square foot in the early 80's. Now that would be like $35 a square foot. And this is Hell's Kitchen!"
That moniker, despite all it has come to imply, is of obscure historical origins.
Clinton -- the more official, though less dramatic alternative -- is clearly traceable to two of the community's, indeed New York's, most prominent forefathers: George Clinton, New York's first governor, in 1777, and his nephew, DeWitt, who served as mayor and later governor. The Clintons owned vast farms by the river.
"It wasn't until the 1880's that this was called Hell's Kitchen," said Mary Brendle, the official district historian. But where the name came from remains a mystery.
One tale tells of a midsummer's utterance by a constable on patrol, that the place was "as hot as hell's kitchen."
But it may have been, Ms. Brendle said, The New York Times -- in a Sept. 22, 1881, story headlined, "A Notorious Locality" -- that labeled, or libeled, the neighborhood. Ms. Brendle says the article, describing "a collection of buildings of the same unprepossessing appearance known to the police as 'Hell's Kitchen,' " is the first printed use of the term she has found. The story calls the area "the lowest and filthiest in the city."
To be sure, the neighborhood has had its bad guys. "Through the 1870's, the Gophers gang ruled the whole West Side," Ms. Brendle said. "They stole from the railroad cars, the docks." And there was an 1880's spinoff of the Gophers, the Hell's Kitchen Gang, which that same Times article cited as the city's "most desperate ruffians." (As late as the 1980's, the neighborhood was plagued by a murderous gang, the Westies, linked to the Gambino crime family.)
BUT by and large, with the farms gone and Manhattan's street grid inscribed (under the governance of DeWitt Clinton), the community embraced an expanding populace of blue-collar families dependent on the newly arriving industries -- the breweries, the dairies, the rail yards, the docks, the soap factories and the slaughterhouses -- all within walking distance of their homes.
"Thirty-ninth Street was slaughterhouses," Ms. Brendle said. "They had the cattle pens on the roof, the ramps. They'd bring them across the river on barges, or by train, and drive them through the streets."
By the turn of the last century, the community was also becoming the city's reservoir for servants, cleaning people, hotel and restaurant workers, Broadway ushers, stagehands and set builders. And, as a melting pot of nationalities, it remains so to this day. According to the 2000 census, 45,700 people live in Clinton.
It was in the mid-1800's, with the farmlands fading, that housing for all those workers would shift from three-story wood-frame dwellings to tenements -- considered a significant step up during those times.
And it is those stolid brick structures, rundown though many of them are, that community leaders fear will disappear.
"We are extremely concerned about the expansion of high-rise buildings bordering and struggling to enter the Hell's Kitchen-Clinton neighborhood," said Ms. Sindin, the community board chairwoman.
In 1974, the city created a Special Clinton District, from 41st to 59th Street between Eighth Avenue and the river, in which midblock buildings cannot rise higher than seven stories or 66 feet, whichever is less. On the corners, however, buildings may climb as high as the underlying zoning allows.
"They aren't as tall as the 42nd Street stuff," Ms. Sindin said, "but tall enough to tower over the neighborhood. We've always tried to keep Clinton a low-density village-type area, but so much is coming that it's too much for one afternoon's typing."
What Leni Schwendinger, president of the Hell's Kitchen Neighborhood Association, worries about is the city's long-term vision for the area south of 42nd Street. "We do not look forward to office development," Ms. Schwendinger said. "We do not think that our neighborhood should be an extension of the Midtown business district."
Mr. Fisher of the Clinton coalition said: "All this stuff puts pressure on neighborhood people. Landlords are clearing out tenants. A building on West 51st, 26 tenants got hit with court papers in one day."
"How is the city going to provide for the electricity, the traffic, water, solid waste and sewage?" Mr. Fisher wondered. "It's going to catch up with us."
And there are businesses at risk. "There's photographers, sign makers, small companies that provide services to the office towers in the real Midtown," Mr. Fisher said. "Where do the delivery trucks gas up? When the auto shops are gone, where are you going to put them? In New Jersey?"
Joe Restuccia has been working for years to strike a balance in the community. Mr. Restuccia is director of the Clinton Housing Development Company, a nonprofit group founded in 1973 by neighborhood volunteers to preserve affordable housing in the special preservation district. "The big struggle was to prove that tenements could be renovated instead of demolished," he said. "This was the 70's when the idea was to knock it all down and start all over again."
Housing in the neighborhood is almost entirely tenements -- railroad flats with tubs in the kitchen and toilets in the hall. "The challenge is to take a building like that and modernize it, installing kitchens, private bedrooms, a toilet with a door." Mr. Restuccia said. "This was like a major achievement -- a toilet with a door!"
So far, the company has renovated 72 buildings with 900 apartments using $78 million in public and private funds. About 60 percent of the buildings had been held by the city for tax arrears; the rest were renovated by private investment with low-income housing tax credits.
And that is how the Clinton company has worked with some of the developers of those rising towers -- all of whom are building what are called 80-20 projects.
For those projects, either the city or the state issues bonds to finance low-rate mortgages. In exchange, the developers must set aside 20 percent of their apartments for people earning between 40 and 60 percent of the metropolitan area's median income. The affordable apartments must be equally distributed throughout the building and match the distribution of apartment sizes.
In another type of exchange, as with the Victory on 10th Avenue, developers can receive extra square footage or building height if they either construct or renovate affordable apartments on site or off site, over and above the 20 percent already set aside. Just such an exchange is taking place on the east side of Ninth Avenue between 42nd and 43rd Streets. 
There, where for decades the Gardini family pharmacy stood, the Brodsky Organization is pouring foundations for an 80-20 building that wraps around a row of four-story midblock tenements.
W HAT we're putting up," said Daniel Brodsky, the company's president, "is a 10-story building on 43rd connected to a 23-story building at the corner of 42nd, for a grand total of 256 apartments." But to maintain the height of the midblock tenements, part of the 43rd Street section of the new building will be only four stories. With occupancy expected in the 10-story section early next year, rents for studios will start at about $1,700, one-bedrooms at $2,200 and two-bedrooms at $3,500.
The low-income apartments, however, will be off-site. And that is where Mr. Restuccia comes in. "They have worked with us to renovate a building at 501 West 52nd Street," Mr. Restuccia said. "It was four tenements with 27 units -- the kind with tubs in the kitchen -- that the city took over for urban renewal in 1969."
The four tenements are being combined into one elevator building with standard apartments. And the 12 long-term tenants relocated during construction will return, with the remaining apartments rented to low-income neighborhood residents.
"The secret of this stuff is that when it works, it really works," Mr. Restuccia said. "When the private developer is interested in engaging with the community in a creative way, the developer gets a benefit, the community gets a benefit and low-income neighborhood residents get a better place to live. This is not about marching with banners; this is sitting at the table and working it out."

HEADLINE: Prosperity Beckons 

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: ELIZABETH 

 BODY:
JUDGING by the pancake index, this historic port city with a historically uneven reputation seems to be stacking up surprisingly well.
 Michele Kenny, the owner of the International House of Pancakes on North Broad Street, the closest thing to a diner near this city's gritty, bustling center, said the IHOP's sales volume has risen to a hefty $40,000 a week from about $6,000 when she bought the franchise 10 years ago. 
 On a recent weekday morning, the restaurant's sunny dining room radiated optimism as the plates, forks and knives of men in suits, mothers with children and other Elizabethans, as residents here are known, harmonized in a clanging chorus of prosperity.
"Actually, it was 20 years ago, and Elizabeth was not doing well, and it was a company-owned franchise and IHOP wanted to get rid of it," said Ms. Kenny, 49, who was working as a waitress in Union when she and the chef there pooled their assets. "Elizabeth has changed a lot since then. In the last 10 years, a lot of business has returned." 
By land, sea and air, in fact.
With more than 110,000 residents, Elizabeth, the seat of Union County, is the state's fourth-largest city after Newark, Jersey City and Paterson -- and one of its most dynamic. From the giant retail outlets that have sprouted from barren brownfields along the New Jersey Turnpike to the new hotels near the increasingly busy Newark International Airport to the rows of townhouses that have replaced decaying apartments for many of the city's lower-income residents, Elizabeth has undergone no small transformation over the past decade. 
"We're the best-kept secret in the state," said Dan Sullivan, executive director of the Elizabeth Development Corporation, a native of Elizabeth and a former school board member who is now a freeholder.
Indeed, it is having trouble getting attention for itself as cities like Newark -- enjoying a self-proclaimed renaissance with its New Jersey Performing Arts Center, baseball stadium and restoration of some of the city's stately skyscrapers -- garner most of the attention. Jersey City is repeatedly trumpeted as the state's financial capital and leader in job growth, and has become virtually synonymous with the term "waterfront boom." Even Paterson -- despite its stagnation -- manages to stay in the spotlight, or perhaps searchlight is more accurate, if only through its struggle with characteristically urban problems of poverty, unemployment, corruption and violence.
But while Elizabeth has been booming -- averaging $45 million a year in new construction over the past five years -- it has attracted little attention. What outsiders do tend to hear about Elizabeth from the occasional news release issued by the Union County prosecutor's office -- an investigation into municipal corruption; a doctor is shot dead in a hotel parking lot; a youth football coach is accused of molesting his players -- reinforces negative stereotypes.
"I have a friend who said to me, 'Aren't you afraid to live in Elizabeth?' " said Christine Lalevee, 48, who moved to Elizabeth with her husband in 1985, and lives along a park near the city's western border with Carteret. "It's not like that."
Ms. Lalevee, a part-time office worker for the American Heart Association, said: "When I came here, there used to be a lot of cars stolen in this area. Now I don't see that."
Neither do the police. In keeping with state and national trends, reported crime has significantly fallen in Elizabeth in recent years.

Improved Schools Hold the Key
But for all of the city's improvements and potential, even its biggest boosters say long-term prosperity depends on a struggling public school system that while showing signs of improvement, continues to perform well below the state as a whole.
"The biggest concern, and one that really could be a major inhibitor to economic growth of the town is the underperformance of the school district," said State Senator Raymond J. Lesniak, a Democrat who was born and raised in Elizabeth. "When people look to relocate in a town, whether it's a business or a family, they look for quality of life, they look for economic opportunity, they look at the school system.'
With about 15,000 students, it is the fourth largest system in the state, and with the districts in Newark, Jersey City and Paterson all under state control, Elizabeth has, in a sense, New Jersey's largest independent district. It is also among the state's 30 Abbott districts -- poor urban districts that take their name from the New Jersey State Supreme Court cases, Abbott v. Burke.
Being an Abbott district does qualify Elizabeth for additional state aid for operations, pre-kindergarten classes and facilities, but the extra aid has been slow in coming.
On the High School Proficiency Test administered to 11th graders, 58.2 percent of Elizabeth High School students passed the reading portion in 2000, the most recent year for which statistics were available. Math was no better, at 56.6 percen, while 78.1 percent passed the writing portion. (Typically, a much higher percentage of students statewide pass the writing portion, which is easier than the math and reading parts.) The scores were an improvement over 1999, but still lagged behind the rest of the county.
In the most immediate sense, the disparities worry residents like Christine Lalevee and her husband, Wayne, who moved to Elizabeth in 1985, and now have an 8-year-old son, Luc, in the district. 
"I don't know if I would buy a house in Elizabeth," said Mr. Lalevee, 41, a former Honda service manager who now receives federal disability benefits because of a chronic back injury.
It is Luc's current school, Westminster Academy, that keeps the Lalevees in Elizabeth. Westminster, where Mr. Lalevee is president of the Parent-Teacher Association, is a magnet school for kindergarten through sixth grade in a new building, with sunshine streaming in, space, and enthusiasm among students, staff and parents.
"What keeps us here?" Mr. Lalavee asked. "His school. If he had to go to Hamilton? I don't have the money to put him in a Catholic School, so we would be out of here."
Whatever divide there may be between the city's economic strides and the perceptions of its school district is mirrored by a schism -- a blood feud, if you will -- between City Hall and the Board of Education. The district's harshest critics include Mr. Sullivan, Mr. Lesniak, and Mayor J. Christian Bollwage. What those men also have in common is their opposition in the early 1990's to the city's legendary former mayor, Thomas G. Dunn Sr., a Democratic powerbroker who reigned for 28 years.
With the support of fellow members of a younger generation who eventually became frustrated with, among other things, Mr. Dunn's refusal to cede power, Mr. Bollwage finally unseated him in the primary in 1992 before going on to win the general election.
Although Mayor Dunn died in 1998, his name lives on, literally, at the Board of Education. Elizabeth's superintendent of schools is none other than the mayor's son, Thomas G. Dunn Jr., who was elected by the board in 1991 while his father was mayor. But even after Mayor Dunn's defeat, his son remained at the district's helm.
A common criticism directed by Mayor Bollwage, Senator Lesniak and others toward the superintendent and his supporters is that they have exploited the district as political patronage mill the same way Mayor Dunn doled out municipal jobs and contracts to help him in City Hall. The most prominent example they cite is the appointment of a former physical education teacher and athletic supervisor, Michael Scarpato, as principal of Elizabeth High School in 1999 after successfully managing the campaign of four school board candidates.
For his part, Mr. Dunn rejected the criticism and defended Mr. Scarpato as a qualified candidate whose appointment may have raised eyebrows, but was sound educationally. In terms of test scores, Mr. Scarpeto's appointment did not seem to hurt the high school, where in statewide testing reading and math improved in 2000, the year after he became principal.
Mr. Dunn's supporters outside the district include the New Jersey Association of School Administrators, which named him superintendent of the year for 2001-2002 after he implemented districtwide standards in an effort to achieve consistency in the quality and nature of instruction.
He is also defended by David Sciarra, executive director of the Education Law Center in Newark, which has represented students from the Abbott districts -- including the latest, most expensive and slowest to be implemented: a 1998 order by the State Supreme Court that the state pay for school repairs and new construction. Elizabeth has not built a single new school but, Mr. Sciarra noted, neither has any other Abbott district.
"It's not out of incompetence on Tom Dunn's part," said Mr. Sciarra. "He has his strengths and his weaknesses, like all these superintendents do. No new schools have been started anywhere, no major renovation projects have been started anywhere."
Glenn Tillou, the Union County superintendent of schools, said Mr. Dunn faced the same daunting task that every other Abbott superintended did in getting new buildings.
"Where you need to build the schools is where the students are, and where the students are are the most densely developed areas, so site selection becomes very difficult and controversial," said Mr. Tillou. "The Elizabeth school system does do reasonably well. Obviously, their test scores are not as high as we would like them to be, but they have made significant strides."

Superintendent Defends Himself
In his own defense, Mr. Dunn, who now lives in Montclair, said his appointment was not the result of nepotism, and he noted that he had been an assistant superintendent before ascending to the top spot in 1991. But he acknowledged that growing up with a father who had one of the nation's longest runs as mayor probably did help him navigate the city's political and bureaucratic crosscurrents.
"Certainly, it has given me insight into how things work and how things get done," Mr. Dunn said in a recent interview in his office, which is across North Broad Street from the IHOP, where he sometimes eats.
Beyond reports of IHOP's hot cakes selling like, well, hot cakes, construction is perhaps the most conspicuous aspect of Elizabeth's economic revival.
In 1998, during the peak of the city's building boom, new construction totaled about $165 million -- including the vast Jersey Gardens outlet mall -- making it second to only Jersey City. Growth has trailed off somewhat, though but still totaled $73 million last year.
Residential construction, though relatively modest for city the size of Elizabeth, has steadily increased in recent years, and in 2001 was valued at $13,092,200. The residential figure, too, falls short of totals in many other cities, but officials note that much of it involves the city's affordable housing program, which has lined several streets with 130 new townhouses in the Elizabethport neighborhood.
The program, known as Hope VI, which is financed in part by a special 3 percent tax charged by retailers that is part of the city's Urban Enterprise Zone, has put a fresh face on the city across the Arthur Kill from Staten Island, and provides a new sense of comfort and privacy for people like Willie Hill, who last year moved into hius own townhouse from an apartment in a nearby housing project.
"You got your own place," said Mr. Hill, a plain speaking 65-year-old retired factory worker. "It's okay."
The new houses are accompanied by a range of neighborhood programs involving child-care placement, adult education, substance abuse treatment, entrepreneurial, credit and homeownership counseling, and job training for residents to work for Hope VI contractors. Like an infant version of Newark's thriving Ironbound section, with its vibrant array of Portuguese and Brazilian shops and restaurants, a significant Portuguese community is taking root.
Supporters of Mr. Bollwage credit the mayor with bringing about Elizabeth's revival in part by scouring state and federal grant programs for every dollar of seed money and matching funds available. 
Yet the impetus for Elizabeth's boom might rightly be identified as the opening of the 350,000-square-foot Ikea store across the turnpike from the airport in 1990, which anchors the 100-acre Elizabeth Center that includes a Kids 'R Us store and the Rex-Plex, a giant family recreation mall that also houses a job training center. The effort seems to be working, in that the city's unemployment rate fell to 6.2 percent at the start of this year -- still slightly above e the national figure of 6 percent, but well below the 14.3 percent rate in 1993.
Of course one of the engines of Elizabeth's growth is Newark International Airport, which straddles the Newark-Elizabeth border. The airport, which today handles more volume than either LaGuardia or Kennedy, with 30.5 million passenger having arrived and departed in 2001, has fueled development of Elizabeth's hotel corridor along Route 1 and 9. By comparison, Kennedy hyandled 29.4 million passengers and LaGuardia 21.9 million. Moreover, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is planning an expansion that will add another 10 million passengers a year by 2010.
In addition, five new hotels are about to open or under construction: the Mariott Courtyard, the Mariott Residence Inn, American Extended Stay Hotel, Holiday Inn Crown Plaza, and the Carlton Country Inn and Suites.
"This market has been strong for an awfully long time," said David W. Rossman, general manager of the Wyndam Newark Airport, a hotel that opened this year on Route 1 and 9 in Elizabeth. "And with the $3 billion that the Port Authority has invested in this airport, it's going to be a strong markert for a while."
It was just after the Wyndham's ceremonial opening in January that Mayor Bollwage gave his annual state-of-the city address to the Greater Elizabeth Chamber of Commerce. "The state of the city is strong," he told an enthusiastic audience of about 400 business people, a record crowd for the annual event. 
At this point, Elizabeth's most potent symbol of renewal is the 1.3 million-square-foot Jersey Gardens outlet mall, which opened in October 1999 after being built atop an old municipal landfill and was heralded as one of the state's most successful projects in terms of making use of a contaminated property that was cleaned up. The 200-store mall, with its wide-open, exposed-beam construction that resembles the immense jet hangers across the turnpike, drew more than 15 million visitors in 2001, and increased sales 8 percent, according to city figures. The mall, off Exit 13A of the turnpike, provides 5,000 jobs and $6.5 million in annual city revenue.
After buying a Brooks Brothers blazer or pair of Tommy Hilfiger jeans -- or almost any conceivable item of clothing in between -- Elizabethans and others can now take in a movie at the 20-screen Loews Theater cineplex that opened next to Jersey Gardens last August.

Light Rail Is on the Way
Soon, those shoppers, employees, airline passengers and residents will be able to get around more easily with a two-part light rail system now under construction. The first segment will be an 8.8-mile stretch linking downtown Newark and Elizabeth with the airport. The second part will be a 5.8-mile stretch extending from downtown Elizabeth to an area along Newark Bay that is being developed as a huge, mixed use complex known as Bridgeview Center for its view of the Bayonne Bridge. The area will also have its own ferry service to Manhattan later this year. 
Bridgeview, which is being developed by a company known as OENJ-Cherokee of Bayonne, is proposed as a three-building, 700,000-square-foot office complex with an estimated cost of $140 million, with its ultimate completion dependent on the demand for office space. Bridgeview -- significant not only in its scale but also because it is the city's first major office project in decades -- will share the 182-acre site of the reclaimed landfill with Jersey Gardens. 
Ultimately, officials agree, economic development and improvement in school performance goes hand-in-hand. But there is a chicken-and-egg question over which comes first: good schools that draw residents, keep them there and produce a well-educated, quality workforce that retains old businesses and attracts new ones; or economic development that fuels the tax rolls, enabling the district to hire more teachers and build new schools, ultimately producing better students. 
"I think there is a mutual concern among the business community and school districts concerning the training and education of the workforce," said Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association.
"Businesses will want a well trained work-force, so that is a component of economic development," Mr. Belluscio said. "The thing about development, it builds up the tax base, which makes it easier for the district to raise money."

HEADLINE: The View From Weehawken and Other Mayoral Campaign Issues 

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: WEEHAWKEN 

 BODY:
UNLIKE its fast-growing neighbors, little has changed in this riverfront town in the past decade, including the nameplate on the mayor's desk. Richard Turner has been running things here -- pretty much as he wants, some say -- for the last 12 years.
 For Laura Ledesma -- an 18-year-old naturalized citizen who will be voting for the first time on Tuesday -- it is time for a change. 
 "I'm voting for the new team, actually," said Ms. Ledesma, referring to a slate of challengers who call themselves Weehawken Initiative Now, or WIN. "I don't know, it's been the same people over and over. The mayor has done a great job, you can't deny that. But I want to try something new." 
It was 12 years ago that Mr. Turner led his first slate of five candidates for Weehawken Township Council to victory, and that slate in turn chose him to serve as mayor for a four-year term, a process repeated in 1994 and 1998.
And although the mayor and his current running mates -- all part of the Weehawken and You team -- boast about how crime has gone down, taxes have been stable and property values and the quality of life have gone up, the 52-year-old Mr. Turner is nonetheless facing his most aggressive electoral challenge.
The most obvious measure of opposition to the mayor's reign is the fact that this is the first time his team is being challenged by a full slate of five candidates who question the mayor's commitment to residents as opposed to wasterfront developers as well as to open goverment.
Benjamin A. Goldman, challenger for an at-large seat who has lived here for six years, said: "I've worked for communities my entire adult life, and I've fought for people who have been underrepresented, and for access to information about what government is doing and what communities need, all of which would be of benefit to a place like Weehawken, which on the one hand is a small town, and on the other faces some of the most complex issues of any community in the world."
The 41-year-old Mr. Goldman, who opposed the project, has written about the environment and other policy issues, and served on President Clinton's Council on Sustainable Development.
The slate of challengers has accused Mr. Turner of being an autocratic, secretive ruler. Moreover, they have questioned how the incumbents in a town of 12,000 have raised about a quarter of a million dollars, largely from out-of-town businesses, including engineering firms, law firms and other development-related companies.
"I think they're bought and paid for, and I think it's why their decisions have not represented the interests of our local citizens," Mr. Goldman said.
For their part, the incumbents rejected those assertions. They minimized dissent, they said, by ironing out differences at work sessions. And they questioned how the challengers could make an issue of how business was conducted, assereting that they had attended few council meetings.
Mr. Turner said that in terms of campaign funds, the challengers were lumping $143,000 in donations over the past three years to the Weehawken and You Civic Association, a charitable group, with $98,000 in recent contributions to the Weehawken and You Campaign Fund.
Weehawken, where Aaron Burr mortally wounded Alexander Hamilton in their duel on the banks of the Hudson, does not have the PATH service or night life of Hoboken, its trendier neighbor to the south. But it is home to the Lincoln Tunnel and New Jersey Transit's 181 bus, making it a logical choice for commuters with families, especially since its schools have improved over the past decade. And there is the unobstructed view of Midtown Manhattan across the Hudson.
To be sure, the mayor has his supporters, even among relative newcomers. Daniel S. Cieri, who moved here four years ago from Union City, said he had been impressed by Mr. Turner's success in turning around a public school system.
"I have a little boy in first grade, and I am proud to be living in a town that takes such pride in its schools," said Mr. Cieri, 60, who is co-owner of a fitness center in Palisades Park. 
As for the mayor, Mr. Cerci added: "He's so approachable, and he's easy to get to know.
And to upset the equation a bit more, even some longtime residents are ready for a change.
Virginia Hessmer, a retired executive secretary whose father and grandfather were Weehawken police captains, said she would not vote for Mr. Turner.
Ms Hessmer blamed the the mayor -- unfairly, he insists -- for approval of the controversial Port Imperial South project, a mini-city of 1,632 housing units and more than a million square feet of office space between the Hudson and the the Palisades.
"I changed my mind," Ms. Hessmer said, standing outside her yellow brick apartment building on Park Avenue. "My windows upstairs, I have a beautiful view of New York, and I don't want to lose it.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Michele August, Michael Marotta

 BODY:
Michele August, a daughter of Nancy and Robert August of Whately, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Lawrence Marotta, a son of Nancy and Michael Marotta of Todt Hill, Staten Island. Jerrold Winer, a Massachusetts justice of the peace and the bride's great-uncle, officiated at the Pines Theater in Florence, Mass. 
 Mrs. Marotta, 27, is the manager for corporate sponsorships and special events at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. She graduated from Syracuse University. Her mother is a physical therapist at Cooley Dickinson Hospital Rehabilitation Services in South Deerfield, Mass. Her father owns Nasami Farm, a nursery in Whately. 
 Mr. Marotta, 32, is a vice president in a risk-management group at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the New York investment bank. He graduated from the University of Notre Dame and received a master's degree in political economy from New York University. His mother is the assistant principal at P.S. 50 in Oakwood, Staten Island. His father, who until 1999 was the principal of Tottenville High School on Staten Island, is an adjunct professor of science at St. John's University in Queens. 
The couple met in June 2000, as they were preparing to jog. As they stood together waiting to cross the West Side Highway at 14th Street, Mr. Marotta grew impatient and began speaking to Ms. August. When the light changed and both began running south, Mr. Marotta asked Ms. August if they could jog together.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Seeing Reasons To Believe In Technology

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
IT has been more than two years since air started leaking, then rushing, out of the technology balloon. 
 The Nasdaq 100 index has fallen nearly 75 percent from its peak in March 2000. About 45 percent of the decline has occurred over the last 52 weeks. Since the start of 2002, the index is down more than 20 percent. Yet it is still about 30 percent higher than in early 1998, when it closed at 956.19. 
 Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter and chief investment officer of Murphy New World Mutual Funds, spoke last week about technology stocks' prospects. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. Good news from Cisco Systems last week set off a rally in tech stocks, which then fell back. Are they oversold?

A. They are strongly oversold. We have a record level of Nasdaq short-selling. Nobody wants to own these stocks. Big mutual funds own anything but technology. The Cisco news was not that much -- they said revenue in the July quarter would be up 5 percent, which translates into a 22 percent annual growth rate. But the reaction to that news shows how extremely oversold we were.

Q. Why are you bullish on technology?

A. We are bullish because of the fundamentals. There is more product improvement and generational innovation going on in virtually every area right now than in the 30 years I have been following this business.
Everything from semiconductor equipment to third-generation cellphones to software, which is moving to Internet-based computing, to data storage, which is moving from big disk-drive systems to storage area networks. 

Q. Did technology companies attract too much investment capital in the late 1990's?

A. The problem is that things become obsolete. When a JDS Uniphase writes off $3 billion in inventory, people think they are writing it down. That's wrong. They are taking it to the dump. There was a huge amount of semiconductor equipment installed, but it is now useless. The cost of making an Intel Pentium 4 chip has gone from $100 down to $40. The $100 chip sits idle, and will never get used.
There are 550 million personal computers in the world, and 300 million of them can't run Windows XP. A lot of those PC's were bought in 1999, and their three-year cycle is pretty much up. There are one billion cellphones out there, but the third-generation cellphone is a way better product. 

Q. Is there real demand for new equipment?

A. Well, in the first-quarter gross domestic product numbers, spending on computers was up 38 percent, off a very low base. Auto companies and the government are helping electronics.
There is no question there is huge demand for data storage. Over the next three years, we will store more information than in the last 3,000. But storage companies sell big systems that cost as much as $1 million each. Even if the chief information officer at a company wants to spend that kind of money, the chief executive doesn't. The chief executive wants to make sure the company is really out of recession. At some point this summer we think spending for those sorts of things will be emerging. 

Q. Which two tech stocks you would sell now?

A. We advocated selling Lucent and Nortel. We don't think Lucent has its act together to come back. It's not too late to sell. Nortel has been so badly hurt by all this they may have to exit the optics business completely and turn themselves into a wireless company.

Q. Which stocks are you buying?

A. We have been buying Xlinx, which is the clear leader in programmable chips. Nvidia, which is a pretty controversial stock, is a company we know well and is gobbling up lots of features to put into integrated graphics chip sets.
Another is Taiwan Semiconductor, which in a few years will be manufacturing 25 percent of all the semiconductors in the world. During the recession they kept spending money and modernized all their plants. Now they are as good at manufacturing chips as I.B.M. and Intel.

Q. What about the prospects for Intel, Microsoft and Cisco Systems?

A. We are finding it easier to find good big stocks than good small ones. That is a big change that is mostly due to the fact that venture capitalists are not making any new investments. Bigger companies have managed to gain market share, and a lot of their erstwhile competitors have gone away. We have been buying all three of these stocks, and think Intel is the cheapest of the bunch. But with around $10 billion in cash, Cisco is looking like a bank. Microsoft is in the same position.

HEADLINE: Palace Revolt 

BYLINE:  By KATHERINE MARSH 

 BODY:
FROM the moment the new tenant moved into the Apthorp, the majestic turn-of-the-century apartment building on Broadway between 78th and 79th Streets, she was the subject of rumor and gossip, much of it unkind.
 Some tenants dismissed her as nouveaux riche, saying that her over-the-top appearance was at odds with the shabby-chic ethos that has attracted not only solid middle-class tenants but also celebrated figures like Nora Ephron and Cyndi Lauper to the building. Others speculated as to how the newcomer managed to get prime real estate under the main arch at the Apthorp's entrance. Soon, a rumor spread that she had been imported by Nason Gordon, the Apthorp's nonagenarian landlord and one of the building's four managing members, as they are known. 
 The new tenant, a life-size marble nude, arrived in 1998. She is a fitting symbol of the painful transformation under which the 189-apartment Apthorp, one of the city's most celebrated rental buildings, is evolving from comfortable West Side icon to gilded palace for the very, very rich. 
For owners, the statue represents the latest in a long line of improvements designed to attract new, luxury tenants, like investment bankers and chief executives. For many longtime tenants, who feel they are gradually being forced out by sharply increasing rents, the statue epitomizes the pursuit of tasteless luxury at the expense of the building's character, not to mention their own pocketbooks.
A legendary New York residence in the same league as the Dakota and the Ansonia, two other neighborhood grandes dames, the Apthorp houses nearly every subspecies of Upper West Sider from rent-controlled senior to socially conscious psychiatrist to celluloid celebrity to ultrawealthy executive.
With its 3,000-square-foot apartments and airy interior courtyard, the Apthorp embodies the dream of New York living. These days, for some, it also represents the nightmare.
In the last few years, tenants have heard bizarre stories involving jewel thefts and a mysterious dead body. In recent months, with the increasing turnover of tenants, the building has been roiled even more. Afraid of repercussions or protective of their famous names, many tenants refuse to speak on the record. But off the record there is incessant buzzing -- Is it true that Al Pacino just moved into one of the big-ticket apartments, as some tenants have said? -- and the air is heavy with intrigue.
"I've never seen such fear in people," said Boaty Boatwright, the talent agent and social figure who has lived in the building for nearly a quarter of a century.
The most recent event to set tongues wagging was the departure last month of the movie director Nora Ephron and the writer Nick Pileggi, her husband since 1987. "We left because they doubled our rent and then doubled it again," said Ms. Ephron, who moved out of her eight-room apartment after 22 years in the building but is keeping an office there. Ms. Ephron, who has moved to the Upper East Side, filmed part of her 1986 movie "Heartburn" in the Apthorp.
In March, Ms. Ephron's younger sister and creative partner, Delia, a novelist and screenwriter, left the Apthorp -- and the Upper West Side -- after her rent was quadrupled from what it was when she arrived seven years ago.
Other famous figures are fighting to stay -- at often-enviable rents. Cyndi Lauper, the helium-voiced 80's pop star, is suing to get her rent rolled back from $3,250 to $507. Kate Nelligan, the actress, is in State Supreme Court to prevent her rent from soaring much higher. It was $2,570 a month in 2001.

Tenants With Room to Roam
On a recent Tuesday evening, Paul Nickolatos and Michael O'Neal, the chairmen of the Apthorp Tenants Association, gathered a few fellow tenants in Mr. Nickolatos's apartment to discuss plans to fight a proposed rent increase.
The living room of his four-room, rent-stabilized ($1,438-a-month) apartment features 10-foot ceilings, a fireplace and an original 1908 mirror framed by Edwardian molding. But the detail that reveals most about why tenants are fighting so aggressively to stay in the Apthorp is a baby grand piano that had been in the family.
Neither Mr. Nickolatos nor his wife, Katherine Ryden, play a note. They acquired the instrument because, unlike most New Yorkers, who can't stuff another stick of furniture into their tiny apartments, they had space to spare. The Apthorp has that most precious of New York commodities, room.
Last November, the Apthorp's owners, an entity known as 390 West End Associates, applied to the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal for what is known as a Major Capital Improvement (M.C.I.) increase. The aim was to offset $1.8 million the owners had spent replacing the building's 11 elevators.
The two tenant leaders contend that the new elevators -- some spray-painted gold, to many tenants' dismay -- are little better than their predecessors. The real purpose of the increase, they say, is to drive out longtime rent-stabilized residents like themselves to make way for others with deeper pockets. (Under the city's rent laws, if a stabilized rent exceeds $2,000 and the tenant's family income is over $175,000 for two consecutive years, the apartment may be rented at market-value -- luxury -- levels.)
The proposed increase is a modest one -- $25 per room per month. But if it is granted, the tenant leaders say, under the city laws some people will be forced out. To prevent this, the tenants' association has hired a lawyer and an elevator expert.
Mr. Nickolatos complained that while stone lions and urns multiply in the courtyard, longtime tenants continue to grapple with rusty water and outdated wiring.
"The big complaint among tenants is that the M.C.I.'s aren't helping the building, but the landlord," Mr. Nickolatos said. He is particularly critical of Barbara Ross, the building's managing agent. "Ms. Ross has been on a rampage of fixing things up," he said. His wife added, "We're afraid that this is just the beginning."

Upgrading to Woo the Wealthy
One Thursday afternoon around the same time, Ms. Ross and Mr. Gordon met in their cavernous wood-paneled office on the Apthorp's ground floor to demonstrate how they are making the building more enticing to upscale tenants. Except for an enormous mahogany desk that dwarfed both Mr. Gordon and Ms. Ross, the room was empty.
"The room we're in is part of what would be a very elegant dining room," Mr. Gordon said, pulling out a brochure published when the building opened. The brochure wooed turn-of-the-century titans with lavish descriptions of the Apthorp's amenities.
In the last several years, demand for luxury real estate on the Upper West Side grew. Many landlords sought to adapt to the changing neighborhood. For its part, 390 West End Associates spent more than $10 million upgrading the Apthorp to attract the 21st-century version of these original tenants. Improvements include a steam-cleaning of the richly ornamented limestone exterior, a new gatehouse, new navy uniforms with gold buttons and epaulets for the doormen -- "Like captains on a cruise ship," Ms. Ross said -- the new elevators, and renovations of vacant apartments to include amenities like central air-conditioning, new plumbing and wiring, washer-dryers and SubZero refrigerators.
"As we've been renovating, we've gotten more upper-level tenants," said Ms. Ross, who has managed the building for 18 years and whose dressy business attire and ebony beehive are a fixture in the building.
Ms. Ross and Mr. Gordon defend the wooing of affluent tenants, and although they will not say how much it costs to run the building, they defend the rent increases as necessary to do the job. "Owners and landlords are entitled to M.C.I. increases," Mr. Gordon said. "Everyone benefits from the improvement of the building."
Ms. Ross said the elevators had been replaced because they were breaking down. "I don't think we're trying to push anyone out," she added.
She also said the management was quick to address any plumbing or electrical problems, adding, "We have a contractor on the premises, and when a problem is reported, we send them in immediately." 
Many tenants deny this, saying they have reported complaints but found the response sluggish. They also say they do not report major problems because they doubt that any action would be taken.
As freshly outfitted doormen gave over-the-top hellos, Ms. Ross and Mr. Gordon headed upstairs in one of the new gold-painted elevators to conduct a tour of an apartment nearing the end of a nearly yearlong renovation.
Inside the four-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bathroom space, which is on the market for $25,000 a month, a McMansion aesthetic has replaced shabby chic. The space had been fitted with a granite kitchen floor, new plumbing and wiring, and the piece de resistance, a master bathroom with a beige marble Jacuzzi and other fixtures.
"This is the top right now," Ms. Ross said of the apartment.
Back in the courtyard, the pair lingered near the new gatehouse to offer a few more observations about the changes. "Barbara and I have devoted our lives to this building," Mr. Gordon said. "It's not just about making a dollar." What it is also about, he said, is restoring the Apthorp's former glory.
He and Ms. Ross seem particularly proud of the marble nude near the front entrance. "We bought that statue strictly to conform to the building," Mr. Gordon said. But as her fellow tenants suspected, the statue's true provenance reveals a great deal about the world she now inhabits. Contrary to a rumor that had swirled through the building, her last known residence was not a cemetery, as some had suspected, but Sotheby's.

Edwardian Splendor
For almost a century, tenants have been coming to the Apthorp not for statues but for space. To understand the spell of the Apthorp is to understand the passion of Manhattanites packed onto a tiny island for square footage. Built by the Astor family and named after the original owner of the land, the 12-story Renaissance Revival structure was designed as a luxury building at a time that apartment living was considered a lower-class convention.
The reason apartments were built large, up to 12 rooms apiece, was to lure the rich out of their brownstones. The building was completed in 1908. With units the size of houses, the Apthorp occupied an entire city block, and was an instant success.
By the Great Depression, however, even the rich were less inclined to cough up several hundred dollars a month for rent. In the next few decades, as profound social and economic changes swept through the city, many of the Apthorp's largest apartments were sliced in half. Residents left for the suburbs. Single-room-occupancy hotels proliferated on and off Broadway, as did crime.
The ambience of the Upper West Side of the 1960's and 1970's left much to be desired. But many tenants arrived in those years, attracted by spacious if rundown apartments available at rent-controlled and rent-stabilized prices.
Mr. O'Neal, a bearded Hemingway look-alike who, with his family, owns O'Neal's restaurant opposite Lincoln Center, moved to the Apthorp in 1972. Mr. Nickolatos and Ms. Ryden arrived in 1977. Many in this generation of tenants saw themselves as urban pioneers.
"There were hookers and drug dealers everywhere," said Mr. O'Neal's wife, Christine, who remembers the night she heard the screams of a prostitute whose thumb had been bitten off by another prostitute. "There were also a lot of transvestites. You'd wheel your child in a stroller and hope they couldn't see up their skirts."
Manhattan's West Side had traditionally been a world apart from the East Side, in both income level and character. But by the 80's the distinctions began to blur.
Luxury buildings sprouted along Broadway, notably in the West 60's. As the Internet boom helped spark another era of affluence in New York, Wall Street executives and those who in another era would have gravitated to the Upper East Side began to take a fresh look at upper Broadway.
The shift in population has resulted in startling developments, like the appearance of a Coach store on Broadway and 84th Street a few years ago. One effect of the change is that landlords have been able to raise rents to astronomical levels, pricing even the ordinary rich out of the Upper West Side, and out of the Apthorp.
Even before tour buses began stopping at Zabar's, just to the north, and before Victoria's Secret moved in on the hookers, the Apthorp's down-on-its-heels sensibility had attracted creative artists like Lena Horne, Joseph Heller and George Balanchine. In the 1990's, a more celebrity-studded roster that included Ms. Lauper, Ms. Nelligan and the television figures Rosie O'Donnell, Steve Kroft and Conan O'Brien discovered the Apthorp. Limousines near the entrance became an increasingly familiar sight.
Landlords were helped by a 1993 law that let them raise the rents of many rent-controlled and -stabilized apartments. Most tenants who arrived around this time, like Delia Ephron, were offered leases calling for what initially seemed like reasonable market-rate rents of $2,000 to $3,500 a month. But as rents began to climb, some tenants asserted that their apartments had been illegally destabilized.
One such resident was Ms. Lauper. In 1993, she sublet an apartment for $3,250 a month. In 1996, she and her husband, David Thornton, sued the previous tenant, saying that he had never lived in the apartment and therefore could not destabilize it and charge them a market-rate rent. In 2000, she expanded the suit to include the building's owners, on the ground that they were aware of the arrangement, and she demanded a lease specifying a monthly rent of $507, the rate before the rent was destabilized. In February, Justice Marylin G. Diamond of State Supreme Court ruled in her favor. 
Ms. Nelligan has also been squabbling with the building's owners since they took her to court to declare her original 1991 lease void. In an affidavit, Ms. Nelligan asserted that to secure this lease, which included set increases and lifelong renewal rights, she had paid $285,000 in "key money" to a former tenant, and that the Apthorp's owners had known of the deal. Her fear was that under a new lease, the owners could raise her rent as high as they liked.
The owners have declined to comment on both these matters on the ground that legal action is continuing.

The Body on the Roof
As the atmosphere in the building became increasingly bitter, a small group of tenants began compiling documents that, in their view, proved that the building was being mismanaged.
Even tenants who chose not to complain found the wave of rent increases especially galling, because they came in the wake of several sensational crimes. In 1997, a dead body appeared on the roof. The body was later identified as Gabriele Opferman, a German tourist who had died of exposure. A police investigation followed. But as no one in the building admitted to knowing Ms. Opferman, tenants were left worrying about a level of security that allowed a corpse to appear on their roof.
Four years later, the jewel thief struck. On a single day in January 2001, more than $400,000 worth of jewelry was stolen from the apartment of Andrew and Helen Sheinman, and jewelry valued at $60,000 disappeared from the apartment of Paul Nickolatos and his wife.
"I came back from a business trip, and there were 22 policemen in the apartment fingerprinting everything," Mr. Sheinman said. The thief was never arrested. 
Ms. Ross says the owners have done much to allay security concerns. Last year, they hired Kroll Associates, the security consultant, added cameras in elevators and lobbies (which operate but are not monitored round the clock), and require guests to wear a badge and sign in at the gatehouse. But some tenants still feel unprotected. "Is anyone watching?" Mr. Sheinman said of the cameras. "I doubt it."
As residents peer into the future, many predict that the invasion of the superrich will soon be a fait accompli.
"In two or three years' time," Ms. Boatwright said, "this building will be like the Four Seasons in Dallas, full of Enron people."
In some eyes, certain of the new arrivals are still unwelcome.
"The lions, that nude statue, no one wants them there," Delia Ephron said. "It's very nouveau riche-y. I think that management doesn't understand that the building has a heart and soul."

HEADLINE: Admitting To Mixed Feelings About Motherhood 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH HAYT 

 BODY:
SINCE its publication last fall, Naomi Wolf's "Misconceptions: Truth, Lies and the Unexpected on the Journey to Motherhood" has become a staple of baby shower gift baskets. Ms. Wolf, who has made a career of turning her rites of passage into social critiques, details the difficulties of her second pregnancy, the lack of support for new mothers and the toll that parenthood takes on couples. The book, which rejects the conventional, nurturing tone of popular baby advice books, is one of several published recently that challenge the prevailing image of this second Sunday in May -- of motherhood as Hallmark card. 
 After two decades in which boomers managed to make children the raison d'etre not only of their lives but of the culture at large, another version of motherhood is beginning to seep out, with some mothers speaking up -- in the impassioned tones of those breaking a taboo -- about the drudgery of child care, the isolation of the playground and their loss of identity. 
 "Motherhood is supposed to be this gauzy, pastel-painted, blissed-out state that has no depth or complexity," Ms. Wolf said. "That is the socially acceptable picture in the mass market. But women have discovered that the cultural mythology surrounding motherhood has nothing to do with their lives. Women are hungry for the truth. They want to know they're normal when they feel overwhelmed, lonely, isolated or ecstatic." 
In addition to Ms. Wolf's book, others in the genre include "A Life's Work: On Becoming a Mother," a memoir by the novelist Rachel Cusk, who confesses her disgust for breast-feeding and decries the "feudal relation" she slid into with her husband; "Augusta, Gone" by Martha Tod Dudman, an unvarnished memoir of the trials of raising an uncontrollable teenage daughter; and "Life After Birth: What Even Your Friends Won't Tell You" by Kate Figes with Jean Zimmerman, a parenting guide that covers problems like a new mother's inability to feel unconditional love.
"I wanted to write a book because I felt inadequate and alone," Ms. Figes said. "There are these myths that motherhood is natural and instinctive and that mothers bond with their babies immediately." 
The rosy glow surrounding parenthood in contemporary culture dates from the 1980's -- the era of movies like "Baby Boom" (1987) and television series like "Thirtysomething" (1987-91), which sanctified child-rearing as the next step for a generation of middle-class Americans who had spent an extended adolescence indulging themselves. Beginning with the Reagan presidency and gaining momentum after the 1992 election, when Bill Clinton made policies like the Family Leave Act a part of the Democratic platform, "family values" became an overwhelmingly bipartisan issue. Today, Baby Gap ads make child-rearing appear as fashionable and easy as a credit card swipe, and the White House is turning its attention in the coming midterm elections to "Mommy issues." 
At the same time, there are signs of an anti-romantic reappraisal of motherhood. They exist in pop culture, like the most recent season of "Sex and the City," in which Miranda, the lawyer and single-mother-to-be, learning that her baby is to be a boy, responds with a fake smile and a sarcastic, "Oh, great." After giving birth in the final episode, she said dryly, "It feels like a giraffe just entered the room."
Donna Wick and Wendy Ettinger, former college roommates who each have three children, are the co-producers of a documentary called "Bringing Up Baby," which follows six New York professional women through the late stages of pregnancy, birth and two years of child-rearing, laying bare their frustrations and self-doubt. One of the subjects wonders why "just being a mother isn't more fulfilling" and another feels guilty for craving time alone. 
"Why aren't we allowed to talk about hating the park?" said Ms. Wick, 44, who expects their film to be shown on the Oxygen network next year. "You feel alone and think you're crazy. We want women to be able to say it's O.K. to dislike parts of being a mother. It's boring, lonely, not valued and not paid. It's mindless and repetitive and no one ever says to you, 'It looks like you're having a tough day, go for a cup of coffee' like they do at the office." 
A number of mothers -- and potential mothers -- who have read some of the anti-romantic parenting tomes expressed relief. "The idea that there could be some ambivalence about motherhood, to hear that echoed is really important," said Michelle Goldberg, 26, a New York writer, who does not have children. "You always hear about people regretting not having children, but you never hear of any woman saying, 'I regret having children.' "
"There has to be some measure of regret, and you don't have to be Susan Smith," she said, referring to the South Carolina woman who drowned her two sons in 1994.
Although 1970's feminists like Adrienne Rich and Jane Lazarre wrote about their bipolar swings between loving and resenting their children, the family-values momentum of recent decades has swept aside most of the dialogue that is less than pro-natal.
"We've seen a dampening of the feminist discussion of the complexities of adult women's lives, including parenting, which has been simplified down to a 'good mommy/bad mommy' formula," said Suzanna Walters, a professor of sociology at Georgetown University and the mother of a 7-year-old daughter. "The late 60's and 70's were a brief, shining moment when all kinds of unspoken things were spoken, including maternal ambivalence." More recently, she added, "there's been a prohibition against voicing ambivalence about mothering." 
A number of the mothers who have written recently of their conflicted feelings provoked reactions that made them feel they had touched a high-voltage wire.
Ms. Cusk, a novelist who has won Britain's Whitbread award, attracted sharp criticism for "Life's Work" when it was first published in England last year. In her memoir, she longs for the freedom she had before her child was born. "You become an anonymous person as a mother, but to speak as an author from that experience is extremely difficult," Ms. Cusk said. "When my book came out, people had a fit about it. I wasn't prepared for the level of anger. I had to go on TV to defend myself."
The writer Peggy Orenstein witnessed the self-censorship of mothers when she conducted some 200 interviews for her book "Flux: Women on Sex, Work, Love, Kids and Life in a Half-Changed World," which appeared in paperback last August. Although some women seemed relieved to confess that they disliked motherhood and wished they might walk away, immediately after making that admission, they qualified it by saying how much they loved their children and would kill for them. "It was almost furtive for them to admit motherhood is not fulfilling," Ms. Orenstein said. "It actually makes me feel deviant and anti-mother to say that. But I'm not. It's like being anti-American. Motherhood silences women. The kryptonite words for women are fat, slut, bad mother and selfish. The words make us lose our powers just like Superman loses his in the face of kryptonite."
One of the paradoxes of the feminist movement is that after opening the workplace to women, offering them independence and professional fulfillment, it sometimes made child-rearing feel like a letdown. Today, a typical 32-year-old prospective mother has had a 10-year career and has made her own decisions since college. Although motherhood has always entailed sacrifice -- of time, of the ego, of one's sex life -- contemporary mothers are sacrificing more: careers, salaries, status. 
"What women are bringing to the table is confidence, education and work experience," said Ann Crittenden, the author of "The Price of Motherhood: Why the Most Important Job in the World Is Still the Least Valued," which argues that mother's work is economically and socially slighted. "When they become mothers, they discover it's an anachronism. Women are used to being treated equally, and then they have children and they find they're back in the Dark Ages."
Even for those who return to work, a compromise of professional goals often ensues, as suggested by Sylvia Ann Hewlett's recent cause celebre, "Creating a Life: Professional Women and the Quest for Children," which reports that in the "top echelons" of corporate careers, nearly half of the women are childless.
In the face of some women's maternal ambivalence, many others will testify to being blindsided by the power of maternal love, and quickly resetting priorities, sometimes never to return to careers. "I had no conflict about leaving to be a full-time parent," said Darcie Sanders, 49, who quit a job in publishing to have a baby and be a stay-at-home mother in Lyons, Colo., 10 years ago. She is the co-author, with Martha M. Bullen, of "Staying Home: From Full-Time Professional to Full-Time Parent," published in 1992. "I didn't feel like I was sacrificing anything," Ms. Bullen added. "There are aspects of drudgery to it, but for me the benefits so overwhelmingly outweigh those aspects, and anyway, there are aspects of drudgery to any job." 
Danielle Crittenden, 39, a Washington mother of three and the author of "What Our Mothers Didn't Tell Us: Why Happiness Eludes the Modern Woman" of 1999, faulted feminists of the 60's and 70's for devaluing motherhood. 
"I grew up in the 70's with that whole idea that you're supposed to work, and motherhood wouldn't be satisfying and maybe you condemned it," she said. "We've undervalued the satisfaction motherhood can bring. We haven't planned our lives to accommodate our children, and yet having children has proved to be one of the most profound and satisfying experiences of life. We're afraid to give ourselves over to motherhood -- to drop out of the workforce. Motherhood is great and important and something I want to do."
In the end, the subject of maternal ambivalence is not a skirmish in the long-running conflict between working and stay-at-home mothers. Most American women balance careers and families. Sixty-three percent of married women with children under 18 are in the workforce, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
Working or not, all mothers may be relieved to learn that motherhood may not come automatically to anyone after all. Sarah Bleffer Hrdy, an anthropologist at the University of California at Davis, studied primates, including humans, to understand better the biological relationship between mothers and their offspring. Describing her findings in her 1999 book, "Mother Nature: A History of Mothers, Infants and Natural Selection," she said that mothers are not innately selfless beings but learn to care for their babies over time. In addition, a mother's own well-being may conflict with nurturing her baby.
"It's instructive for women to understand that ambivalence isn't something to feel guilty and ashamed about," Ms. Hrdy said. "Striving for social status, which today comes from work or earning power, and relying on others for help are integral to motherhood in the human species."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS; 
Cathedral Needs Alms In the Wake of Calamity

BYLINE:  By KELLY CROW 

 BODY:
In the first half of the 1900's, the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine was busy seeking money to build its north transept, a stretch of arched offices and alcoves off the main sanctuary. One idea of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the longtime chairman of the fund-raising committee, was to place a 12-foot-long plaster model of the cathedral within the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal. 
 The ploy worked, and awed train commuters donated heavily to the project. 
 Last week, Jere T. Farrah, the cathedral's executive vice president of development, shook his head as he eyed the crumbling remains of the model, now sitting in a charred corner of the north transept, which was ravaged by fire five months ago. The transept, now open to the sky and dotted with warped steel bookcases and debris, had been the cathedral gift shop. The model was its centerpiece.
"You think this building is indestructible, and then you see what three hours of fire can do," Mr. Farrah said, as he gingerly picked up a singed postcard from the sooty floor. "Maybe more people should see it."
If they did, they might understand why the cathedral is in such financial trouble since the fire of Dec. 18, which was started by a short circuit. 
The church resumed normal activity within weeks of the fire, and insurance will probably cover most of the costs of reconstruction. The cathedral's social and arts programs have continued because they are supported by outside grants.
But the gift shop had been expected to make $1 million last year, mostly during Christmastime. The take fell well short of that figure. A smaller shop, expected to open in June in another part of the church, is unlikely to recoup those losses. Two Christmas concerts had to be reduced in size and relocated after the fire, which meant a $100,000 loss in ticket sales. Tourism, already slumping from the recession, stopped for several months. So did group tours of the cathedral, which once brought in at least $500 a week.
People have contributed $400,000 since the fire, but the church still has a $400,000 budget deficit. The fiscal year ends June 30.
Mr. Farrah and others are also looking to the Rev. James A. Kowalski, the new dean of the long-unfinished cathedral, to help stem the money troubles. There are few easy solutions.
"There's a lot of pressure right now, and I knew that coming in," Father Kowalski said last week. "But what I keep telling people is that major construction hasn't happened around here since Pearl Harbor. So, my hope is that with all the attention and fear of losing the cathedral to the fire, we can go further." KELLY CROW
