HEADLINE: Sequels? Sure. But Godard, Too. 

BYLINE:  By ANITA GATES

 BODY:
THE Jedi knights are back. So are the under-age spies, the small-town serial killer, the talking mouse, the mod 60's agent with bad teeth and a pair of men who look great in black. Otherwise it looks like a catchall season, maybe because so much has happened since Americans last settled in for something as frivolous as a new batch of summer movies.
 There are films based on works by Melville, Wilde and Capote and just as many that began as Saturday-morning cartoon shows, Web-site series and theme-park attractions. In one unfortunate town, residents are being attacked by giant spiders; elsewhere, a young man in a red spider suit is attacking evildoers. 
 Godard, Rohmer, Chabrol and Zhang Yimou have new films, as do the American auteurs Steven Spielberg, Woody Allen, Steven Soderbergh and John Sayles. Some actors are playing at least slightly against character: Gwyneth Paltrow doing literary research, Tom Hanks getting tough as a hit man, Matthew McConaughey slaying dragons. Tom Cruise, Mel Gibson and Eddie Murphy are doing science fiction. And in a romantic triangle in which the wife is having an affair with a younger man, Richard Gere is playing the husband. 
Here are 145 or so of the films in our near future, with opening dates, as usual, very likely to change -- and change again. Hope you like sequels.

June

KAATERSKILL FALLS: "Knife in the Water" moves to the Catskills. In this low-budget, Americanized version of Roman Polanski's 1962 thriller, a Manhattan couple heading out on a country weekend pick up a young hitchhiker who ends up spending the night with them. The three are soon faced with a harrowing moral quandary. Josh Apter and Peter Olsen directed. June 5.

BAD COMPANY: One black, one white, both cops or private eyes or secret agents. Hollywood has found that a sure-fire box office formula in the last few years. But who would have thought that the next team would be Chris Rock and Anthony Hopkins? Mr. Rock plays a streetwise hustler whose twin brother, a C.I.A. agent with a different kind of savvy, has been killed. Sir Anthony is the veteran agent who has to train the hustler to take his brother's place, fast. A comedy directed by Joel Schumacher, who worked with another crime-fighting team in "Batman and Robin." June 7.

CHERISH: A thriller about romantic obsession, starring Robin Tunney as a love-starved animator. Put under house arrest (wrongly charged with a hit-and-run), she listens to entirely too much gooey 70's and 80's radio. What else is there to do? Fall in love with her parole officer (Tim Blake Nelson)? With Jason Priestley and Lindsay Crouse. Directed by Finn Taylor, who wrote the dreadful "Pontiac Moon." June 7.

DIVINE SECRETS OF THE YA-YA SISTERHOOD: Mothers and daughters don't always get along, but relatively few daughters actually get disowned. Ellen Burstyn and Sandra Bullock play Vivi and Siddalee, a less-than-friendly pair, in the film adaptation of Rebecca Wells's best seller. Callie Khouri, who made her reputation with the screenplay of "Thelma and Louise" 11 years ago, turns to the world of women's friendships again. She directed and wrote the screenplay with Mark Andrus, who also wrote "As Good as It Gets." Ms. Bullock's character is a Louisiana-born actress whose eccentric mother won't speak to her. The Ya-Yas are the mother and her best friends since youth (Shirley Knight, Maggie Smith and Fionnula Flanagan), who always enjoyed being bad girls. Now they're determined to help Vivi and Siddalee make peace. The cast also includes Ashley Judd (as young Vivi), James Garner and Cherry Jones. June 7.

THE FAST RUNNER (ATANARJUAT): Probably the only movie you'll see in Inuktitut this year. In fact, this fable from another millennium is the first feature film ever made by the Inuit people of northern Canada. The story, based on local legend, is a romantic triangle with a simple moral: it's never a good idea to fall in love with the fiancee of the chief's son. It received the award for best first feature at the Cannes Film Festival and the award for best Canadian film at the Toronto festival. A. O. Scott of The New York Times pronounced it a masterpiece when it appeared at the New Directors/New Films series earlier this year. With Sylvia Ivalu, Natar Ungalaaq and Peter-Henry Arnratsiaq. Directed by Zacharias Kunuk. June 7.

HARVARD MAN: A campus drama about one student (Adrian Grenier) who partakes of sex, drugs, gambling and, to some degree, higher learning. On the love-life front, there's a beautiful mobster's daughter and a beautiful philosophy professor. With Sarah Michelle Gellar, Joey Lauren Adams and Eric Stoltz. Directed by James Toback, who directed "Two Girls and a Guy" and wrote "Bugsy." June 7.

IVANS X.T.C.: Danny Huston -- son of John, grandson of Walter and brother of Anjelica -- stars as Ivan Beckman, a Hollywood version of Tolstoy's Ivan Ilyich. Ivan, a very hot talent agent, is dead at the beginning of the film, which proceeds to show us how it all happened. Drugs, debauchery, a terminal illness and his gun-loving, woman-hating, gay-bashing best client (Peter Weller) play major roles. With Tiffani Thiessen, Valeria Golino and the Muppet heir Lisa Henson. Directed by Bernard Rose. June 7.

MAMA AFRICA: A documentary about young women coming of age in urban Africa. From three African directors, the film is introduced by Queen Latifah. June 7.

CUBA FELIZ: A documentary about a 76-year-old Cuban street singer, Miguel del Morales, on a road tour with his guitar. In Spanish with English subtitles. Directed by Karim Dridi. June 12.

THE BOURNE IDENTITY: Richard Chamberlain starred in a television movie version of Robert Ludlum's novel. Now Matt Damon takes on the role of Jason Bourne, a master spy who has amnesia and so has no idea why hired killers are after him. But Bourne is pretty sure he's not a bank clerk, after he notices how good he seems to be at languages and self-defense. With Julia Stiles, Chris Cooper and Franka Potente. Directed by Doug Liman, who brought an impressive energy to his earlier efforts, "Swingers" and the lovable "Go." June 14.

CINEMA PARADISO: This is not your standard rerelease. This director's cut of 1990's Oscar winner for best foreign picture is now half an hour longer than the original. Philippe Noiret and Jacques Perrin are the stars of Giuseppe Tornatore's memory film about a director who goes back to the Sicilian village where he grew up and recalls how, as a boy, he fell in love with the movies. In Italian, with English subtitles. June 14.

THE DANGEROUS LIVES OF ALTAR BOYS: Back in the 1970's, what would two eighth graders in a Southern parochial school have done if they were dying of boredom? In this film, directed by Peter Care, they create a violent, sacrilegious comic book, a project that does not please their teachers, who include Jodie Foster as a nun with a wooden leg. Kieran Culkin and Emile Hirsch play the boys. The cast also includes Vincent D'Onofrio and Jena Malone. The film, based on Chris Fuhrman's novel, includes 12 minutes of animation. Of course the title, which was probably meant to be playful, takes on all kinds of unintended meaning now. June 14.

GANGSTER NO. 1: Malcolm McDowell, David Thewlis and Paul Bettany in a psychological portrait of a British career criminal and the new man who wants to be just like him. The film covers 30 years in their relationship and culminates in a major battle of wills. Directed by Paul McGuigan, who did "The Acid House." June 14.

THE GREEN DRAGON: A drama about Vietnamese refugees in California. From Timothy Linh Bui (who was co-writer of "Three Seasons," directed by Tony Bui, his brother), a story of cross-cultural friendships at Camp Pendleton. With Forest Whitaker, Patrick Swayze, Trung Nguyen, Jennifer Tran and Don Duong. June 14.

THE EMPEROR'S NEW CLOTHES: It's a romantic comedy about Napoleon, not Hans Christian Andersen's inadvertent nudist. Ian Holm (whose most recent role was Bilbo Baggins in "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring") plays two characters, Napoleon Bonaparte and the look-alike sailor who takes his place in exile. In this scenario, based on Simon Levy's novel "The Death of Napoleon," the great Bonaparte secretly sneaks back into Paris with a group of loyalists. The plan, of course, is to return him to the throne. (Although Napoleon was fed up with a lot about exile anyway. "Six years of English cooking!" he announces in horror.) But then he meets a woman: a melon seller called Pumpkin (Iben Hjejle, who was John Cusack's girlfriend in "High Fidelity"). Directed by Alan Taylor. June 14.

LOVE AND A BULLET: A drama about a hit man rethinking his career choice, especially after he's instructed to kill his boss's innocent girlfriend. The hit man is played by Treach, a k a Anthony Criss, from the rap group Naughty by Nature. And he's sure to be involved in a showdown. Directed by Ben Ramsey and Michael McCants. June 14. A related article is on Page 22 of Summer Movies.

THE NEXT BEST THING: Chris Eigeman in a satiric comedy about the New York art world. Mr. Eigeman is a starving artist who has a painting stolen, which the thief (Jamie Harris) makes famous but attributes to an imaginary artist. With Connie Britten and Farley Granger. Written and directed by P. J. Posner. Not to be confused with John Schlesinger's 2000 film "The Next Best Thing," in which Madonna and Rupert Everett have a one-night stand and a baby. June 14.

SCOOBY-DOO: Scooby hit television in 1969, a cartoon Great Dane with a decided aversion to anything scary. Yet he and his gang continue to solve crimes, all of them nonviolent. In Raja Gosnell's live-action film, Scooby is computer-generated and everyone else is live. Freddie Prinze Jr. plays the clear-thinking Fred, who has inexplicably been wearing an ascot since the 60's. Sarah Michelle Gellar is Daphne, who wears go-go boots, even now. Linda Cardelini is Velma, the intellectual of the group. And Matthew Lillard is Shaggy, who lives permanently in panic mode. Fred is in the haunting-debunking business, and Rowan Atkinson is his latest client. June 14. A related article is on Page 15 of Summer Movies.

SECRET SOCIETY: A British-German comedy about a fat factory worker (Charlotte Brittain) who becomes a sumo wrestler. Her unemployed husband (Lee Ross) has always loved the way she looks. Directed by Imogen Kimmel. June 14.

WINDTALKERS: Nicolas Cage stars in John Woo's World War II drama about the American military's use of the Navajo language as code. Mr. Cage's character, a marine, is assigned to protect a particular "code talker" (Adam Beach, who starred in "Squanto: A Warrior's Tale" and whose other 2002 project, oddly enough, is "Skinwalkers"). The tough part about this arrangement is that if a code talker is about to be taken prisoner, it's his protector's job to kill him first. Christian Slater, Frances O'Connor and Mark Ruffalo are also in the cast. Mr. Woo, of course, is no stranger to suspense or violence ("Mission: Impossible 2," "Face/Off"). June 14.

NOT NUDE THOUGH: A PORTRAIT OF RUDY BURKHARDT: The life and work of Burkhardt, the postwar photographer, filmmaker and painter. A documentary directed by Doris Kornish. June 19.

WAR PHOTOGRAPHER: An Oscar-nominated Swiss documentary about James Nachtway, who has covered wars around the globe for two decades. What makes him notable, Christian Frei, the filmmaker says, is that he's not a hardened cynic. "The worst thing is to feel that as a photographer I am benefiting from someone else's tragedy," Mr. Nachtway has said. "This idea haunts me." Filming locations include Kosovo, Ramallah and Jakarta. June 19.

JUWANNA MAN: A bad-boy basketball player gets kicked out of the pros, so he dresses like a woman in order to join the women's league. And it works. But like Dustin Hoffman's Tootsie before him, he falls in love with a beautiful colleague. Miguel A. Nunez Jr. stars, with Vivica A. Fox, Kevin Pollak, Kim Wayans and Lil' Kim. Directed by Jesse Vaughan. June 21.

LILO AND STITCH: Disney's major animated entry for summer. The tale of a strange little girl in Hawaii and her new pet (who is actually a six-legged space alien, pretending to be a dog because the intergalactic police are after him). Unfortunately the alien wreaks havoc wherever he goes. The girl is also a huge Elvis fan. Directed by Chris Sanders and Dean DeBlois. With the voices of Tia Carrere, Ving Rhames, Zoe Caldwell and Mr. Sanders (as the alien). June 21. A related article is on Page 15 of Summer Movies.

MINORITY REPORT: Tom Cruise, directed by Steven Spielberg -- and that's enough to get a lot of people into the theater. Mr. Spielberg doesn't like to give away a lot about his movies in advance, but we do know that this is science fiction set about a half-century in the future and based on a story by Philip K. Dick. (Dick wrote "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?," which became "Blade Runner." ) Mr. Cruise plays a future cop in a world where law enforcement is allowed to execute murderers before they've actually killed. This is with the help of seers who alert the police to coming crimes. With Samantha Morton. Oh, and it's reported that Mr. Cruise's character drives a 2058 Lexus. June 21.

SUNSHINE STATE: In John Sayles's new comic drama about Florida real estate development, everyone and everything seem to be on the brink of change. Angela Bassett and Edie Falco play two hometown girls who have returned to their families after their individual, unrelated show business dreams have fizzled. As their quiet small town turns into just another corporate resort town, both women deal with their aging parents and try to plan new lives for themselves. With Jane Alexander, Ralph Waite, Mary Alice and Timothy Hutton. June 21.

SKIN OF MAN, HEART OF BEAST: A French thriller about violence and mental illness in a rural family, as seen by two children. Directed by Helene Angel. June 21.

MONEY BUYS HAPPINESS: Two lovers growing in different directions and trying not to. An absurdist comedy written and directed by Gregg Lachow, a Seattle filmmaker. June 26.

THE COCKETTES: They were a motley crew of San Francisco hippies -- men, women, gay, straight. They loved gender-bending drag 30 years ago, and some people say they invented glitter rock. David Weissman and Bill Weber reflect on those midnight shows ("Gone With the Showboat to Oklahoma," "Tinsel Tarts in a Hot Coma") in North Beach in this documentary. With appearances by John Waters, Holly Woodlawn and the omnipresent Sylvia Miles. June 28.

CROCODILE HUNTER: COLLISION COURSE: A crocodile has accidentally swallowed a top-secret satellite beacon, and Steve Irwin, the Animal Planet adventurer, is there. And he thinks the government agents chasing the crocodile are poachers trying to kill it. Spiders, snakes, guns! Directed by John Stainton. June 28.

HEY ARNOLD! THE MOVIE: Arnold, a big-city fourth grader with a large, football-shaped head, is the star of his own animated television series on Nickelodeon. In his first feature film, Arnold and his multicultural friends are up against bad grown-ups planning to build a "mall-plex" nearby. With the voices of Spencer Klein, Jennifer Jason Leigh and Christopher Lloyd. Directed by Tuck Tucker. June 28.

IN PRAISE OF LOVE: Godard lives. But his new film, released in France as "Eloge de l'Amour," was described by A. O. Scott in The Times as "a lavish expression of artistic impotence, a great filmmaker's elegy for his own lost relevance." The film's central characters are an elderly couple who worked in the French Resistance during World War II. They have finally agreed to sell their story to Hollywood because they need the money to hold on to their little country hotel. The film, which also involves a young man looking for a woman who may be the couple's granddaughter, is half color and half black-and-white. With Jean Davy, Francoise Verney, Bruno Putzulu and Cecile Camp. June 28.

LOVELY AND AMAZING: From Nicole Holofcener, who did "Walking and Talking," a comic family portrait of four neurotic but resilient women. Brenda Blethyn plays a mother of three. Jane (Catherine Keener) is in a miserable marriage. Elizabeth (Emily Mortimer) is an insecure actress who takes in stray dogs. And the little sister, Annie (Raven Goodwin), may be adopted, but she's showing signs of all the family hang-ups. June 28.

MR. DEEDS: The idea that Adam Sandler is playing the Gary Cooper role in a remake of Frank Capra's "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town" is cause for a double take. But then it's not exactly a remake. Mr. Sandler plays a small-town New Hampshire pizzeria owner who suddenly inherits a fortune from a long-lost relative. That includes $40 billion, a couple of sports teams and the world's largest media conglomerate. Chances are, the money won't change him -- except to make even clearer the things in life that are really important. Winona Ryder plays a reporter who disapproves of him. Steven Brill, who directed, also directed Mr. Sandler in "Little Nicky." Tim Herlihy, the screenwriter, also wrote "Billy Madison," "The Wedding Singer" and a few other Sandler hits. June 28.

PUMPKIN: Sorority girl falls for disabled boy. Christina Ricci stars in this romantic comedy going for a politically incorrect tone. In hopes of being named best sorority on campus, Carolyn (Ms. Ricci) and her collegiate sisters volunteer to coach local athletes who are mentally or physically handicapped. Carolyn ends up working with a boy named Pumpkin Romanoff (Hank Harris), who has a beautiful soul. Brenda Blethyn plays Pumpkin's overprotective mother, who calls Carolyn a slut and a pedophile. Directed by Adam Larson Broder and Tony Abrams. June 28.

A SONG FOR MARTIN: Bille August, who gave us "Pelle the Conquerer," wrote and directed this romantic drama. For Martin, a noted conductor-composer, and Barbara, a symphony violinist, it's never too late to leave their families (the children are grown now, after all), run away together and start a new life. But even in their beautiful home on the Swedish coast, bad things can happen to the happily remarried. With Sven Wollter and Viveka Seldahl. June 28.

DAHMER: THE MIND IS A PLACE OF ITS OWN: Jeremy Renner plays Jeffrey Dahmer (1960-94), who killed 17 men and cannibalized them. He was killed in prison by a fellow inmate. With Bruce Davison and Matt Newton. Written and directed by David Jacobson. June.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 19, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A listing last Sunday in Summer Movies, Part 2 of this section, misstated the title and release date of a comedy about the New York art world written and directed by P. J. Posner. It is "The Next Big Thing," not "The Next Best Thing"; it will open in New York on May 29; the general release is June 14.
A listing on May 12 in Summer Movies, Part 2 of this section, for "Minority Report," scheduled to open on June 21, referred incorrectly to the plot. It depicts a future world in which with the help of seers, people are arrested before they commit murders; they are not executed.

SECTION: Section 2A; Column 1; Summer Movies; Pg. 37

HEADLINE: Sequels? Sure. But Godard, Too. 

BYLINE:  By ANITA GATES 

 BODY:
THE Jedi knights are back. So are the under-age spies, the small-town serial killer, the talking mouse, the mod 60's agent with bad teeth and a pair of men who look great in black. Otherwise it looks like a catchall season, maybe because so much has happened since Americans last settled in for something as frivolous as a new batch of summer movies.
 There are films based on works by Melville, Wilde and Capote and just as many that began as Saturday-morning cartoon shows, Web-site series and theme-park attractions. In one unfortunate town, residents are being attacked by giant spiders; elsewhere, a young man in a red spider suit is attacking evildoers. 
 Godard, Rohmer, Chabrol and Zhang Yimou have new films, as do the American auteurs Steven Spielberg, Woody Allen, Steven Soderbergh and John Sayles. Some actors are playing at least slightly against character: Gwyneth Paltrow doing literary research, Tom Hanks getting tough as a hit man, Matthew McConaughey slaying dragons. Tom Cruise, Mel Gibson and Eddie Murphy are doing science fiction. And in a romantic triangle in which the wife is having an affair with a younger man, Richard Gere is playing the husband. 
Here are 145 or so of the films in our near future, with opening dates, as usual, very likely to change -- and change again. Hope you like sequels.

May

A GRIN WITHOUT A CAT: The 1960's look so romantic from a distance. Chris Marker, a Parisian-born filmmaker, created this three-hour documentary about the French left in the 1960's and 70's back in 1977, then updated it in 1993, after the breakup of the Soviet Union. Dave Kehr, writing in The New York Times earlier this month, called the film "a work of extraordinary journalism" as well as "a work of deft and subtle poetry." Castro, Allende, Guevara and the Shah of Iran make appearances. This is the American premiere of this version of the film. May 1.

HOLLYWOOD ENDING: In Woody Allen's newest comedy, which is scheduled to open the Cannes International Film Festival this week, he plays a has-been film director trying to make a comeback. Unfortunately, that may mean working for his ex-wife (Tea Leoni), who is now the studio head's girlfriend. Maybe that's why he goes psychosomatically blind. The cast also includes George Hamilton, Erica Leerhsen, Debra Messing and Mark Rydell. Which makes the average age of the male stars 65, and the average age of the female stars 31. Not that there's anything wrong with that. May 1.

UZUMAKI: A Japanese horror film about slime-covered snail people and and a working-class town obsessed with spirals. May 1.

ABC AFRICA: Abbas Kiarostami, Iran's Palme d'Or-winning director, usually makes more intimate movies, about personal relationships and the stages of life ("Taste of Cherry," "Through the Olive Trees"). This documentary, about the orphans of Uganda, is a considerable change of pace. There are two million Ugandans with H.I.V. and two million already dead, leaving more than a million and a half children without parents. In English and Farsi, with English subtitles. May 3.

DEUCES WILD: We haven't seen much in the teenage gang genre for a while. This one, directed by Scott Kalvert (a video director who moved on to feature films with "The Basketball Diaries"), is set in 1958 Brooklyn. There's a new gang in town, and the guys in the good gang have to stop them before they take over the streets. Matt Dillon, Stephen Dorff, Fairuza Balk and Frankie Muniz (of "Malcolm in the Middle") star. Some suggest that the unrest that year was because the Dodgers had moved to L.A. May 3.

FLEEING BY NIGHT: Some romantic triangles are more complicated than others. From Taiwan, the story of a theater owner's daughter torn between love for her fiance, who is a cellist, and feelings for an opera star. And just to keep things interesting, the fiance has feelings for him too. The setting is 1930's China. With Rene Liu, Lei Huang and Chao-te Yin. Directed by Chi Yin. May 3.

HOME MOVIE: Home being the operative word here. A tour of five extremely unusual residences and the unusual people who live there. The houses include a Hawaiian treehouse, a Bayou houseboat-mansion and a missile silo in Kansas. A documentary by Chris Smith("American Movie"), which won the 1999 documentary grand jury prize at the Sundance Film Festival. May 3.

THE MYSTIC MASSEUR: Ismail Merchant without James Ivory or their usual screenwriter, Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. Caryl Phillips, the Caribbean-born novelist, wrote this fable based on V. S. Naipaul's 1957 novel about diversity and cultural integrity in 1940's Trinidad. Aasif Mandvi, who was so impressive Off Broadway in "Sakina's Restaurant," plays Ganesh, a former teacher who wants to be an author but moves to the country, becomes a masseur and makes it big as a healer. Which means that now people want to buy his books. With Om Puri (as Ganesh's father-in-law), Ayesha Dharker and James Fox. May 3.

SPIDER-MAN: This isn't the next career move you'd expect from Tobey Maguire, who has made his mark as an innocent, sensitive type in films like "Pleasantville" and "The Cider House Rules." He's playing the young Marvel Comics superhero who fights crime by scaling buildings like an arachnid. In his first film, Spidey, as his friends call him, is up against the Green Goblin (Willem Dafoe). The cast also includes Kirsten Dunst, as the superhero's love interest; Cliff Robertson, as his wise Uncle Ben ("With great power comes great responsibility"); James Franco, who was eerily good as James Dean in a TNT film last year; and the stage star Rosemary Harris. Written by David Koepp, who did the screenplay for "Panic Room" and was Michael Crichton's co-writer on "Jurassic Park." Directed by Sam Raimi, who did "A Simple Plan." This is not Mr. Raimi's first encounter with superheroics; 12 years ago he guided a relatively unknown Liam Neeson in the title role of "Darkman." May 3.

WARM WATER UNDER A RED BRIDGE: From Shohei Imamura -- who directed the Palme d'Or-winning film "The Eel" -- is the story of a Japanese businessman (Koji Yakusho) who has been through some difficult times and goes to a little seaside village. He's searching for a particular stolen Buddha, which would certainly cheer him up. He finds, among other things, a very unusual woman (Misa Shimizu) whose sexual satisfaction is so transporting that it affects nature around her. Based on "Akai Hashi No Shita No Nurui Mizu," a novel by Yo Henmi. In Japanese, with English subtitles. May 3.

DIAMONDS AND RUST: Life aboard a diamond mining ship off the coast of Africa. Directed by Adi Barash and Ruth Shatz. Playing with "Profit and Nothing But!" In English, Hebrew, Namibian and Spanish, with English subtitles. May 8.

PROFIT AND NOTHING BUT!: A documentary about the global economic system and its impact on developing countries. Written and directed by Raoul Peck. In English, French and Haitian, with English subtitles. May 8.

UNFAITHFUL: Richard Gere, Diane Lane and the sexy young French newcomer Olivier Martinez in an adultery thriller. Adrian Lyne, who does well with intense relationship stories ("Fatal Attraction," "Indecent Proposal," the underrated 1997 "Lolita"), has done a remake of "La Femme Infidele." The French original was about a husband who kills his wife's lover, which leads to her loving the husband more than ever. The American version is big on the psychology of guilt. May 8.

BLACKWOODS: A screenwriter cheerfully heads out on a weekend trip to meet his girlfriend's family. But the family turns out to have invited him there under false pretenses, and he is in huge running-through-the-woods trouble. With Patrick Muldoon, Michael Pare and Keegan Connor Tracy. Directed by Uwe Boll. May 10.

ESPN'S ULTIMATE X: An action documentary about the 2001 X Games in Philadelphia. That means skateboarding, biking, moto X (which has something to do with motorized bikes) and street luge. Directed by Bruce Hendricks, the film is 42 minutes and is being shown only on Imax and other large-format screens. May 10.

JANICE BEARD: Eileen Walsh plays Janice, a young Englishwoman who has moved to London for a good cause. She wants to earn money to get treatment for her agoraphobic mother. The job Janice finds is as a typist (the film's original British title was "Janice Beard: 45 Words Per Minute") at a car manufacturing company. There she meets and falls in love with the mail-room guy (Rhys Ifans, who was Hugh Grant's clueless flatmate in "Notting Hill"). Patsy Kensit plays Janice's boss. This is a comedy about, ultimately, industrial espionage. Directed by a newcomer, Claire Kilner. May 10.

THE LADY AND THE DUKE: Eric Rohmer, the French New Wave legend, is 82 now (he directed "My Night at Maud's" in 1969) and still creating. "L'Anglaise et la Duc" is the story of a Scottish noblewoman trapped in Paris during the French Revolution. Her relationship with Philippe, Duke of Orleans, a cousin of Louis XVI's, may or may not be a good thing. Lucy Russell and Jean-Claude Dreyfus star. If the film has an unusual 3-D look, it's because of the virtual sets: painted backdrops inserted digitally. May 10.

LAGAAN: ONCE UPON A TIME IN INDIA: A four-hour Bollywood musical about taxes. In 1893, in a small village in British-occupied India, a new land tax is imposed. But Captain Russell (Paul Blackthorn), the local overseer, decides to give the villagers a break. If they can beat the English in cricket, the tax will be repealed. Aamir Khan stars. In Hindi and English, with a half-dozen song-and-dance numbers. May 10.

THE NEW GUY: Here's a peculiar premise for a comedy. If you're an uncool high school student, just get yourself expelled and end up in prison. There you'll meet a lot of guys who can teach you everything they know about coolness. Then, after your release, you can start a new life at a new high school and be happy and popular. Unless a bully from your old school turns up. D. J. Qualls plays the fortunate uncool young man. His co-stars include Lyle Lovett, Zooey Deschanel and Eddie Griffin. Directed by Ed Decter. May 10.

CREMASTER 3: Matthew Barney's work is experimental, avant-garde and deliberately dreamlike. This three-hour film is the final one in his five-part Cremaster cycle, and a good deal of its action takes place in the Chrysler Building and the Guggenheim Museum. With Richard Serra, Aimee Mullins and a couple of New York hardcore bands. Mr. Barney appears as the Entered Apprentice, who is up against dental surgery, a woman who's half-cheetah and an all-Chrysler demolition derby. Wednesday.

STANDING BY YOURSELF: A 24-year-old filmmaker's Oscar-nominated documentary about his own 16-year-old brother's descent into drug use, binge drinking and generally antisocial behavior. The younger brother's best friend goes along for the ride, too. The film, from Josh Koury, was shown at Slamdance, one of the other film festivals in Park City, Utah. Wednesday.

STAR WARS: EPISODE II -- ATTACK OF THE CLONES: Little Darth Vader is growing up. He's still known as Anakin Skywalker and he's still in training to be a Jedi knight, but the young villain-to-be is now played by 21-year-old Hayden Christensen. This is the fifth "Star Wars" film, and the third from both the mind and directorial hand of George Lucas, and most of the old gang from the last one are still around: Natalie Portman as Amidala (who was a queen and is now a senator), Ewan McGregor as Obi Wan-Kenobi, Samuel L. Jackson as Mace Windu, R2D2, C3PO, Yoda and the annoying Jar Jar Binks. Thursday. A related article is on Page 3 of Summer Movies.

ABOUT A BOY: Hugh Grant is playing a bad boy again, with definite similarities to his character in "Bridget Jones's Diary." This time Mr. Grant is an irresponsible, independently wealthy London bachelor who revels in his single-guy privacy. But he decides to join a single-parents' group because it seems like a good way to meet women. No, he doesn't have children, but he invents a son. He's not at all interested in the frantic, suicidal vegetarian single mom played by Toni Collette, but her 12-year-old son (Nicholas Hoult), whom he meets on a double date, decides to make Mr. Grant his father figure. This may or may not turn our hero into a grown-up. Based on the novel by Nick Hornby (who also wrote "High Fidelity"). Directed by Paul and Chris Weitz, who gave us, of all things, "American Pie." Friday.

LATE MARRIAGE: If you're a 31-year-old bachelor in New York or Los Angeles or Kansas City, no problem. If you're a 31-year-old bachelor in Tel Aviv, you're a shame to your parents and your community. This is the unfortunate situation of Zaza (Lior Louie Ashkenazi), whose Georgian emigre parents are getting desperate for their son to find a nice girl and give them grandchildren, in "Late Marriage," an Israeli comedy about true love, family tradition and death threats. Seems Zaza has a good reason to be uninterested in all the nubile young women who are pushed in front of him. He's in love with a 34-year-old Moroccan divorcee (Ronit Elkabetz) who has a child. The film won nine Israeli Oscar-equivalents last year and earned enthusiastic reviews at the New Directors/New Films series in New York last month. Written and directed by Dover Kosashvili. In Georgian and Hebrew, with English subtitles. Friday.

BACK OF THE WORLD: A Peruvian documentary about the disenfranchised. Subjects include child labor in South America, a Turkish parliament member who was jailed for using the Kurdish language in a speech, and a death row inmate in Mississippi. Javier Corcuera directed. May 22.

THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING EARNEST: Rupert Everett is Algernon, Colin Firth is Jack, Reese Witherspoon is Cecily, Frances O'Connor is Gwendolyn, and Judi Dench is Lady Bracknell, the key figures in Oscar Wilde's 1895 play. In late Victorian England, apparently, young bachelors occasionally bent the truth when speaking to young ladies, and two of those men are about to be found out during an eventful country weekend. There's also the matter of an infant found in a handbag at Victoria Station. Oliver Parker, who did the film version of "An Ideal Husband" three years ago, directed and wrote the screenplay. May 22. A related article is on Page 31 of Summer Movies.

BARTLEBY: Yes, it's an update of "Bartleby the Scrivener," Herman Melville's 1853 story. Crispin Glover plays the title character, a mild-mannered public records clerk, who really starts something when one day he tells his boss, "I would prefer not to." He refuses to work or to leave, which creates a problem for his boss. This is an absurdist black comedy directed by a newcomer, Jonathan Parker, and reviewed favorably at the New Directors/New Films series this year, with the observation that Melville may have been the spiritual father of Dilbert. With Glenne Headly, Joe Piscopo and David Paymer. May 24.

C.Q.: Roman Coppola, son of Francis, makes his feature-film directorial debut. The setting is 1960's Paris, where the director of a sci-fi film has gone off the deep end, partly because he's become obsessed with his star (Angela Lindvall), playing Dragonfly the secret agent. A young American filmmaker (Jeremy Davies, whose first starring film role was as an incestuous student in "Spanking the Monkey") is called in to finish the film, which is set in the future -- the year 2001, that is. Unfortunately, Dragonfly captures his fancy too. Gerard Depardieu and Giancarlo Giannini, among others, make appearances. Mr. Coppola, who is 36 and who made a brief childhood appearance in "The Godfather: Part II," wrote the screenplay as well. May 24.

ENOUGH: Jennifer Lopez tries on a damsel-in-distress-fights-back role. And Billy Campbell, the boyishly cute star of ABC's popular but dead series "Once and Again," shows us his villainous side. In the beginning she's a waitress and he's a rich contractor. The next thing you know, they have a dream suburban marriage and an adorable 5-year-old daughter. But soon the husband has become abusive and obsessive. The wife runs away to start a new life, but he finds her and she decides that the only solution is to murder him. (Didn't Julia Roberts already do this in "Sleeping With the Enemy"?) The cast also includes Noah Wyle and Juliette Lewis. Directed by Michael Apted, whose films include "Nell" and "Coal Miner's Daughter." Written by Nicholas Kazan, who did the razor-sharp "Reversal of Fortune" and the maudlin "Bicentennial Man." May 24.

INSOMNIA: An American remake of a 1997 Norwegian film starring Stellan Skarsgard as a Swedish detective on assignment. In the new film, Al Pacino plays an American detective sent to a small town in Alaska to investigate the murder of a teenage girl. He ends up playing cat-and-mouse games with the major suspect (Robin Williams), but the detective is being watched himself by a local police officer (Hilary Swank), who is checking out the death of the detective's partner (Martin Donovan). Directed by Christopher Nolan, who wrote and directed the intriguing Pinteresque thriller "Memento" last year. May 24. A related article is on Page 1 of Summer Movies.

SIA, THE DREAM OF THE PYTHON: For many cities, it's a recurring problem -- which young virgin to sacrifice to the snake god. This time, in poverty-stricken Kombi, it's Sia, the most beautiful girl in town. Her fiance, understandably upset, tries to stop it. A film, based on a seventh-century legend, from Burkina Faso and France, written and directed by Dani Kouyate (also from Burkina Faso). The cast includes Sotigui Kouyate, Habib Dembele, Hamadoun Kassogue and Fatoumata Diawara. In Bambara, with English subtitles. May 24.

SPIRIT: STALLION OF THE CIMARRON: A horse's Western adventures as told by the horse (the voice of Matt Damon). This animated film is the story of a wild mustang stallion captured by cavalry soldiers. Spirit has had no dealings with human beings, but he soon makes friends with a young Lakota (the voice of Daniel Studi) and falls in love with another horse. Kelly Asbury directed. With songs by Bryan Adams. May 24. A related article is on Page 15 of Summer Movies.

13 CONVERSATIONS ABOUT ONE THING: Karma in the big city. A drama about the interconnected lives of various New Yorkers (a vengeful businessman, a cheated-on wife and a cheerful young cleaning woman, among others). Matthew McConaughey, John Turturro, Amy Irving, Alan Arkin and Clea DuVall star in this drama, directed by Jill Sprecher, who did "Clockwatchers," a comic drama about office temps. Ms. Sprecher and Karen Sprecher, her sister, wrote the screenplay. May 24.

ELLING: An Oscar-nominated Norwegian comic drama about two mental-institution roommates who get out, are given a state-supported apartment of their own in Oslo and begin to try to lead normal lives. But the two have trouble -- answering the telephone, shopping for groceries and remembering to change their underwear. Per Christian Ellefsen plays the shy title character. Sven Nordin plays the sex-obsessed Kjell, who learns that you never know what new friends you'll find if you pick up a drunken neighbor passed out on the stairs. Petter Naess directed. May 29.

NIJINSKY: THE DIARIES OF VASLAV NIJINSKY: "I worked like an ox," Vaslav Nijinsky wrote in the diaries that he began in 1919. "I lived like a martyr." Derek Jacobi is Nijinsky's voice in this film based on those diaries, which were first published in 1949. Nijinsky was, of course, the Russian dancer who scandalized Paris in 1912 with "L'Apres-Midi d'un Faune." With re-creations of his works by dancers from the Australian Ballet and Leigh Warren & Dancers. Directed by the Dutch-born, Australia-based Paul Cox, whose other film subjects have included Father Damien and Vincent van Gogh. May 29.

MASTER OF THE FLYING GUILLOTINE: The New York theatrical premiere of a 1974 martial arts film. (A long story about an edit-happy American distributor, a few Midwestern drive-ins and lost negatives.) Wang Yu's film is about a blind monk's efforts to kill his archenemy, the one-armed boxer. With Jimmy Wang Yu, Kam Kang and Tak Chi Chen. In Cantonese, with brand-new English subtitles. May 31.

THE SUM OF ALL FEARS: Ben Affleck follows in Harrison Ford and Alec Baldwin's footsteps, playing Jack Ryan, Tom Clancy's he-man C.I.A. hero. It's a good thing he's around, because terrorists have found a nuclear device buried since the 1967 Arab-Israeli conflict. And they've decided the Super Bowl in Baltimore would be a nice occasion for detonation. In Mr. Clancy's 1991 novel, the terrorists were Arab; in the film, they've been transformed into neo-Nazis. With Morgan Freeman, James Cromwell, Liev Schreiber and Alan Bates. Directed by Phil Alden Robinson, who dealt with gentler themes in "Field of Dreams." May 31.

UNDERCOVER BROTHER: Eddie Griffin as a secret agent in an all-black brotherhood devoted to the unceasing battle against The Man. Now the agent is going undercover in order to sabotage Operation Whitewash, and it will require his wearing tennis sweaters and penny loafers. Luckily he has a beautiful partner, Sistah Girl (Aunjanue Ellis), with whom to go up against villains like Mr. Feather (Chris Kattan). Finally, a comedy based on a Web-site series. Directed by Malcolm D. Lee, who did "The Best Man." May 31.

JOSHUA: Tony Goldwyn plays the title character, a mysterious newcomer to a small town who begins doing a bevy of good works, from rebuilding a church to just bringing people together. The film is based on a 1983 novel by Joseph F. Girzone, a retired priest, in which he imagined Jesus' life if he had lived it in the 20th century. With F. Murray Abraham and Giancarlo Giannini. Directed by Jon Purdy, whose previous subjects have included Al Capone, John Dillinger and the Unabomber. May.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 8

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Is Your Health Insurance Hurting Your Credit?

BYLINE:  By EVE TAHMINCIOGLU 

 BODY:
BECAUSE she had health insurance, Martha Rudnik, a former home care aide from Westport, Mass., assumed that the bills for her hip-replacement operation last May would be handled expediently. The procedure, she said, was clearly covered under her plan. But in the weeks after her surgery, she received a flurry of past-due notices from the hospital and doctors, on bills totaling more than $20,000.
 It was only after four months of dunning phone calls to her medical providers and the insurer, Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts, that the matter was resolved, she said. "Our credit is very good," Mrs. Rudnik, 52, said, adding that she would never want an unpaid bill to come back to haunt her family. 
 Lisa Watson, 33, a homemaker from Levittown, Pa., found that out the hard way. She said a lender she had contacted recently about refinancing her home mortgage told her that she and her husband wouldn't qualify for the lowest available interest rate, because of a mark on their credit report. A billing error had delayed the payment of a $200 hospital bill for her son Ryan last year, and the physician turned over their account to a collection agency, she said. "I assumed it was taken care of," Mrs. Watson said. 
Their frustration is a familiar story. Medical payment delays have become almost routine, but left unresolved they can spell trouble for consumers, possibly affecting their ability to borrow for a new home or car, or even to get the best deal on a credit card.
Hard numbers are elusive, though credit counselors, consumer advocates and others say anecdotal evidence suggests that the problem may be on the rise despite laws in most states that are intended to protect consumers.
Richard Kirsch, executive director of Citizens Action of New York, says one of every five calls to the group's managed-care consumer assistance unit has to do with payment delays. "People are dealing with the enormous stress of having an illness, and on top of that they have the stress of bills," Mr. Kirsch said. In some cases, consumers, fearing that their credit will be damaged, end up paying the bill out of their own pockets even though it is the insurer's responsibility, he said.
Mary Rzeszut, who operates SMV Billing Solutions, a company in Mineola, N.Y., that assists consumers with medical claims, said: "Hospitals and doctors are quick to put you in collections these days. Doctors want their money, insurers drag their feet. But no one is willing to help the patient."
Medical providers and insurers blame each other.
"Insurance companies discovered the time value of money," said Timothy T. Flaherty, chairman of the American Medical Association in Chicago. He defended doctors' practice of quickly sending out past-due notices. "I think it's just good business practice; patients should be aware that their insurance company hasn't paid."
Unpaid bills can add up quickly. In New Jersey alone, about $1 billion in claims go unpaid annually because of insurance delays, according to a survey conducted last year by the Medical Society of New Jersey.
Insurers, though, contend that the providers are slow to file claims and often make billing errors. They also cite a lack of uniformity in health insurance forms. All providers need to move from paper to electronic billing systems if claims are to be paid immediately, said Karen Ignagni, president of the American Association of Health Plans, a managed-care lobbying group.
In Mrs. Rudnik's case, Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts said the charges from her surgery were paid within 30 to 35 days from the time the providers' bills were submitted. If a provider billed the patient, that was out of Blue Cross's hands, said Susan Leahy, a company spokeswoman.
Caught in the middle are consumers, some of whom may be unaware of serious problems until long after the fact. "When we pull a consumer's credit report and an outstanding medical charge appears, they say, 'What's that?' " said Patty Hasson, president of the Consumer Credit Counseling Service of Delaware Valley, a nonprofit group in Philadelphia.
In many cases, she added, consumers themselves do little to help the hospital or doctor straighten out a charge with an insurer. The provider then sends the patient's bill to a collection agency, she said.
While some employers who offer coverage will help with claims, it is often up to consumers to stay on top of their medical bills. The first step is to review the health insurance policy. "You can't rely on your doctor or billing office to know what coverage you have," Ms. Rzeszut said.
Consumers should also make sure that all the information on their insurance forms is correct and has been properly submitted, especially if they are receiving care from doctors who are not among the policy's network of providers. The greatest delays in medical claims are for out-of-network charges, because they involve providers who may be unfamiliar with the insurer's procedures, said William Garnett, president of the Benemax Company in Medfield, Mass., which manages employee benefits for more than 150 companies.
MS. RZESZUT recommends that consumers not pay a bill if they are certain that it is covered by their policy. If such a bill ends up in collections, she said, they should not feel threatened by the bill collectors. "Work with them to get the claims resolved," she said.
Credit reports often note when a claim is sent to a collector. These reports, maintained by the three major credit bureaus -- TransUnion, Experian and Equifax -- should be monitored by consumers at least once a year, financial experts say.
If a medical bill that should have been paid by an insurer appears on the report, the patient should immediately notify in writing all three credit agencies, which are required by law to review items a consumer disputes, experts say. The patient should then contact the insurer and the collection agency to find out why the payment was not made, they say.
Getting a black mark removed from your credit report can take several weeks or months of wrangling with the insurer, the provider and the collection agency. In the meantime, credit bureaus do allow consumers to include a 100-word statement on their credit reports explaining an outstanding debt. It can be a simple statement saying that you were fully covered by insurance at the time and that you are trying to resolve the matter.
Ms. Hasson of the credit counseling center in Philadelphia says she has found that lenders are more understanding when it comes to medical debt.
Lisa Mihailuk, a senior vice president in Countrywide Home Loans' consumer division in Plano, Tex., said consumers whose accounts are sent to a collection agency because of medical debt are typically considered a lower credit risk than those with other types of unresolved debt, because the problem is seen as an isolated incident and not a sign of a consumer's overall creditworthiness. There's a difference, she said, between raking up thousands in charges on a credit card and needing surgery. But the consumer will still have to remove the medical debt from the report in order for a conventional loan to be approved.
Consumers are not without protection. Most states have "prompt pay" laws regulating how long an insurance company may wait before making a payment -- usually 30 to 60 days -- though health care experts say some of the laws need more teeth. A few states are rewriting their laws to include tougher provisions. New Jersey, for example, recently revised its law mandating that electronic claims that are "clean," or clearly covered by insurance, be paid within 30 days and clean paper claims within 40 days; under its old law, clean claims had to be paid within 60 days.
New York State requires insurance companies to pay undisputed claims within 45 days. Since the law was signed in 1997, the state Department of Insurance has imposed fines totaling nearly $1 million for failure to comply. 
Texas is among the most aggressive states in enforcing such rules. Last year it fined 18 insurance companies more than $10 million for prompt-payment violations.
Mrs. Watson, the homemaker from Pennsylvania, is covered by a prompt-payment law in her state. But she says consumers must do their part first in ensuring that clean claims are paid on time. It cost her a low mortgage rate, and although her insurer eventually paid her claim, she is now trying to have the debt removed from her credit report. "It was my fault," she said. "I didn't stay on top of it."

Some Ways to Avoid Billing Surprises
Following are some tips from experts for keeping track of insurance claims:
* Check records. Make sure that your medical provider has all the correct billing information, including the identification or group number of your insurance plan.
* Stay in contact. After receiving a bill, check with the provider or the insurer to be sure that the claim is being processed. Write down the names of people with whom you speak, the dates and the confirmation numbers, if available. 
* Learn the codes. Verify that the medical procedure for which you are being charged is the one that was performed.
* Watch the numbers. Check with your insurer if you think you are being billed twice or being charged more than the contracted rate between the insurer and the provider.
* Get help at work. If your employer provides your insurance, the human resources manager or benefits department may be able to help with your claim.

HEADLINE: The World: Killing Time; 
Everyone Has a Peace Plan. And They Can All Wait.

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
TWO tense armed standoffs have been resolved in the past two weeks, even as bombs keep exploding and tanks roll toward expected reprisals. An international peace conference looms this summer. Israel and the Arab world have outlined competing visions that, however far apart, each claim the aim of a Palestinian state. The United States is off the sidelines and back in the fray.
 So it's time for progress toward peace in the Middle East? Maybe not. In fact, there is every sign that a new waiting game has just begun. The three most important players in this game -- President Bush, Ariel Sharon and Yasir Arafat -- have all shown signs that they see reasons to wait rather than press for a final deal now. 
 Since announcing plans for the peace conference, the Bush administration has gone out of its way to say that it will be only a meeting of ministers, to talk about what to talk about, not to make a deal. The administration's primary passion in the Middle East remains reserved for toppling Saddam Hussein, and managing the Israeli-Palestinian crisis is still seen as less of a priority, a means toward that end. 
Prime Minister Sharon of Israel talks of a whole new period of incremental security arrangements before a final peace settlement, meaning that true Palestinian statehood might have to wait 15 or 20 years. He and his aides say peace talks cannot even begin again until the Palestinian Authority is reshaped to replace Mr. Arafat as the sole leader.
Mr. Arafat, though under enormous pressure from Washington and Arab leaders to rein in violence, knows that in the long run, demographics, world opinion and perhaps the tide of history favor the cause of Palestinian statehood. American intelligence analyses have long held that he is never more patient, or content to wait for a better deal, than when everyone else is clamoring for movement. That was one lesson of Camp David.
Only the moderate Arab states, under pressure to defuse calls for reform from their own restless populations, express particular urgency about the need for quick progress toward ending the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, seizing on it as a proxy for grappling with their internal problems.
"Today, we stand on the knife's edge, and the danger is not only to the region but to the world," King Abdullah II of Jordan said in a speech at Rice University in Houston on Thursday, adding: "Today, I believe we need less process and more peace."
Similar sentiment is widespread in Europe. But all parties agree that only the United States has enough credibility and clout to force progress. And despite counterintuitive calls by some experts that the current stalemate provides an opening to leap ahead to what King Abdullah called "the finish line," the Bush administration has shown few signs it is willing to do so.
Under domestic political pressure to support Israel, the administration hasn't put forward a broad plan of its own. President Bush has publicly assured Mr. Sharon that "I'm never going to tell my friend the prime minister what to do on how to handle his business."
One senior administration official said of his and previous administrations: "Most of the time in the Middle East, we don't have an American plan. We listen to the parties. We don't sit in our capitals and think up great ideas. Sometimes, we have to add our ideas to the mix. But we hardly ever start a negotiation by going, 'Plunk!' "
Even Saudi Arabia, whose Crown Prince Abdullah recently proposed the carrot of broad Arab peace with Israel in exchange for Israel's withdrawal from lands occupied in the 1967 war, has shown no real willingness to brandish the stick of an oil embargo, which would hurt its own weak economy as much as the West's. Nor has the prince offered Israel the tantalizing prospect of direct talks, or a dramatic personal gesture equal to that of Anwar el-Sadat when he all but dared Menachem Begin to invite him to Jerusalem.
So despite the resolution of Israel's siege of Mr. Arafat's compound in Ramallah and of the armed standoff at the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, all sides are still playing for time. The latest suicide bombing in Israel last week left Secretary of State Colin L. Powell warning of the potential for setbacks even as he vowed to "keep moving forward."
"It's not rocket science where you have to get, and keeping a sense of where you have to get gives people the sense that the pendulum will oscillate around a fixed point," said James B. Steinberg, who was deputy national security adviser in the Clinton administration and is now at the Brookings Institution.
"The problem right now is that people have lost some sense of confidence that a deal can be done around that point," he added. "The Israelis have lost confidence that if they make concessions on territory and reach settlements on refugees and Jerusalem they will have real peace. And the Palestinians have lost confidence that what will be on offer any time soon is something that walks and talks like a state."
Israel and the Palestinians came close to those goals two years ago, before the collapse of peace talks at Camp David and Taba, Egypt, which had progressed as far as details of borders and control of Jerusalem. King Abdullah and other Arab leaders insist that new peace talks should build on that framework, not start from scratch, as Mr. Sharon is suggesting.
"If we're going to have a conference where we talk about timelines and modalities, that's frankly a waste of time," said Adel al-Jubeir, a foreign policy adviser to Crown Prince Abdullah.
SENIOR Israeli and American officials are just as insistent that they do not see a return to Camp David-style talks any time soon. They say 19 months of Palestinian terrorism and Israeli reprisals, together with the intense personal loathing between Mr. Sharon and Mr. Arafat, make that all but impossible.
Still, a number of respected experts have begun arguing that now is the time for a final settlement, which the United States and the international community would sketch out in advance, then push Israel and the Palestinians to accept in negotiations. These experts argue that the Oslo peace process allowed both sides to keep jockeying for advantage, by taking only interim steps and pushing off the toughest questions.
"The parties will be unable, if left to themselves, to stand down from this current situation, which is really characterized by violence, unless they have a political rationale and exit strategy," said Edward P. Djerejian, director of the James A. Baker III Institute of Public Policy at Rice University and a former ambassador to Syria and Israel. "I think the conference idea should be a step toward getting international consensus on exactly how the parties can be influenced toward negotiations, and it is really important to set out certain parameters. You don't have to reinvent the wheel."
But Mr. Djerejian added: "This is a period of intense policy formulation, because of the seriousness of the situation on the ground. It's going to take a few months to see where we actually come out."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Disparate Mediums, Familiar Messages

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
DEMOCRATS sometimes fret that there are too many disparate voices in their party and too many prospects for the White House in 2004. But maybe they should think again. While the field is indeed packed, discord isn't what you hear on the campaign trail. In fact, many possible candidates sound like they are reciting the same talking points.
 That is because often they are. 
 Democratic pollsters have been busy, scrutinizing the whims of voters and presiding over focus groups. And by and large, they've been coming to the same conclusion: Democratic voters don't want to criticize the war on terror, but they have bones to pick with the Bush White House on bread-and-butter issues. That advice is having an intriguing effect: when it comes time to deliver speeches, the candidates often seem to be speaking from exactly the same playbook. Sometimes, they use identical language. 
The biggest differences are not in content, but in how the speeches are written and what emphasis they give to one topic or another. Democrats all criticize the Bush tax cut, but they do not dare call for its repeal. They try to reclaim the education issue from Republicans. And they remind audiences that Mr. Bush's considered lowering arsenic standards in water.
The conventional wisdom is that the Democrats have a disjointed message because, without the White House, there is no leader to lay out a coordinated message. But maybe party leaders should get more credit. 
"In an odd way, the Democrats are moving toward a kind of consistency that is coming from all this listening to people," said Stanley Greenberg, a Democratic pollster. Senator Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, said: "I hear the same people testing the themes all the time."
The most striking example occurred at a recent gathering in Orlando of the Florida Democratic Party. Several of the party's luminaries were there, and here are some samples from their speeches:
On terrorism, patriotism and following the leader:
Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts: "Make no mistake: we are united as never before in the effort to win the war abroad. But we cannot permit Republicans to pretend the war is the only issue before our country."
Senator John Edwards of North Carolina: "In many ways our country has never been more united. . . . While we fight these wars overseas, we can never forget to stand up for what's right here at home. The American flag represents freedom, opportunity and justice for all -- and that's what we believe in as Democrats!"
Former Vice President Al Gore: "All of us Democrats and Republicans are united on the war on terrorism. . . . We do stand shoulder to shoulder with the president and with our brave servicemen and women in defending America from terrorism. . . . Here in America, patriotism does not mean keeping quiet."
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut: "Right now, in the war on terrorism, I'm proud to say we Democrats are standing shoulder to shoulder with the president as we should. We're putting country above politics, as we must. For this war is about one thing, and only one thing: America, and defending our way of life."
Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic national chairman, speaking of Mr. Bush: "Patriotism demands that we stand shoulder to shoulder with him."
On the Bush tax cut:
Mr. Kerry: "They want to give a tax cut to the wealthiest Americans at the expense of the average citizen and the economic health of our nation."
Mr. Gore: "They wanted to shovel it out to the wealthiest tax brackets in the form of tax relief for those who need it least and the rest of the country gets peanuts and the American people get stuck with the bill."
Mr. Lieberman: "Instead of a plan to expand opportunity and grow the middle class, President Bush just gave us a tax cut."
On education:
Mr. Kerry: "It's also time to remind our Republican friends you can't keep saying teaching is your most valued profession but not value it with decent pay. You can't attract a new generation to the profession if you demagogue your way to office by bashing teachers."
Mr. Edwards: "We have to stand up, fellow Democrats, for the kids in this country who so desperately need a good education but can't get it because their school system is not providing it."
Mr. Gore: "Education has gotten short shrift. We made real investments in improving education. They the Republicans were satisfied in making headlines on education."
Mr. Lieberman: "The smartest investment we can make is to give our public schools the tools they need to meet our high standards. In particular, we can't expect our teachers to do the job we need them to do unless we give them the respect they deserve and the professional salaries they have earned."
On Social Security:
Mr. Kerry: "Social Security is a lot more than just a program. It's about the relationship between the government and its people. It's the promise we make to people who after a lifetime of labor in good faith have a right to expect that good faith will be honored."
Mr. Edwards: "People in this country who go to work every week and see that money going out of their paycheck to Social Security, to Medicare, should not have to worry whether Medicare or Social Security will be there when they finally retire."
Mr. Gore: "They've turned their back on America's covenant with our greatest generation, raiding the Social Security and Medicare trust funds without pause, without remorse and seemingly without even a thought to the long-term consequences of what they're doing."
On the collapse of Enron:
Mr. Gore: "We're the party of Main Street U.S.A. They're the party of the pirates of Enron."
Mr. Kerry: "We're not going to let George W. Bush do to Social Security what Arthur Andersen and the administration's friends did to Enron."
On the environment: 
Mr. Gore: "Who could forget when they tried to convince us that our water was too clean, and didn't have enough arsenic in it?"
Mr. Edwards said of his children: "I wonder if they will have clean air, and clean water to drink."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING; 
Bill Clinton, the Club (Not the Kind With Turkey)

BYLINE:  By JIM O'GRADY 

 BODY:
Since President Bill Clinton left office in January 2001, there hasn't exactly been a rush to name public facilities after him. Neither staff members from his Harlem office nor the Clinton Presidential Center in Arkansas could point to a single building or facility that has honored Mr. Clinton by adopting his name. 
 But somebody had to go first. So the New Century Democratic Association, a 300-member political club in Flushing, plans to rename itself the William Jefferson Clinton Democratic Club of Queens. 
 "I'm really excited about it," said the club president, John Dorsa. "It's going to provide us a higher profile." He said his would be the first political club in New York City to take Mr. Clinton's name. "We might be the first one anywhere," he added. 
To be fair, it often takes years before a public figure sees his name chiseled into a building. The most recent American president with his name on a New York public school is Lyndon B. Johnson (P.S. 223 in Jamaica, Queens, and P.S. 151 in Bushwick, Brooklyn).
The club plans to celebrate its change with a party Tuesday at Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Mr. Dorsa said more than 300 tickets at $90 each had been sold by the middle of last week, mainly because the former president will be the guest of honor.
State Assemblyman Brian McLaughlin, who helped found the club in 1997, is also president of the New York City Central Labor Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and so many club members are union members. Several of them cited the 90's economic boom as a reason for their fondness for Mr. Clinton. "You have to give him credit for it," Peter Manno, an electrician from Flushing, said of the former president.
Mr. McLaughlin said the only objections to the name change that he was aware of came from nonmembers who scrawled what he called wisecracks about the former president onto party invitations returned by mail. 
"Whoever Bill Clinton's detractors are, they usually criticize him for his personal behavior," he said. "Not his public policy." 
Paul Belliveau, a 41-year-old paperhanger and club member, said he not only supports the name change but also would like to see Mr. Clinton become more involved in local politics. "Maybe we can get him to run for City Council," he said. 
Mr. Belliveau, who plans to attend the party with his parents, wife and three children, may get the chance to offer his suggestion to Mr. Clinton in person. If the two men want to discuss the matter further, they could adjourn to the Stage Deli in Midtown Manhattan and order corned beef, chopped liver and onion on rye, a sandwich known as "The Bill Clinton." JIM O'GRADY

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Will Wall Street Become a Regular at the Courthouse?

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
BROKERAGE firms' stocks have been battered since Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York attorney general, released documents showing how alarmingly symbiotic the relationship was between Merrill Lynch's research and investment banking departments in recent years. Assuming that more damaging revelations are coming, investors have driven down the American Stock Exchange Securities Broker/Dealer index of 12 publicly traded securities firms by 12 percent in just the last month or so. 
 Merrill Lynch alone has lost $10.6 billion in market value since the attorney general's investigation was made public. Merrill's shares have fallen to $41.53, or around 1.7 times their net worth or book value, and they look alluringly cheap. Since 1995, the company has traded in a range of 1.31 to 3.7 times its book value. 
 Several securities analysts have said that the loss in Merrill's stock seems well in excess of the litigation costs the firm will incur dealing with analyst conflicts and that the shares are worth buying. But Brad Hintz, brokerage analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, in New York, is more cautious. In his recent reports on what the sundry investigations might mean for the industry and its stocks, Mr. Hintz has concluded that the potential litigation costs from a variety of plaintiffs could be much higher than some analysts have estimated. 
The psychological impact of the cases and the negative publicity they might bring could also delay a recovery in investor activity. Mr. Hintz reckons that the lawsuits will drag on into 2004. 
So far, assessments of Wall Street's vulnerability to customer lawsuits have focused on cases brought by individuals who bought stocks based on recommendations made by Henry Blodget or other Merrill Lynch analysts. Mr. Hintz argues that pension funds may also sue investment firms to recoup losses. He thinks the people who administer and manage these funds may be obliged, under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, known as Erisa, to sue an investment firm if the fund could recover substantial amounts of money.
There is no doubt that lots of money vanished in the technology stock bubble. Considering only the seven Internet stocks identified by Mr. Spitzer in his filing against Merrill Lynch, losses in market value from peak to trough totaled $118 billion, Mr. Hintz noted. Given Merrill Lynch's market share of Nasdaq trading during the period, Mr. Hintz estimates its maximum liability at $3.8 billion to $5.2 billion on the stocks.
Obviously, Merrill will do whatever it must to keep from having to foot such a bill. Still, the numbers provide some perspective on the potential liability at some Wall Street firms. 
There is another risk for investors. One lawyer, an expert on Erisa who spoke on condition of anonymity, reasoned that the Labor Department, as an administrator of Erisa, might bring action against firms where conflicts were apparent. The problem for Wall Street is that the Labor Department looks at firms as a whole and not as separate operating units. The lawyer explained, "If a Merrill Lynch advisory arm represents a pension plan and is buying stocks that Merrill Lynch is hyping through their analysts, and the firm is going to get some potential investment banking fees out of that, that is a potential conflict that I could see the Labor Department waking up to someday." 
There is no indication that such transactions took place at Merrill or at other firms. But throughout the 1990's, Wall Street firms built themselves into financial supermarkets, offering investment services of all kinds to all people. Such a vertical integration can lead to potential conflicts between the operations if the firms are not careful. And in the mania, who was?

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Where TelecomBargain Hunters Turn

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
IT has been two months since Ivan G. Seidenberg, the chief executive of Verizon Communications, mused at an investment conference that his company might bid for WorldCom "for the fun of it" if the stock price of that long-distance and Internet carrier continued falling. 
 Since then, WorldCom's shares have dropped 80 percent, to $1.58 on Friday. But as Mr. Seidenberg wryly suggested, conditions in the communications sector are so tough that Verizon has no real interest in WorldCom at any price. Verizon, along with rivals like SBC Communications, BellSouth and Deutsche Telekom, all have plenty of their own problems without taking on WorldCom's, which include gigantic debt and an accounting investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 How bleak has the telecommunications scene become? Verizon's shares closed yesterday at $39.35, down 17 percent for the year, yet its investors can count themselves lucky. Telefonos de Mexico is the only member of the American Stock Exchange's index of 14 large North American telecommunications companies that has fared better since Jan. 1. Telefonos has risen 4.3 percent for the year, while the index has declined by 39.2 percent.
Such troubles invariably create opportunities for bargain hunters. Some portfolio managers have begun snapping up shares of equipment makers like Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and JDS Uniphase in the belief that the worst is over for them. Risk-tolerant investors have been heeding analysts who believe that the prices for some bonds issued by Qwest Communications International had dropped too far. Since April 30, the 10-year note issued in March by Qwest Corp., the company's operating subsidiary, has risen 3.4 percent to $100.54. And despite a drop in Worldcom's credit rating to junk status, the company's 3-year note maturing in May 2004 rose 23 percent for the week, closing at $68.77.
Some stock analysts recommend that investors consider companies like Alltel, CenturyTel and Commonwealth Telephone that serve rural areas. "Rural phone companies are great defensive alternatives," said Cannon Carr, who follows them for CIBC World Markets. Such companies receive government subsidies, have minimal involvement in the money-losing wireless segment and can market higher-priced services like broadband Internet links with less competition from the cable industry. On May 2, Commonwealth, based in Dallas, Pa., projected revenue growth of at least 3 percent this year and raised earnings estimates by 15 cents a share, to at least $2.
Abel Garcia, portfolio manager of the AIM New Technology fund, says the best bets in the sector are leading equipment companies, especially those in the consumer segment like Nokia, the world's largest cellphone maker, or UTStarcom, a leader in China's rapidly growing wireless business. "But we're not recommending any exposure to telecom," Mr. Garcia said. "Tech investors are better off looking at semiconductors or game companies."
From Wall Street's perspective, the industry's biggest problem may be its inability to merge long-distance companies like AT&T and WorldCom into the large local and wireless carriers. Wall Street would also like to see the wireless industry consolidate into three or four national companies. 
"The telecom industry is beset by destructive competition in almost every sector," said Frank J. Governali, who follows the major conventional telecommunications companies for Goldman, Sachs. But Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the chief executive of SBC, told investors last Monday that the government appears to oppose more big mergers.
Wireless companies are still adding customers, but they spend less time on their phones. Most of the companies are losing money, and there is uncertainty about consumers' willingness to pay for services like high-speed data transmission. AT&T Wireless, the largest publicly traded cellphone service in the domestic market, closed at $7.47 on Friday, down 75 percent from its initial offering price of $29.50 in 2000.
The conventional, or landline, companies, which Wall Street expected as of November to report revenue gains of 9 percent for this year, are now projected to end up with a 12 percent decline, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. The biggest phone companies are expected to continue cutting capital investments this year, which could deepen the slump at equipment suppliers.
It was fashionable last year for analysts to see the industry's problems as a temporary adjustment to excessive investment in new networks and services in the late 1990's. Now fears are rising that telecommunications has too much in common with industries like steel and airlines, in which profitability has been undermined repeatedly by overcapacity and competitive pressure.
That pressure extends well beyond the obviously declining segments, like long-distance voice service via landlines. Internet traffic doubled last year, but carriers were able to increase revenues from it by only 17 percent, according to estimates published last week by RHK, a market research firm. 
Adam Quinton, who follows the landline carriers for Merrill Lynch, recently concluded that their modest growth prospects over the next five years were comparable to those for gas and electric utilities. But big regional phone companies like Verizon are trading at an average of 12.5 times projected earnings for next year, compared with 11.3 times for the major electric utilities. That makes the phone sector look like a riskier bet. The only stock Mr. Quinton is recommending among those he follows is AT&T, and that is only because the company still owns the huge cable television business it has agreed to sell to Comcast. Until that deal closes, AT&T is a back-door way to invest in cable, according to Mr. Quinton.
AT&T and WorldCom provide a broad range of voice and data services to global companies, but their long-distance phone businesses are losing traffic to cellphones, e-mail, instant messaging and systems that send calls over the Internet. In addition, Verizon, SBC, BellSouth and Qwest, which own the local phone businesses created by the AT&T breakup in 1984, are gaining regulatory clearance to re-enter the long-distance business in their territories. 
IN the first group of states where the Baby Bells have begun selling long-distance along with local service, they have quickly grabbed as much as 20 percent of the market. Analysts from research firms like the Yankee Group expect that share to rise to 50 percent over the next few years. The battle is shifting quickly toward which companies can offer the most attractive bundles of local, long-distance, wireless and broadband services. That leaves the Baby Bells as the likely winners and better bets for long-term investors, many analysts say. 
Fans of the Baby Bells say these companies' dominance in their home regions gives them a strong foundation for riding out the sector's problems, and, to the extent allowed by the government, for buying assets from bankrupt competitors. Two of them -- Verizon and SBC -- also have solid dividends, yielding well over 3 percent. 
Patrick Comack of Guzman & Company expects that many prime assets of AT&T and WorldCom, including their services for big businesses with global operations, will eventually end up in the hands of one or another of the Baby Bells, known in the industry as regional Bell operating companies, or RBOC's. "At the end of the day, you're going to have the RBOC's battling each other," Mr. Comack said.
