HEADLINE: MANHATTAN: RETAIL SPACE; 
Rent Report Cites Signs of Rebound, Even Downtown

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
The amount of retail space available in Manhattan declined slightly from the end of September to the end of March, to 11.2 million square feet from 11.3 million, while the overall average rent being asked per square foot increased by $3, to $87 a square foot a year from $84, a Real Estate Board of New York survey shows. 
 Compared with a year previously, however, the average rent being asked in Manhattan was significantly lower. On March 31, 2001, the figure was $98 a square foot, and 10.6 million square feet were available. The board's semiannual report, based on the findings of 17 realty companies that surveyed 2,118 stores available for rent throughout Manhattan, is to be released today. 
 The September-March increase occurred even as the rents sought declined downtown, which means south of Canal Street. Retail activity there was mainly in the World Trade Center's shopping mall, according to the Real Estate Board.
Despite the destruction and fear engendered downtown by the attacks, the decline in the rents being asked through March of this year was only $2 a square foot less than the $60 a square foot that downtown stores had sought at the end of last September. The asking price reported on March 31, 2001, was also $60.
But signs of improvement downtown abound, the report said. Downtown stores that had been open six days a week are now open seven days. One participant in the survey said that retail activity was stronger south of Wall Street than it was a year ago. Another participant reported 550 inquiries for a retail space available downtown. All survey respondents were cited anonymously.
"Notwithstanding 9-11, that extraordinary event didn't signal a long-term downturn," said Ben Fox, the executive vice president of Newmark New Spectrum Retail and a member of the Real Estate Board's stores committee advisory group. "There is still a vibrant population downtown, and the increase in tourists wanting to visit the site of the terrorist attacks is a positive for retail." While some major cities have many empty stores in prime areas, he added, "you don't see that anywhere in New York."
In addition to downtown, the other areas covered by the survey were the East Side (60th Street to 96th, Fifth Avenue to the East River), Midtown (31st Street to 59th Street), Midtown South (Canal Street to 30th Street), Upper Manhattan (97th Street and higher, Fifth Avenue to the East River; 111th Street and higher, west of Fifth Avenue to the Hudson River) and the West Side (60th Street to 110th Street, Hudson River to west of Fifth Avenue). 
Other than downtown, the West Side was the only other neighborhood where the rents being asked at the end of March were even fractionally less than at the end of last September. They were $91, down from $92.
"The significant variations within each market mean that overall figures for available space and asking rents can't, by themselves, provide a truly detailed portrait of the retail market," said Steven Spinola, the president of the Real Estate Board. To supplement the numerical information in the report, the survey also contains data compiled from a summary of brokers' insights and their accounts of submarkets. 
The average asking rent this spring for ground floor space varied greatly according to location and size. On Madison Avenue between 57th Street and 67th, it was $170 a square foot for 385 square feet and $800 a square foot for 2,800 square feet. The rent sought in Times Square on Broadway between 42nd Street and 47th Street ranged from $70 a square foot for 320 square feet to $600 for 21,000 square feet. And on Fifth Avenue between 48th and 59th Streets, the asking price was $120 a square foot for 1,689 square feet and $500 for 20,000 square feet. 
While brokers have usually provided the rents being sought to the Real Estate Board, they have not done the same for the actual rents.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
Warehouse Vacancy Rates Are Up as Rents Fall

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Out on the western edge of St. Cloud, Minn., there is a 1.1 million-square-foot box, put there in part because the city is not much farther from any one big coastal American city than from any other. It was built for the single purpose of gathering baseball bats and sofas and coffee makers and all manner of goods together in one place, where they could be packaged into made-to-order bundles and sent out to the homes of customers.
 The structure's interior is completely automated, with racking systems, conveyer belts, scales and bar-code scanners -- $7.5 million worth of improvements in all to a plot of land worth less than $600,000. The use of technology was appropriate for the owner, the Fingerhut Corporation, an e-commerce unit of Federated Department Stores Inc. that is headed for liquidation after talks to sell the business fell through last week. The company also has warehouses in Spanish Fork, Utah, and Piney Flats, Tenn. 
 They are prized assets, but they could be difficult to sell. 
The warehouse industry is in a slump all over the country, with vacancy rates rising to 9.9 percent nationwide at the end of the first quarter from 7.5 percent in the quarter a year ago, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate brokerage and services company. In the corresponding period, annual asking rental rates have fallen to $5.75 a square foot from $6.16. 
Some of the most stagnant property listings in the portfolios of real estate brokers -- although probably accounting for less than 1 percent of all warehouse space, brokers and analysts said -- are the facilities used by all the vanquished rivals of Amazon.com.
"Kind of a double whammy when the bottom fell out was that these e-commerce companies had built and leased not only big buildings, but big buildings with specialized equipment," said James L. Dieter, executive managing director of the United States industrial group at Insignia/ESG, a commercial real estate services company.
While e-commerce companies owned and leased a negligible amount of warehouse property in the overall market, they helped alter the way companies approach storage and delivery. They shuffled priorities for industrial space in an evolution that was helped along by advances in logistics technology and a shift toward reliance on delivery by third parties. 
In the current market, landlords are making plans based on their contrasting views of the way companies will reset their priorities for warehouse space in the future, at the same time those companies are re-evaluating storage and transportation strategies and making few leasing or purchase deals. Though the pace of construction has quickly diminished, speculative building has glutted the market nationwide, and vacancy rates are rising and rents falling as companies cut costs in a soft economy, and as they tinker with delivery patterns.
In the nationwide industrial real estate market, 17.1 million square feet of space have been completed so far this year, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Of that amount, warehouse space accounted for 14.4 million square feet, and the other categories -- high-tech, manufacturing, office service and other -- accounted for more than 2.7 million square feet. Cushman estimates that the total amount of existing industrial space is 7 billion square feet, including 4 billion square feet of warehouse space.
"We got a tremendous amount of vacancy from overbuilding," said Thomas T. Lynn, executive vice president in the Dallas office of the Staubach Company, a real estate services concern. He attributed the continued pace of construction, even as the state of the economy declined, to "the herd mentality of developers. It was working, just like in the 80's, buildings were being built, and they were being leased."
Owners that are seeking to fill empty space are resorting to incentives that include waiving payment for part of the lease term.
"We are starting to see free rent, which we haven't seen in many years," said David R. Kahnweiler, president of Colliers Bennet & Kahnweiler, a corporate real estate company in Chicago.
Investment firms suggest that the sluggishness presents an opportunity. A new draft report by Laler DeCosta II and Steve Walker of Lend Lease Real Estate Investments makes the case that "investing in mature locations in the biggest industrial markets is a strategy for success, even if the most contemporary product is unavailable."
Whether investors accept that depends on their view of how companies will adjust their inventory patterns. And there are development companies and property owners to represent nearly every view.
"There is going to be net less demand for warehouse space, particularly warehouse space for storage," said Hamid R. Moghadam, chief executive of the AMB Property Corporation, an industrial real estate investment trust based in San Francisco that owns more than 900 buildings.
Mr. Moghadam's company lost more than $20 million investing in Webvan, an online grocer that closed last summer. Their warehouses were retrofitted with 100-foot-long computerized lazy susans and other high-technology modifications. On pure property though, Mr. Moghadam said his company his come through the experience well because the three facilities ABM still owns that it once leased to Webvan are small and close to city centers, characteristics he thinks companies will find desirable as they shift storage and delivery patterns. He has told investors that two of the facilities have new tenants.
Trammell Crow has a different view, one that includes a vision of an eventual need for millions of square feet of new warehouse space. Burned in the last slump by its holdings in land, the company has concentrated on structuring joint development agreements to keep all but about 20 of the 1,000 acres on which it intends to build warehouses sheltered from the balance sheet. The company is waiting until the properties can be leased before building.
In contrast, ProLogis owns 1,600 acres around the country, enough to develop 32 million square feet of warehouse space. The company's strategy is based on the same belief held by Mr. Moghadam, that companies will keep shrinking rather than increasing the amount of space they use, but that they will simultaneously shift to different, smaller facilities. That prospect would seem to leave developers with the same problem of too much space.
"Not if you're gaining market share," said John W. Seiple, the company's president. He said ProLogis is holding so much land, a gambit that seems to simultaneously contradict his stated agreement with AMB and ignore the worries about land ownership and interest payments expressed by Trammell Crow, because the land is a resource needed to fill new demands.
Building only for committed tenants did little to protect the industrial developers from the most recent downtown in the economy.
"When landlords underwrote facilities as single tenant facilities in an obscure location, they were really underwriting the tenant's credit as opposed to the asset itself," said Gregory Whyte, a managing director of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter who is responsible for covering commercial real estate investment trusts.
Some developers said they would refuse to build for tenants in particular industries, like e-commerce. This has not proven to be a perfect fix. In Mira Loma, a suburb of Los Angeles, there is a 750,000-square foot building outfitted like the Fingerhut warehouse in St. Cloud. ToysRUs.com put in expensive conveyer systems but never moved in, and the landlord had to find a new tenant. That new tenant, which moved in less than 18 months ago, is Kmart, a traditional retailer that has since filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 and is reorganizing.

HEADLINE: California Governor Seeking Tax Increase to Cut Shortfall 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 14 

 BODY:
After months of saying he had no intention of raising taxes, Gov. Gray Davis announced a revised budget today to reduce a $23.6 billion shortfall with the help of far-reaching spending cuts and tax increases.
 The deficit outlined by Mr. Davis, a Democrat who is up for re-election in the fall, is almost twice the figure predicted in January and equals one-third the $80 billion general budget. Mr. Davis attributed the shortfall to the decline in the stock market and the economic repercussions of Sept. 11. 
 Officials attributed much of the difference to a $19 billion drop in revenues since January 2001, some 90 percent of which was said to have come from a falloff in capital gains and stock options.
To make up for the loss, the budget for the 2002-2003 fiscal year, beginning on July 1, calls for $7.6 billion in cuts, including steep reductions in health programs and aid to local governments. 
Mr. Davis also proposed temporarily increasing vehicle license fees, which have been reduced to a third of 1998 levels and increasing cigarette taxes. In addition, he called for borrowing $4.5 billion against money that the state expects to collect from its settlement in 1998 with tobacco companies.
Republican legislators, whose support will be necessary to garner the two-thirds votes necessary to pass the budget, have warned the governor against raising taxes to balance the budget and criticized him for spending too much.
"We don't have a deficit because car owners have done something wrong," State Senator James L. Brulte, the Republican minority leader in the Senate, said. "And doubling the car tax, penalizing working Californians, simply because Gray Davis is a big spender, we don't think makes a lot of sense."
Mr. Davis defended his performance, telling reporters: "The problem is not spending. The problem is lack of revenue, given the decline in the performance of stock market. That is the heart of the problem."
He said that education remained his top priority and that he was able to meet the financing requirements of Proposition 98, which guarantees minimum levels of financing for education. The budget provides financing for enrollment growth for 80,000 students and cost-of-living adjustments for schools, as well as increasing per-pupil spending, to $7,183 from $6,618.
The budget includes $672 million for health care coverage for every eligible child, a total of 624,000 children by the end of June 2003.
For the first two years of his administration, Mr. Davis benefited from large surpluses and was able to cut taxes. But those surpluses slipped away along with the dotcoms and amid the energy crisis. The revised budget was based on April tax receipts, which were far below forecasts.
The last time that the state confronted such dire circumstances was when the shortfall reached $14 billion in 1991, an era of extensive layoffs in the aerospace industry. 
"Closing this budget gap has been an extremely difficult process," Mr. Davis said. "But the people of this state elected me for exactly this reason, to make the tough decision, and that's exactly what I've done."
The tax issue, however, is expected to lead to intense struggles as lawmakers review the plan. Under state law, the Legislature has to send a budget to the governor by June 15, a deadline that is unenforceable, however, and not frequently met.

HEADLINE: Abortion Clinic Wins a Round In a Fight Over Its New Home 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 14 

 BODY:
A clinic that performs abortions mostly for low-income women won an important if technical victory this evening in its efforts to relocate after the city's Zoning Board of Appeals refused to hear a last-ditch argument against the move by two Democrats on the City Council.
 That refusal means that the clinic, the Summit Women's Center, which opened at its new site on Main Street this morning after 25 years downtown, will stay open as it fights further appeals and possible legal action by the council members' lawyer. 
 In January 2001, the city condemned the Middle Street building from which Summit had leased space to make way for a new courthouse. But John M. Fabrizi, the Council's president, and Councilwoman Josephine Covino said they learned of the move to Ms. Covino's district only in late March, after the deadline to appeal had passed. The two officials, both Democrats, said they opposed the clinic's new location because anti-abortion demonstrators would hurt other businesses in the area and create a safety problem for the clinic's clients and neighbors. 
But tonight, the zoning board's chairman, Richard Bepko, noting the tardiness of their appeal, refused to listen to Mr. Fabrizi or his lawyer, Raymond Rizio, saying, "You're too late."
Mr. Rizio said later that he planned to change tactics by contending that the city had approved Summit's new building based on "material misrepresentations" of fact by its owner, David Lipton, and his lawyer, who dismissed the allegations as a ploy.
The clinic's move had clearly become political, with bipartisan support for it coming in letters and speeches from United States Representative Christopher Shays, a Republican from Bridgeport; Richard Blumenthal, the Democratic state attorney general; both leading Democratic candidates for governor; and several Republican and Democratic mayors and first selectmen from neighboring towns. 
Although the board's refusal to hear out Mr. Fabrizi tonight provided some breathing room for Summit and its low-income patients, the continuing dispute over its zoning permit will certainly not end the weekly protests and decades of recriminations between those on either side of the abortion debate.
"We are outraged that the center has moved and continues to operate," said Joseph McAleer, the spokesman for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport. He said Friday morning prayer vigils outside the clinic would continue at the new location. "We pray that the clinic will close, and we pray that pregnant women will realize that they have an alternative, namely adoption."
Mr. Lipton, who owns five other abortion and gynecological clinics in Hartford, Atlanta, Detroit and Alabama, welcomed a chance to move. Because the old clinic had no private entrance, protesters routinely clogged the sidewalk beside the clinic's door, shouting down or pleading with pregnant women, many of them escorted from their cars by volunteer protectors.
The new clinic, in the heart of an old but prosperous business district, occupies a two-story office building with a private, fenced-in parking lot and mirrored yellow windows.
In late March, when Summit's plans to move became public, Operation Save America, a national anti-abortion group, began organizing loud protests outside the clinic's old offices.
On April 3, the two council members filed an appeal protesting the move because, they said, the clinic did not have the proper zoning permit to perform surgical procedures like abortions. But, as Jennifer Jaff, a lawyer for the clinic, pointed out, state law exempts clinics that do not keep patients overnight. 
Summit doctors perform about 100 abortions a month, using five-minute surgical outpatient procedures, Mr. Lipton said. If the clinic closed, he said, low-income women who rely on Medicare or Medicaid would be forced to travel to Stamford or New Haven to have abortions.
This afternoon, Mr. Fabrizi admitted his appeal was based on only a technicality to keep Summit from opening in the new neighborhood, just a few blocks from the diocese's headquarters. He said his real reasons for opposing the clinic's move had to do with the negative economic and public safety consequences of moving an abortion clinic into a business district that was bound to suffer from the throngs of protesters.
"This is a very vibrant, strong, busy retail area," he said. "X amount of times a week you have to put a dozen cops out there." He said he would rather see the clinic "in a much, much less densely populated, less high-profile commercial area."

HEADLINE: Downtown Families Eligible for More Housing Aid 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Families living in Chinatown and Little Italy will be eligible for housing assistance grants of up to $750 more than previously proposed under a revised plan that is expected to be announced today, state officials said yesterday.
 The revision in the housing aid plan by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation increases to $1,750 the amount available to families in the area, which extends north from Canal Street to Delancey or Kenmare Streets and east from Lafayette Street to the East River. 
 The new benefit is similar to those already proposed for Manhattan residents who live below Canal Street. Households with at least one child under the age of 18 that have committed to remain in the area for at least one year will receive a $750 family bonus. In addition, as previously proposed, a $1,000 grant per household is available for residents who lived in the area on Sept. 11. 
The proposed revision is included in a $300 million assistance plan for people and businesses affected by the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. The final version of the plan was forwarded to the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development for approval this week, state officials said.
Sheldon Silver, the State Assembly speaker whose district includes Lower Manhattan, pushed for the changes, which were also supported by Gov. George E. Pataki, officials said. 
State officials also said the development corporation would allow owners of residential buildings in Lower Manhattan to increase rents charged to residents who receive the grants, in some cases to levels above what was charged for those apartments before Sept. 11.
The development corporation also agreed not to withhold from grants offered to Battery Park City residents the equivalent of any benefits they receive from the Battery Park City Authority related to Sept. 11. Some residents have been withholding payments due to the authority while they seek compensation for changes in the value of their apartments related to the disaster. The development corporation had previously proposed offsetting any negotiated benefits from the grants awarded to those households.

HEADLINE: Census Shows Bigger Houses And Incomes, but Not for All 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14 

 BODY:
The celebrated prosperity of the 1990's brought a surge in the size and values of homes and in family incomes, according to new Census Bureau statistics covering 13 states, including California, Illinois, Indiana, Washington and Wisconsin. Many more Americans earned college and graduate degrees, and the incomes of the elderly jumped about 60 percent. 
 But the data, covering 75 million people, or more than a quarter of the United States population, indicate that the decade's prosperity bypassed many Americans. 
 The poor gained little. Following the overhaul of the welfare system six years ago, poverty among single mothers with young children declined. But poverty among all families remained largely unchanged from its 1980 and 1990 levels, an average of 8 percent in the 13 states. To be deemed poor, a family of four in 2000 had an income less than $17,600. 
Most women's incomes rose in the decade, but men's stagnated or fell. 
"Some people did really well," said Annabel Kirschner, chairwoman of the department of rural sociology at Washington State University in Pullman. "Other people did not." Along with the poor, she said, unskilled workers fared poorly, with wages failing to keep up with the rate of inflation.
The demographic shifts disclosed today show up in the Census Bureau's so-called long form, a list of 53 questions that about one in six households nationwide filled out to supplement the less detailed Census 2000 short form, the results of which were published last year. The long form treats many issues the other did not, like income, education, home value, ancestry and divorce. 
Today the bureau released long-form data for Alaska, California, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Oregon, Montana, Wisconsin and the Dakotas. Last week it released data for Mississippi, Nevada and Washington. Data for other states will be released over the next three weeks. New York's and New Jersey's are due on Monday. 
According to the data covering the 13 states, the typical home grew in size to 5.3 rooms, from 5.1 rooms. The numbers of married people declined. The numbers of divorced people rose 30 percent, to nearly five million. Median home values surged past $100,000 in all but Mississippi and the Dakotas. Million-dollar homes sprang up around all major cities. Immigration, which the long form broke down into richer detail about origin and current residency than the first report, reached levels that altered the character of cities.
"In round numbers, two-thirds of our population growth in the 1990's was foreign-born, and two-thirds of that was Hispanic," said Max Dieber, director of research services at the Northeastern Illinois Planning Commission in Chicago.
In California, a longstanding immigration trend reversed course. The number of people moving to the state from other countries and elsewhere in the United States slowed sharply, said Andrew Reppenstein, a demographer at the state census data center in Sacramento. "California is again a state where a majority of the residents were born in the state," Mr. Reppenstein said. 
The statistics do not differentiate the decade's biggest winners -- people with large stock market gains and million-dollar salaries -- from those who were struggling just above the poverty line. Reports to be released in the fall should clarify those distinctions, but analysts today said there was little doubt that working-class Americans saw few gains for themselves.
Government programs moved low-skilled workers away from dying industries and into manufacturing jobs in new technology industries, said George Hough, demographer at the Center for Population Research and Census at Portland State University. But he said those new jobs typically paid an average of $15,000 a year. "That puts them above the poverty line," Mr. Hough said. "But what's $15,000 going to get you?"
A wide gap between the incomes of working men and women narrowed in the 1990's, the statistics show. Women's earnings rose in all 13 states except Alaska. But stagnant and declining men's wages contributed to the narrowing, too.
"This is an irritation for both groups," said Andrew Beveridge, a demographer and sociology professor at Queens College and a consultant to The New York Times, who compared 1990's and 1980's data. 
Demographers and sociologists explain that many men lost high-paid industrial and mining jobs in the 1990's. In Washington, for example, men lost thousands of logging jobs in communities where unemployment rates subsequently soared. At the same time, more and more women went to college and qualified for higher-paying jobs. For Washington men working full time, incomes barely rose, with inflation taken into account, to $40,687 a year from $40,267. In contrast, women's wages rose to $30,021 from $26,745, narrowing the gap between men's and women's wages to 26 percent less for women from 34 percent. 
In other states the gap showed similar changes. In Illinois, women earned 30 percent less than men in 1999, compared with 35 percent less in 1989. 
As a result of more women in the work force, median family incomes rose, typically about 10 percent, to more than $50,000 a year in most of the states. One exception was California. There, the number of women working full time slipped to 51.3 percent from 53.4 percent, and the median family income rose only $385 in 10 years, to $53,025. 
Mr. Beveridge's calculations also show that poverty levels hardly changed over two decades, even though the welfare overhaul moved the largest group of those on welfare -- single mothers -- into the work force. Percentages of families deemed poor were roughly consistent with the percentages of those on welfare -- about 8 percent in the 13 states. One state showing a clear decline in poverty was the poorest of the 13, Mississippi. There, 16 percent of families fell below the poverty line, down from 20 percent in 1990. 
For the better-off, middle-class, home-owning Americans, mortgage payments typically grew more than incomes. In Illinois, the median income grew 14.8 percent in two decades, Mr. Beveridge's analysis shows, while mortgage payments grew 38.7 percent. 
For those over 65, however, incomes grew, in part because Social Security payments are tied to inflation and in part because of stock market gains they were able to reap. As a result, poverty among the elderly dropped in nearly all the states. In Indiana, for example, poverty in this group dropped from 10.7 percent in 1990 to 7.7 percent in 2000; in Washington, it dropped from 11.3 percent to 9.5 percent.

HEADLINE: For China's Wealthy, All but Fruited Plain 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: PINGHU, China 

 BODY:
Li Qinfu, snapping his fingers to emphasize the points he is making, races his purple Lamborghini toward what looks like the United States Capitol rising above the canola fields south of Shanghai.
 As he turns into the manicured grounds surrounding the domed marble building, a slightly smaller copy of Washington's own, he points to the pinnacle. There, instead of the original's Statue of Freedom, stands an 18-foot, three-ton bronze likeness of himself, right hand raised as if beckoning to the future. 
 "It would have been too dangerous to cast the hand waving with the palm turned out," he said, referring to the gesture that is still reserved for statues of Mao here.
Mr. Li, at 40 one of China's wealthiest private businessmen, is well aware of the suspicion with which the new super-rich are regarded here and of the symbolism of his politically inspired edifice and effigy high in the air. 
While the Communist Party publicly embraces capitalists these days, inviting them in a controversial decision last July to join the party, it is still trying to restrain the emergence of a wealthy class.
The party worries that the disparity between rich and poor is potentially dangerous in a country where, according to Lu Zhiqiang, a senior government official addressing the Asian Development Bank recently, 70 percent of citizens feel that the fast-growing gap threatens social stability. Bold displays of riches are rare.
Yet, try as the government might to keep capitalists from amassing huge amounts of capital, people like Mr. Li, whose money comes from printing and garment manufacturing joint ventures with a Japanese company, are beginning to blip onto the world's wealth radar screens.
There are now thousands of multimillionaires in China, and the super-rich have reached such critical mass that Forbes compiles a list, however imperfect and incomplete, of the country's wealthiest individuals. Mr. Li ranks 71st, though he asserts that his true ranking is much higher. 
Last year, No. 5, a Shanghai real estate developer, stunned tycoon-thick Hong Kong by paying $30 million for the territory's most ostentatious house, an unheard-of public show of wealth by a mainland businessman.
Mr. Li, who estimates his wealth at hundreds of millions of dollars, is also not afraid to show his money, though he steers clear of Chinese reporters. Besides his Lamborghini, which he said cost him about half a million dollars after paying China's exorbitant import duty, he owns a Bentley, two Mercedes-Benzes, several BMW's and a fleet of Japanese luxury cars. 
The Pinghu Capitol houses the headquarters of his manufacturing operation, complete with showrooms and spacious offices for designers and executives. His Shanghai offices are like a five-star hotel occupying a three-floor glass cube atop one of the city's tallest new office towers. From the Jacuzzi in his private gym he can survey booming Shanghai below.
A forest of bureaucratic barriers and government prejudices make the accumulation of such vast wealth difficult, even risky. One reason is the government's fear that without restraint, the population could slip back into the stark disparity that marked China in the 1930's and 1940's, when a very few enjoyed inordinate wealth amid a sea of poverty.
The government report presented to the Asian Development Bank conference says China now has one of the world's greatest wealth gaps, from almost none 20 years ago. 
But a more immediate concern is that wealth begets political power, which the Communist Party is loath to share.
Mr. Li, wearing a tailored black suit from one of his own factories, lifted his hands repeatedly off the Lamborghini's wheel and touched his wrists together, miming a man in handcuffs, as he listed fellow entrepreneurs who have ended up in jail.
"They all ran into trouble when their wealth grew too great," he said, adding that he had been far more careful in acquiring his riches. For example, he said he was scrupulous about separating personal from corporate assets and paid taxes in three countries: China, Japan and the United States.
Mr. Li believes that the Communist Party is misguided in its effort to suppress the upper reaches of society to keep glaring social inequalities to a minimum. 
"It does help social stability, but only in the short term," he said later over a glass of expensive Bordeaux in one of his private dining rooms. "In the long term it will hurt China."
He suggests that a more democratic political system would be a better way to ease the social pressures, and worries that without one the slow polarization of Chinese society can spell trouble. "In a one-party country everything looks peaceful," he said, "but when there's a problem, it's a big problem."
Meanwhile, the widening wealth gap is good for the economy, he argues, because it creates incentive among the masses to better their lot. "The current problem is that there's isn't enough competition and people aren't worried," he said.
His own career tracks China's slow march from a Stalinist state back toward a market economy.
The eldest of five children born to a farmer and raised not far from his mock Capitol, he vowed to devote his life to the Communist Party as a red-neckerchiefed member of the Young Pioneers, the organization that nurtures future party members.
"We spent our days in bayonet practice," he recalled.
A decade later, he was fired from an electric fan workshop for, he said, "advocating capitalism."
Then, in 1983, he took advantage of sweeping economic reforms under Deng Xiaoping that let individuals take over government-owned enterprises and run them as quasi-private businesses if they guaranteed the government a fixed return.
Mr. Li, then 21, promised to pay the local government $240 a year for the right to operate a defunct textile factory. As part of the deal he was obliged to keep all of the factory's 40-odd employees. But he could keep any profits after paying the local government its annual fee.
He started with $60 in savings making polyester shirts and pants that were then in huge demand in Beijing and Shanghai among an urban population eager to cast off the faded cotton clothes of the Cultural Revolution. He netted more than $7,000 the first year.
"There was a lot of pressure," he said. "If I didn't do well the officials would give me trouble, but if I did well they'd also give me trouble."
By 1988 the government had ratcheted its annual rent on the business up to $24,000, but the factory was still earning double that, so the government took it back, making him an employee.
"In America the law is bigger than any leader, but in China the leaders are bigger than the law," he said.
After that, he looked outward for help. 
He found a Japanese partner for the factory and in 1990 formed a joint venture that began making uniforms for Japanese companies. In 1993 he and his new Japanese backers started a high-quality printing business.
Last year, after taking the Chinese side of the garment joint venture public, Mr. Li bought the local government's share for $15 million. His Capitol-inspired headquarters was built on the site of the original factory.
He is vague about how the few million yuan he saved as contractor of the factory multiplied so much in just a few years, but says he and his businesses are debt-free. 
Today he owns 30 percent of a group of companies that include the biggest supplier of company uniforms to Japan -- where most employees of many companies wear uniforms -- and China's biggest printer of airline tickets and receipts for payments of the value-added tax, a kind of sales tax.
"It's like printing money," he said, stopping by one of the print shops to watch the machines whir.
Despite his political views, Mr. Li did not arrive at such wealth without plenty help from government officials, though he will not name benefactors.
"In China you have to have relations with the government," he said. When state-owned enterprises want to do something, he said, the government clears the way, but for private companies, he added, holding up his hand like a cop stopping traffic, "we still need a lot of approvals."
He says he spends most of his time petitioning the government or entertaining officials to win permits or understand policies that frequently change and are often not made public.
Though he is not a party member, his wife is, and he is a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Congress, an advisory body to the central government made up mostly of prominent non-Communists. Friends say he is being courted for membership in the National People's Congress, the country's largely ineffectual parliament.
"If you want to succeed you have to socialize with powerful people," he explained while showing a guest around the club on his company premises, which includes Japanese and Italian restaurants, karaoke rooms where guests can snuggle with hired hostesses, and a bathhouse that offers massages.
"Those people won't go out to a restaurant or come to your office, so you have to have a place like this," Mr. Li said.
On the road back to Shanghai, he was pestered by bankers. "Give me three more points and I'll deposit 30 million," he barked into a tiny cellphone.
He says he never borrows from them, but because China's private businessmen remain largely hidden, bankers and brokers are two of the most important sources of information about his peers.
He parks the Lamborghini at his villa in a new compound of closely packed homes on the edge of Shanghai and switches to his purring Bentley. Later, in his offices high above Shanghai, he straightens oil paintings on the wall. One is a portrait of himself in early 19th-century European dress striking a Byronic pose. On an adjacent wall hangs a painting of Napoleon.
But among the snapshots of Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, former President George Bush and King Abdullah II of Jordan posing with Mr. Li is one small black-and-white photograph of his family in 1963, wearing padded peasant garb and sitting on crude bamboo furniture in front of a rickety farmhouse.
His trajectory from that humble beginning is aimed at steering him clear of the turmoil that marked his early years. Though he travels on a Chinese passport, half of his wealth is invested abroad. His 16-year-old son lives in a Manhattan apartment near the United Nations with a chaperon and a chauffeur to ferry him to a private school in Scarsdale.
Said Mr. Li, "He prefers it there."

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Court Lacks Last Word In Aid to Religious Schools

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein 

 BODY:
THE Supreme Court will soon decide if public money can pay for tuition at private religious schools. Advocates and opponents of vouchers await the ruling with great excitement or dread. But the decision may be less important than they think. 
 Whatever the ruling, constitutional policy will change little because the government already supports religious schools by providing them with busing, textbooks and remedial aid. Tax policy helps as well, because donations are deductible. 
 Last year's federal tax cut also included credits for private (including religious) school fees. Arizona and Pennsylvania have their own tax breaks for charities that subsidize such fees. Other states are weighing similar plans.
But the main reason the court's ruling will have little impact is that private schools' attraction as a way to improve education is beginning to wane. A decade ago many policy makers believed that private education was less bureaucratic and that competition for students would spur all schools to improve. They thought that poor and minority students in particular would achieve more if they could go to private schools.
But evidence is now accumulating that privatization is no simple answer. Consider the urban Roman Catholic schools that sometimes post higher scores than nearby public ones. Recent carefully controlled studies have more ambiguous results than expected. In New York City, black students gained 5.5 percentile points in math and reading, on average, after being offered subsidies to attend private (mostly Catholic) schools for three years. Some grade levels gained more, others less. Yet in Washington, black students gained nothing over all. Hispanics gained nothing in either city.
These murky results are not surprising. Catholic schools and public ones face similar problems, like poor academic support from disadvantaged parents. Catholic-school teachers, paid less than those in public schools, are often as unqualified as the least-prepared public-school teachers. Even where Catholic-school teachers are nonunion, firing bad teachers is almost as hard as in public schools. It is never easy to replace teachers if adequate replacements cannot be found. Also, Catholic-school administrators usually follow due process in evaluating teachers, making terminations for less than blatant malfeasance unlikely.
Charter schools -- run like private schools but technically public -- have also been no panacea. Some charters have higher scores than comparable regular schools, but others do not. Some states are now tightening charter laws because achievement has declined in some charter schools.
The high cost of private education also shows why it may not be the wave of the future. The most prestigious private schools serving affluent families charge far more than public agencies can pay. In addition, private schools have not shown that they can adequately serve lower-income students for the amount public schools spend.
Edison Schools Inc., for example, the nation's largest for-profit school chain, was founded in 1992 to create private schools that produced better results at less cost than public schools. Its officers thought public schools wasted money on bureaucracy, so Edison could still profit by cutting administrators and charging less tuition than public schools spent.
But Edison could not design a system that cost less than public education. Now, when the company contracts with districts to operate regular schools, it charges the full amount that public schools spend. Ironically, Edison asserts that even at this price the company is unprofitable because its administrative costs are too high. Its officers say the company must now expand, by adding more schools, to gain economies of scale that will reduce the per-pupil cost of bureaucracy.
Yet with 75,000 students, Edison is already one of the nation's largest school systems. When a public district gets this big, it often becomes less efficient, not more. For example, a superintendent can no longer supervise each principal, so new layers of oversight are needed. The most efficient districts probably have about 20,000 students.
In the long run, private education will grow only if it yields high achievement more efficiently than public schooling, especially for disadvantaged children. Private schools may be unwilling to subject themselves to this test. In Milwaukee, for example, a city whose vouchers' continuation will depend on the Supreme Court ruling, a requirement that private schools report test scores for voucher students was dropped after advocates of vouchers objected.
Demonstrating higher achievement at less cost may not be impossible, but is more difficult than it once seemed. The Supreme Court's decision cannot enhance the quality of this evidence.

HEADLINE: Edison Schools In Settlement With S.E.C. 

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES and JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
Edison Schools, the nation's largest commercial operator of public schools and a pioneer in the field of for-profit school management, provided inaccurate information about its past revenue and maintained inadequate financial controls, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday.
 The commission also disclosed that Edison had agreed to a settlement with the commission that requires the company, which did not admit or deny any wrongdoing, to revise the way it reports its revenue and to hire an internal audit manager to strengthen its financial procedures. No financial penalties were imposed by the S.E.C., which noted that Edison had fully cooperated with its inquiry. 
 The commission's announcement came less than half an hour before -- and effectively upstaged -- a conference call by Edison executives that was intended to reassure investors, educators and parents that a recent steep decline in Edison's stock price would not derail the company's plans to take over 20 failing schools in Philadelphia this summer or impair its nationwide operations. 
In that call, Edison's founder and chief executive, H. Christopher Whittle, reported that the company was in serious discussions to raise $30 million to $50 million from an investor whose identity he could not yet disclose. "Our hope is to conclude this within the next few weeks," Mr. Whittle said. He noted, in a later interview, that the company had long been successful at attracting capital over the years, but acknowledged that the recent 85 percent decline in its stock price and the apparent erosion in investor confidence pose a special challenge.
Mr. Whittle also announced that, after the coming school year, the company would sharply scale back its pace of growth, from more than 60 percent a year to about 30 percent, so that it could both reduce the amount of cash it consumes and move toward making a profit. Under contracts with school districts and charter schools, Edison educates about 75,000 children in 22 states. 
At the heart of the S.E.C.'s complaint is the fact that Edison, which has dazzled investors with the pace of its revenue growth but has never made a profit, had not disclosed that about half of its reported revenue actually consisted of money that its client school districts paid to others -- teachers, bus companies and cafeteria vendors, for example -- on Edison's behalf. 
For example, of roughly $376 million in revenue that Edison reported for the fiscal year that ended last June, $154 million had never actually landed in Edison's bank account. But because Edison also included those district-paid amounts in its own expenses, its revenue-reporting policy had no effect on its profits -- or, more accurately, its losses.
By failing to disclose "that a substantial portion of its reported revenues consist of payments that never reach Edison," the commission said, Edison's financial reports "have not provided accurate disclosure regarding significant aspects of Edison's business." Edison promised that it would clearly separate district-paid expenses from revenue in the future.
In settling the complaint, Edison also agreed to revise some of its previous financial reports to lower its reported revenue on a handful of its school contracts. For example, its total revenue for the fiscal year that ended last June will shrink about 7 percent, to $350.5 million from $375.8 million. 
Similar shrinkage will occur in the revenue amounts Edison reported for the 1998, 1999 and 2000 fiscal years, while revenue reported for the first half of the current fiscal year, which ends next month, will contract by about 11 percent.
Mr. Whittle apologized yesterday for the S.E.C. investigation and its consequences. Because Edison, which he called "the most scrutinized school system in the country," stands "at the vanguard of an important movement," it needs to "be right 100 percent of the time," he said.
And in this case, he said, Edison and its auditors, PricewaterhouseCoopers, thought the company had been reporting revenue correctly. Indeed, the S.E.C. acknowledged that Edison's accounting treatment of the district-paid expenses did not violate generally accepted accounting principles.
But Wayne M. Carlin, regional director of the commission's New York office, said that Edison's case showed that "technical compliance" with those general principles "will not insulate an issuer from enforcement action if it makes filings with the commission that mischaracterize its business, or omit significant information."
Mr. Whittle's comments yesterday were in sharp contrast to his aggressive defense of the company's revenue-recognition policies in mid-February, when those policies were questioned by Bloomberg News. In fact, Edison reported at that time that any other accounting treatment "would be incorrect and misleading."
But Edison executives, in response to questions by several Wall Street analysts during the conference call yesterday, stoutly defended their decision not to disclose the existence of the S.E.C. inquiry until yesterday. Edison's chairman, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the former president of Yale University and former dean of the Columbia University law school, said in an interview last night that it was "extremely difficult and dangerous, if not impossible" to clearly define the scope of an S.E.C. inquiry before it is concluded.
"Putting that out into the market just gives free rein for people to assume the absolute worst," Mr. Schmidt said. Instead, he said, the company decided to refrain from disclosing its negotiations with the S.E.C. until all the details and consequences could be disclosed as well. 
Edison's announcement of the settlement came almost immediately after the S.E.C.'s.
And almost as an afterthought to yesterday's crowded agenda, Edison announced its financial results for the first three months of this year, the third quarter of its fiscal year. It reported that its revenue -- presented as the S.E.C. desired -- had increased 31 percent, to $121.9 million, over the period last year. But in part because of a $6.8 million write-down in the value of Edison's investment in Apex Learning, a company that offers advanced placement courses online, Edison's losses totaled $16.9 million.
That translates to a loss of 31 cents a share, about 10 cents more than analysts had expected.
But the analysts focused most of their questions yesterday on Edison's Philadelphia contract. Last month, the state panel assigned to oversee the troubled Philadelphia system voted to assign Edison 20 schools -- 25 fewer than what some state officials, as well as Edison itself, had led investors to expect. A succession of downgrades of Edison by analysts followed, and the value of the company's stock plunged from nearly $13 a share in early April to less than $3 last week. It closed yesterday at $2.94, up 28 cent, and rose to more than $3.50 in after-hours trading.
Last night, acknowledging the analysts' disappointment in the Philadelphia decision and the apparent erosion of investor confidence, Mr. Whittle said, "We managed to take our greatest win and turn it into an expectation defeat."
The company could pick up several additional schools -- though far from the 25 more it is seeking -- as soon as this afternoon, when the state panel meets in Philadelphia.
But even so, after the coming school year, Edison intends to slow its pursuit of new contracts across the country, Mr. Whittle told the analysts. Some of them questioned whether this pullback would delay Edison's achievement of profitability, which it has long said was dependent on rapidly achieving economies of scale.
Mr. Whittle, however, insisted that slower growth would actually hasten the company's ability to turn a profit because it would be able to reduce high start-up costs involved in opening new schools, and invest in management improvements that would further reduce its headquarter expenses.
Those overhead costs grew in the third quarter, both in absolute dollars and as a percent of revenues, totaling nearly $54 million so far in the current fiscal year, compared with less than $39 million in the comparable period last year.
Adam Feild, the company's chief financial officer, blamed higher legal and accounting expenses the company incurred in dealing with the S.E.C. investigation and the protracted negotiations in Philadelphia for some of the growth in headquarter expenses.

HEADLINE: Senecas Vote to Approve Plans for 2 Casinos 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

DATELINE: CATTARAUGUS INDIAN RESERVATION, May 14 

 BODY:
Members of the Seneca Nation of Indians in western New York voted 1,077 to 976 today in favor of two proposed casinos for Buffalo and Niagara Falls, and the hundreds of millions of dollars they are expected to bring.
 The casino compact between the Seneca Nation and the state must still overcome legal challenges and pass a federal review, but approval by the nation overcomes a major hurdle. The closely contested vote today drew Senecas from as far away as Florida and Virginia. "The people sent us out to do this, and we went out and did it," said Cyrus M. Schindler, the nation's president, who was elected two years ago on a pro-casino platform. 
 The compact could bring as much as $4 billion to the tribe over the 14-year life of the agreement, tribal officials say. The state, which would take a portion of the proceeds from slot machines at the two casinos, stands to make $300 million to $400 million a year from the Seneca casinos plus four others that are planned, according to a spokeswoman for Gov. George E. Pataki, and would give 25 percent of that money to the casinos' host cities. Some of the money would also be used to treat gambling addicts, said the spokeswoman, Suzanne Morris.
An expansion of gambling faced stiff opposition in the State Legislature, particularly in the Republican-led Senate. But with the harsh fiscal realities brought on by Sept. 11, resistance melted away, and last October, lawmakers passed a bill allowing the governor to negotiate compacts for six casinos, three in western New York and three in the Catskills. The bill also allowed video lottery terminals at racetracks and participation in a multistate lottery, with tickets going on sale Wednesday. The governor has argued that casinos are a badly needed pump for the upstate economy, and that New York is losing revenue to Canada and to other states that permit gambling.
The promise of gambling riches has also proved to be a strong lure within the Seneca Nation. The tribal council ran television and newspaper advertisements urging a yes vote, promising that money from the casino would pay for better education, housing, health care, pensions for tribal elders and even a sewage treatment plant. It would also, the council promised, provide each Seneca with a regular check.
But there is no specific plan now for how to use the gambling windfall. "The possibilities are open," said Richard E. Nephew, a member of the tribal council who owns a smoke shop. "There's just so much." 
Mr. Nephew stood in pro-casino headquarters on Route 438 near the polling site. The rented house was hung with 'Vote Yes' banners and bustling with Senecas helping themselves to heaping plates of baked chicken.
But down the road, the Wolf's Run smoke shop and diner offered corn soup and fry bread to those who voted no. Sally Snow, the owner, sniffed out indecision in a customer, Frank Guite, 52, a construction contractor who had come from Virginia Beach. Half his family disapproved of the casino, he admitted, but the other half wanted to know how soon they could board the bus.
"Gambling is one of the worst sins we can commit as traditional Iroquois people," Ms. Snow told him. The casino proponents, she said, were greedy, and the compact with the state would compromise, not increase, the tribe's sovereignty.

HEADLINE: Contemporary-Art Auction Sets Records for 15 Artists 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
"Who wants to die with money in the stock market when you can have Rothkos on your walls?" a collector asked as he was leaving Christie's sale of postwar and contemporary art last night.
 Not many, at least among the standing-room-only crowd of collectors, dealers and curiosity-seekers who crowded the Rockefeller Center salesroom. The 90-minute sale broke records for 15 artists, including Jean-Michel Basquiat, Donald Judd, Louise Bourgeois and Ed Ruscha. 
 For the first time since November 1997, Christie's put its postwar and contemporary artworks together in one sale, and it was a buoyant evening. Of the 67 works, 56 sold. The sale totaled $46.9 million, just under its high estimate of $47 million. 
"It was just amazing," said a dazed Christopher Burge, honorary chairman of Christie's in America and the evening's auctioneer. "It was fast and furious. I was fielding bids from all over the room. I'm completely exhausted."
The two top sellers last night, both paintings, were being sold by Lars Ulrich, the songwriter and drummer for the band Metallica. Of five works he was selling, Jean-Michel Basquiat's "Profit I" (1982), a dark canvas dominated by a skeletal black man, was the most popular. Two determined bidders fought for the painting, estimated at $3 million to $5 million. It sold to an anonymous telephone bidder for $5.5 million, a record for the artist.
Mr. Ulrich was also selling Dubuffet's "Paris Montparnasse" (1961). Five bidders tried to buy the large, dense painting, which brought $4.7 million, far above its high estimate of $3.5 million. The buyer was David Gray, the Chicago dealer.
(Final prices include Christie's new commission: 19.5 percent of the first $100,000 and 10 percent of the rest. Estimates do not reflect commissions.)
Sculpture has brought high prices for several seasons and last night was no exception. An untitled 1967 monumental stainless steel and plexiglas wall piece by Donald Judd was estimated at $3 million to $4 million. The seller was Irving Blum, the California dealer, who was to sell the work at Christie's in November but got cold feet after Sept. 11.
Those days seemed far away last night. Two bidders vied for the Judd, which sold to a telephone bidder for $4.6 million. The price eclipsed the artist's previous record, set just the night before when another 1967 wall piece sold at Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg for $1.3 million. There was much speculation about the buyer; many art experts believed him to be Francois Pinault, the luxury goods magnate who owns Christie's.
Mr. Pinault certainly was a seller last night, offering a group of Louise Bourgeois sculptures identified in the catalog as coming from a private collection. The artist's "Blind Man's Buff" (1984), an abstract marble sculpture of rounded shapes resembling udders, was estimated at $600,000 to $800,000. James Cohan, a Manhattan dealer, wrestled the sculpture away from three other bidders for $1.4 million, a record for the artist. After the sale, Christie's executives said Mr. Cohan had bought it for an American institution, but they declined to say which one.
Pop Art brought strong prices, as it has all spring. Andy Warhol's "Four-Foot Flowers" (1964) was being sold by the auction house, which owned the silkscreen. Estimated at $1.8 million to $2.2 million, it sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $3.7 million. Phillips sold another version of the image on Monday night for $2.2 million.
Christie's also had three Pop works from the 1960's from the collection of Reinhard Onnasch, a Berlin real estate developer, dealer and collector. Mr. Onnasch bought the works from 1970 to 1974.
Mr. Ruscha's "Talk About Space" (1963), a takeoff on the American billboard in which a single word is the subject, was expected to sell for $1.5 million to $2 million. Five bidders went for the painting, which sold for $3.5 million, a record for the artist. At Phillips on Monday night, another one-word painting executed by Mr. Ruscha in the same year brought $2.5 million.
A collage by Tom Wesselmann, "Great American Nude No 44" (1963), also from Mr. Onnasch, was expected to fetch $600,000 to $800,000. Four people tried to buy the collage, which depicts a naked woman standing in a colorful living room with a bright red wall telephone hung against a bright blue wall. It sold to Maxwell Davidson, a Manhattan dealer, for $944,500, another artist's record.
Roy Lichtenstein's "Red Barn 1" (1969), a Pop version of a quaint American barn set in a bucolic landscape, was estimated at $1.4 million to $1.8 million, A telephone bidder paid $2.4 million.
As the audience was leaving Christie's, many were trying to make sense of the market. Some believed that in this shaky economy, putting money in art may be a sounder way to go, and a more enjoyable one.
"There was a bit more money floating around," said Anthony d'Offay, the London dealer. "Everything was strong."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jean-Michel Basquiat's "Profit I" (1982), the highest-price work at Christie's last night, selling for $5.5 million. (Christie's)

HEADLINE: THE NEWARK ELECTION: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
As Civil Rights Battles Recede, Generational Fights Replace Them

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LEZIN JONES 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 14 

 BODY:
Thirty-five years ago, this striving city still digging itself out of the rubble of riot -- played host to one of the first national conferences on black power. The theme of the conference was simple: energizing a sometimes passive electorate and positioning black candidates to run for elective offices dominated by a white establishment. 
 It is a curious bit of symmetry that the mayoral election here today represented a different kind of quandary -- the struggle for power between one generation of African-American politicians and another. 
 With his victory in today's fiercely contested race against City Councilman Cory Booker, Mayor Sharpe James did more than just withstand an assault on one of the Northeast's most entrenched political machines. 
In a larger sense, he also circumvented deep rifts within the black political establishment that have further heralded the emergence of a new wave of black leaders, born after the civil rights movement, who are often the beneficiaries of the struggles fought by the leaders they now seek to unseat.
To be sure, the forces at work here were not novel. Cities across the nation have seen the vanguard of emerging young black leaders gently -- or sometimes not so gently -- nudging their elders away from center stage. And the political dynamic in Newark was certainly not as portentous as it was three decades ago.
But the bitterness and vitriol that characterized the contest between Mr. James and Mr. Booker highlighted the continuing evolution of black political power and the internecine tensions between the established forces that wield it and those who seek to claim it.
"The natural order of things is for the young to replace the old," said David A. Bositis, a senior political analyst with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, who has compiled a 30-year study of black elected officials. "There comes a time when even if old black leaders don't necessarily want to leave power, nature reminds them it's time to go." 
For Mr. James, now, at least, it's not that time. Although Mr. Booker tried to rouse the electorate by charging that the steps Newark had made toward economic revitalization had not been significant enough, voters disagreed. Mr. Booker, 33, raised in suburban Bergen County with an Ivy League pedigree, had sought to tap into that sense of dissatisfaction and of a mission incomplete among many here.
Voters, however, agreed with Mr. James, 66, who countered by pointing out the strides that the city made after it was torn by the riots of the summer of 1967 and asked, after 32 years in political office -- 16 of them as mayor -- for more time to finish the job.
He also won a fifth term as mayor by playing on a sort of xenophobia and civic chauvinism among Newark residents, who turned away a candidate that Mr. James had described as a carpetbagger, even though he grew up only two counties away.
Mr. James also played upon internal ethnic conflicts, as well as class and social differences among many blacks in the still troubled city. He questioned whether the upper-middle-class Mr. Booker could effectively relate to -- and by extension, govern -- the residents of a city that is still gripped by stunning poverty in many neighborhoods. 
That message was a risky one for Mr. James in a changing Newark where the old rules of ethnic politics -- as played by Mr. James's generation -- may no longer apply. "Newark is increasingly a city that cannot be explained simply by a black-white social calculus," said Clement A. Price, a history professor at Rutgers University-Newark who has closely followed the campaign.
Still, though, in this city, which is just over half black and nearly a third Latino, the support of those ethnic groups has historically gone to Mr. James, and there were few indications heading into today's election that that would change.
Mr. James also played up his record as a civil rights advocate and pointed to the support that Mr. Booker had received from whites and those outside Newark to bolster his claims that the councilman was beholden to some who might try to exploit the city. 
Mr. Booker said Mr. James's long stint at the helm of the sometimes cumbersome gears of the city's political machine made the prospect of rapid or significant change unlikely.
Those perspectives represented generational differences between the old and new black political guards that may become only more pronounced as both generations age.
"What makes these generational differences so striking is that there was a time when the difference between the young politician and the old politician was just age," Mr. Bositis said. "Now you have different experiences and different viewpoints."
Despite those differences, however, both candidates share similar core beliefs -- a concern for civil rights and social justice and a belief in using government to improve the lives of their black African-American constituents.
And although Mr. James's resume as a civil rights crusader in the 1960's still carried great weight with today's electorate, its significance may be diminishing.
"To people from the segregated South, the oppressor was the white world," Mr. Bositis said. "When they were growing up, there were very few black Americans who were embraced by the white world. So it's very easy to slip into the 'Cory Booker is white-centered' or 'Conservatives have brought him in.'
"But, let's face it, in another 20 years you're not going to find another black politician who will have had the experience of segregation, even in the South."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Priceline Cuts Ties With Hill, Holliday

BYLINE:  By Bill Carter and Jim Rutenberg 

 BODY:
Priceline.com said yesterday that it had ended its relationship with Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston after almost three years. Priceline, the online seller of discount travel services like airline tickets, will handle its own advertising. 
Last year, it spent about $40 million on advertising, according to the CMR division of Taylor Nelson Sofres.
 Brian Ek, a spokesman for Priceline in Norwalk, Conn., confirmed a report of the decision in the online edition of Adweek. He declined to discuss the reason, as did Eileen O'Connor, a spokeswoman at Hill, Holliday, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The company's recent radio commercials, however, were produced internally by Priceline. 
 Hill, Holliday created the humorous commercials for Priceline featuring the actor William Shatner, who will continue to appear in the campaign, Mr. Ek said.

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
A New Tale Of 2 Cities, But Both Are Newark

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
MONDAY night's rain had cut attendance at Sharpe James's pre-election rally to 200, from the planned 2,000. There was extra food and an extra-loud band, and anxiety rippled through the paltry crowd in the cavernous bus garage that had been cleared out for the event. "I'm surprised there's not more people," one woman said nervously.
 Mr. James seemed as if he couldn't care less. "We complained about the drought," he said. "The Lord gave us rain." 
 It sounded like something a politician might say on the eve of being washed up. Then the band played: "Don't worry about today. With Sharpe James, it's gonna be all right."
It sounded like a song the band might play the night before things would not turn out all right. Mr. James, wearing a wool hat that said "Newark," danced a little, spinning a few supporters across the garage floor. Then he said good night to the crowd with final instructions for the morning: "Early to rise, early to polls. Back to pull more votes."
Mr. James, chased by a younger, more energetic challenger, was perfect for the part of the older, wily warrior. This was his ninth election for city government, and while Cory Booker, a one-term councilman, had given him a surprising scare in a vicious contest, Mr. James was careful to show no fear. The election had long ago turned from political to personal.
"He wants to run the largest city in New Jersey without any experience," Mr. James said Monday night. "We have a right to be offended by this."
Mr. James was more offended than anyone. He was one of the black politicians who emerged after the 1967 riots to lead the wounded city. He beat Kenneth Gibson, the city's first black mayor, in 1986. He built a political machine like the city has not seen in a generation, one that was singed, but not engulfed by corruption. And he has overseen the beginning of a rebirth of Newark, which is far from complete.
Not only did Mr. Booker -- half his age at 33 -- not pay proper homage, but he represented a challenge to the perception of Newark that was Mr. James's legacy.
There were many conflicts at work in the election. Machine versus insurgent. Young versus old. Political fixture versus newcomer. But one of the most bitter divides was between the inside perception that Newark has pulled itself back onto its feet, and the outside perception that Newark is still reeling from the devastation of the riots 35 years ago.
THAT outsider view was the subtext of much of the national attention focused on Mr. Booker: What's a nice, bright guy like this doing in a city like that?
In his lighter moments, the attention drawn by his opponent drove Mr. James to humor. At a rally a few weeks ago, Mr. James compared Mr. Booker's golden resume with his own recent award as New Jersey's best mayor. "What does that make me, chopped liver and chitlins?" he asked, mixing shtick with soul.
It also drove Mr. James to crank up his political apparatus for one more victory.
Mr. Booker battled impressively against Newark's parochial politics. "That's the way it always is in Newark," said Allison Burgess, a crossing guard on Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, on Monday afternoon. "If you're not from here, you're not supposed to be here controlling anything."
Mr. James's victory, no matter how he casts it, was not a vote for one perception over the other. The facts are the facts. Crime is down and construction is up, but the city is beset by high unemployment for adults, low birth weight for infants and high dropout rates for teenagers. The Hayes Homes, public housing projects that stood opposite the police station where the riots started, are long gone, replaced by 206 town houses. But Springfield Avenue, the commercial district that was looted and burned in the riots, still has long vacant stretches.
In victory last night, Mr. James was suddenly above the fray of the election that had threatened him. "Tomorrow, we must come together to continue to rebuild our city," he said. "This election was not about Sharpe James; it was about the future of Newark."
But yesterday afternoon, with the polls still open, the election was about the future of Sharpe James.
"One side is going to win, and one side is going to lose," Mr. James said, at a final campaign stop. But just in case anyone thought he had become philosophical with his legacy in the balance, he added one last emphatic thought: "We're going to be the ones that win."
