HEADLINE: Study Finds an Oversupply of Neonatal Doctors 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 15 

 BODY:
A study of death rates among newborns finds strikingly few differences from region to region and suggests that far too many doctors and hospital units specialize in intensive care of premature or sickly babies.
 Only newborns in areas with the very fewest specialists die at a higher rate than elsewhere. But once a certain threshold of care is reached, having more doctors offers no advantage, the study says. 
 The researchers said this oversupply was not only a waste of medical resources but might even be harmful, because it might subject babies to unnecessary tests and treatments.
The findings "raise disturbing issues regarding the nation's unquestioning acceptance that more is always better with respect to the supply of specialist physicians and hospital technology," said Dr. Kevin Grumbach, a public health researcher at the University of California at San Francisco, who wrote an editorial to accompany the findings, to be published Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine.
The researchers, at Dartmouth Medical School in Hanover, N.H., found that areas where the supply of neonatal specialists ranged widely -- from 4.3 to 11.6 per 10,000 births -- all had about the same newborn death rates. Even the most premature babies were found to die at roughly the same rate in these areas. The supply of neonatal intensive-care hospital beds made no difference in death rates around the country.
"Enough may be enough," said Dr. David Goodman, the pediatrician who led the study.
The neonatal-care specialty has boomed since the 1970's, thanks to new technology and therapies, including ventilators designed for premature newborns and prenatal drugs that help fetuses' lungs develop. But the researchers suggested that social and economic factors had expanded the field beyond pure medical need. For doctors, the specialty can be gratifying, exciting and well-paying. For hospitals, it is a lucrative and prestigious business.
Because of the oversupply, the researchers said, some relatively healthy newborns may be subjected to unneeded tests and treatments that could prove harmful.
"If I have a healthy full-term baby, I actually don't want anyone messing around with that baby," Dr. Grumbach said. "There's a downside where we meddle too much."

HEADLINE: ADMITTING ERRORS, ARAFAT PROMISES WAVE OF REFORM 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: RAMALLAH, West Bank, May 15 

 BODY:
Yasir Arafat responded today to growing Palestinian and international pressure for reform by acknowledging mistakes and promising changes to his administration and new elections, though he presented scant details.
 But his pledges to move ahead with reforms were unlikely to sway an Israeli government and army convinced that no promises from Mr. Arafat are credible. 
 A senior Israeli military official said today in Washington that the Bush administration's plans to send George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, to the region were pointless because Israel would never trust any Palestinian security force controlled by Mr. Arafat, even one that Mr. Tenet helped build. Page A12. 
The Palestinian leader spoke a day after Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel demanded reform as a condition for negotiations. But Mr. Arafat appeared to be responding more to American pressure and to a rising clamor among Palestinians for change, including elections and improvements in fighting corruption, in separation of powers and in civil freedoms. Many long-simmering frustrations are suddenly boiling over.
"This is the right time for change and reform, despite all the attempts to undermine our efforts," Mr. Arafat said in a speech here to the Palestinian Legislative Council. "This is the time for work, for building."
The speech fell on the annual Palestinian commemoration of the Nakba, or catastrophe, as they call the 1948 declaration of Israeli independence in what they consider their homeland. A year ago, thousands of Palestinians demonstrated in downtown Ramallah. Today, perhaps 200 people showed up, and Mr. Arafat made only passing reference to it in his speech, which pivoted from a grim account of the recent struggle with Israel to his proposals for the future, blending promises of change with appeals for patience.
The developing change in Palestinian politics, which is seen as no immediate threat to Mr. Arafat's hold on power, was reflected in legislators' pleased but skeptical reception of the speech. Applause for his call for elections turned to gentle laughter when he suggested there was no hurry, adding, "We should be responsible -- we should implement what we can."
"This is great," Ahmad al-Deek, a longtime member of Mr. Arafat's Fatah movement, said afterward. But, he added, "We don't want programs. We want practical steps."
Some advocates of governmental reform fear that the sudden interest at the top may be less a reflection of desire for change than of hope that it can be shaped to benefit the current leadership.
Nader Said, a sociologist at Bir Zeit University, said that some potential beneficiaries of reform were "the people who are behind the corruption. So how can we trust them again to lead the society on a democratic basis?"
Nabil Amr, who resigned last week as Mr. Arafat's minister of parliamentary affairs, citing a lack of reform, said, "We must see what he will do on the ground. We need a new government." Mr. Amr, long viewed as a member of Mr. Arafat's circle, is suspected by other Palestinian politicians and political analysts of trying to leap to the head of the parade -- evidence, in any event, of the political dynamic at work.
Abdul Jawad Saleh, a leader of the legislative opposition, waved a copy of a speech that he said Mr. Arafat gave more than a year ago. "It's the same," he said, "only now it's more detailed." He added, "Nothing he said last year he has implemented."
Mr. Saleh said of Mr. Arafat: "He's not serious. He's serious when there is pressure against him." He called for demonstrations and civil disobedience by Palestinians to express what he called their desire for "real and substantive reforms and freedoms," noting a lack of freedom of the press.
But Mr. Saleh warned that Israeli and American demands "make it harder" for advocates of reform by making them appear to serve foreign interests. 
Some Palestinian politicians, including members of Fatah, have called for years for civic reform. Hussam Khader, a Palestinian legislator from Nablus, has derided Mr. Arafat's intimates as "the Oslo Economic Party," a reference to corruption he believes was fostered by the Oslo peace process.
In his speech, Mr. Arafat repeated his stated opposition to attacks on Israeli civilians, saying that "they do not serve our interests."
Some of the men prompting calls for reform may be among those who gain from it. Many Palestinians are angry with Muhammad Rashid, a financial adviser to Mr. Arafat who has served as a conduit to Israel by meeting with Mr. Sharon's son, Omri. Mr. Rashid is linked to Muhammad Dahlan, the chief of Palestinian security in Gaza, who has emerged as a favorite of Mr. Arafat. 
Mr. Dahlan has been chafing at the lack of promotion within the Palestinian Authority as aging ministers cling to their portfolios.
Another ally of those officials, Hanan Asfour, a Palestinian minister, was badly beaten outside his home here by five masked men on Sunday, in a sign of the intensity of the jockeying for power.
Mr. Arafat has been sharply criticized by many Palestinians for permitting 13 Palestinians accused by Israel of terrorism to be sent into exile to resolve the 39-day standoff at the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem. Mr. Rashid was involved in striking that deal. Obliquely referring to such criticism today, Mr. Arafat said that only he should be blamed for any mistakes. 
"I am telling you, if there is a mistake, I am responsible," he said, in a highly unusual acknowledgment. But, he added, "There is no movement without mistakes in the whole world."
Israel's president, Moshe Katsav, said after Mr. Arafat's speech: "Leaders are allowed to make mistakes -- it's only human. But the problem with Arafat is that he consciously and deliberately makes these mistakes."
Palestinians are dispirited by the overwhelming Israeli military offensive and by their dwindling economy, some Palestinian leaders said. "What's frustrating is the political situation and the leadership, which did not achieve what it is calling for," said Jamal Barghouti, a Fatah activist.
In his speech, Mr. Arafat called on the legislators to make "a review that touches all our aspects of life." After ignoring the bill for 18 months, Mr. Arafat on Tuesday signed into a law a measure granting judicial independence.
After Mr. Sharon made his demand for Palestinian reform on Tuesday, some Israeli politicians suggested that he was asking too much of the Palestinian Authority, which has been crippled by the conflict with Israel. But Palestinian politicians said today that real reform would speed their pursuit of a state.
They may lack a state, but the Palestinians have established a formidable bureaucracy. Mr. Arafat oversees 28 ministries, from agriculture to youth and athletics. Many Palestinians complain that they get little help from the administration, but they also blame the Israeli incursions and their blockades of Palestinian areas.
Palestinians have not held elections since January 1996, when they voted for the president, Mr. Arafat, and 88 members of the legislative council. Israel would have to ease its restrictions for elections to be held.
The Bush administration has been urging reform of the Palestinian Authority, with particular attention to the multiple security agencies. But it recently balked at a French proposal for prompt elections, fearing that extremists would gain. 
Mr. Said, the sociologist, said of the prospect of elections, "What is missing is the more liberal, secular, democratic faction, which is not very organized."
He said that the United States views Arab states only as corrupt clients or fundamentalist dictatorships. "They can't see that there is a potentially vibrant democratic movement in the Arab world," he said.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: THE ENERGY MARKET; 
Power Giants Have Trouble Raising Cash For Plants

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Accused of accounting chicanery and illegally inflating power prices, companies that generate much of the nation's electricity have lost the confidence of investors. For the moment, they are finding it nearly impossible to raise money for new plants, raising the risk of future power shortages, industry experts say.
 The stock prices and credit ratings of independent power producers, the companies that are building most new power plants nationwide, have plunged since the collapse of Enron. The crisis has worsened in the last week, amid new disclosures about aggressive business and accounting practices in the sector. 
 In the short run, the effect on the nation's power supply will be limited. Scores of new plants have been built since 1999, and supply exceeds electricity demand by a comfortable margin nationally. 
But if the companies cannot regain the trust of Wall Street and Washington, plant construction may stall for years, leaving some regions short of power later this decade, experts say.
"There is a serious question in my mind about financing the next cycle of power plants," said Paul Joskow, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an expert on electricity deregulation. "You're crippling a sector that was supposed to be an engine of investment for these plants."
The turbulence worsened last week when three companies -- Dynegy, Reliant Resources and CMS Energy -- said they had misled Wall Street by exaggerating the size of their electricity trading divisions. Federal regulators, meanwhile, released documents that appear to show that Enron tried to force up prices in California at the height of the power crisis.
Yesterday, CMS Energy said that it had overstated its revenue by $3.4 billion, or 35 percent, last year as a result of sham electricity trades. An additional $1 billion in phantom trades were made in 2000, the company said. 
Standard & Poor's said yesterday that many power producers might face a cash squeeze if their credit ratings dropped further. The bad news knocked shares in several companies -- including CMS, Reliant, Aquila and Dynegy -- to 52-week lows.
"We need to have a healthy environment between the companies and the regulators and the consumers," said Steven Fleishman, a utility analyst at Merrill Lynch. "There needs to be some basis of trust. And there's obviously been tremendous damage done on that trust."
Wall Street's skepticism about the sector is a sudden change from its attitude only a few months ago, when investors flooded power producers with cash. Last year alone, Calpine raised $5.7 billion from investors to support a $15 billion plan to become the nation's largest power company. Calpine, based in San Jose, Calif., said it planned to build plants with a total capacity of 70,000 megawatts, almost 10 percent of United States production. Mirant, Reliant, Dynegy, and other producers raised tens of billions of dollars more.
But the collapse of Enron caused investors to take a hard look at the accounting practices and heavy debt loads carried by other big power producers. They discovered that the companies had used a variety of accounting gimmicks to make their balance sheets look healthier and their sales and profits seem larger than was really the case.
In some cases, the companies had created special partnerships that enabled them to reduce the debt they had to disclose to investors. In others, they had announced energy trades that did not really exist, increasing their reported sales.
The practices appear to have stemmed from the companies' desire to report fast growth in sales and earnings as a way of persuading investors to finance new plants.
Now, short on cash and under heavy political pressure, the independent producers are postponing or canceling those plants. In March, Calpine canceled 35 orders for natural gas turbines from General Electric and delayed the delivery of 81 other turbines. Calpine said the cuts would lower its capital spending by $3 billion over the next two years. Over all, General Electric plans to build 150 turbines for the United States market next year, down from 284 last year, a spokesman said. The number will shrink again in 2004.
Investment in new power lines, which are badly needed to bring power to several major cities, including New York and San Francisco, has also lagged.
By the middle of this decade, spot power shortages are possible on hot days, Mr. Fleishman said. He added that he was less concerned about generating capacity than about building new transmission lines to get power where it is needed. Paying for those lines is a complex issue that has been pushed off regulators' agendas by the crisis in the independent producers' sector, he said.
"The focus on replaying issues in California and such is taking away attention from the biggest near-term issue in terms of infrastructure need in the sector, which is transmission," Mr. Fleishman said. "We don't have enough transmission in some areas, including downstate New York," or New York City and Long Island.
The long-term risk of power shortages may vary widely by region, Mr. Fleishman said. In states like Texas, where new plants can be built more quickly, the recent cancellations and deferrals will probably not result in problems because they can quickly be reversed if the power market tightens. But in states like New York, where building plants is difficult, deferrals could have a bigger impact.
"Longer term, this is a hugely capital-intensive industry that is going to need access to capital, and that access is now being cut off, and that's not good," he said.
The North American Electric Reliability Council, an umbrella group that works with the industry and federal government to supervise the power grid, is now assessing the impact of the cancellations. It expects to have a report out within a month.
Because of the recent construction boom, most of the United States should meet demand until 2006, said Douglas M. Logan, principal at Platt's Research and Consulting. But if the independent power sector remains weak, after that "we may see high prices or even shortages before construction kicks in again," he said. New York City, the mid-Atlantic region, the upper Midwest and California could see problems sooner, he added.
Eric Hirst, a Tennessee consultant who has worked with dozens of power producers and state regulators, said the slowdown in plant construction was not unexpected. The boom in building that began in 1999 was unsustainable, he said.
"My sense is that six months ago the announced megawatts planned was way more than we needed, and was going to lead to a glut in the market," he said. "The cancellations are necessary."
In addition, the industry can extend the lives of older plants, and the economic slowdown and Internet slump has caused demand for power to flatten, Mr. Hirst said. Moreover, if prices begin to rise in anticipation of shortages, companies will scramble to put new plants in place, he said.
"If we're serious about competition on the generation end, we're going to have to accept that it's investors who are going to make the decision whether plants are built," he said. "I still am a believer in competition, although it gets harder and harder to say that with a straight face after the California problems."
Since the early 1990's, the United States has gradually deregulated its electricity industry, which was once a strictly regulated group of local monopolies. Under the old system, utilities like Con Edison were responsible for making sure they owned enough generating plants to supply power to all their customers. In return, the utilities had a monopoly on selling power in their service area, and state regulators set rates at a price high enough to cover their costs and leave a profit.
But as electric rates soared in the 1980's, especially in the Northeast and California, industry experts and some big users of power complained that the regulated system had failed and demanded the right to pick their own electric suppliers.
In response to the criticism, many states forced utilities to sell most of their generating plants. Now, instead of generating their own power, the utilities buy it for consumers on newly created wholesale markets. And instead of being fixed, the price of electricity rises and falls with demand. This change has been largely invisible to consumers, since in most states retail rates are still fixed.
But over the next few years, retail rates in several states will be deregulated, and consumers will pay prices that rise and fall along with the wholesale market -- as ratepayers in New York City, which is served by Con Edison, already do.
If deregulation is to move forward, the independent producers need to rebuild trust among regulators and investors, Mr. Logan said. "These companies need to show that they're managed well, they have good assets, their assets are competitive in the market, and they're not playing financial games."

HEADLINE: A Race to Vote On a Budget In Albany 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 15 

 BODY:
Operating in closed meetings, state lawmakers today began absorbing details of the gargantuan budget bills negotiated by their leaders. The legislators, juggling dozens of dollar figures largely in their heads, were to begin voting on the bills Thursday morning. 
 Late tonight, the administration released some details of the $89.6 billion plan that has been hammered out in secret meetings between the legislative leaders and the governor over the last two weeks. The talks have not included rank-and-file legislators, who tonight still had yet to be given details on paper. Nor had they seen the bills, although the leaders had briefed them extensively. 
 State aid to local schools will increase about $440 million above what Gov. George E. Pataki proposed in January, with $4 of every $10 going to New York City. All told, spending will rise about 6 percent, but the portion paid for with state revenues will rise only 3 percent.
The budget depends heavily on spending about $1.2 billion of the state's savings, borrowing hundreds of millions and using about $1 billion in other one-time revenues. These pools of money will let the state avert deep cuts in services and proceed with planned tax cuts at a time when income tax revenues have dropped because of last year's recession and the terrorist attack.
"I believe we have done a very good job under circumstances that were less than ideal,"said the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat.
Some lawmakers said they feared that the government would face a huge shortfall next year because the budget includes at least $2 billion in revenues that will not recur.
"It's a lousy budget," said Assemblyman William L. Parment, a Jamestown Democrat. "It's a budget that relies too heavily on borrowing and one-shot revenues, very similar to the bad budgets that we did back in the late 1980's and early 1990's."
But Governor Pataki defended the use of state reserves and other one-time revenues to get through hard times. "All in all, in an extraordinarily difficult year, this is a great budget," he said.
Some of the nine bills detailing that budget went to the printers today, though some fine print on other bills had yet to be worked out late tonight.
The budget does not raise income or business taxes, but it does raise about $86 million by increasing fees or imposing surcharges on everything from hunting licenses to cellphones. It also expands the state cigarette tax to include cigars and chewing tobacco. 
Late Tuesday night, the leaders agreed on an early retirement program that had eluded them. The state would offer early retirement to most civil servants who are 55 and have served 25 years, excluding the police and other workers the governor deems essential. The governor would also be able to offer incentives to other workers at his discretion. The buyouts should save the state $55 million and remove 5,000 workers from the payroll, officials said. The retirement program is also available to local governments.
Negotiators failed to agree on a number of issues but agreed to pass the budget anyway in the hope of working out those sticking points later. The budget will not give Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg control over the New York City school system as some city lawmakers had hoped. Neither will it force the city to devote a greater share of its annual revenues to the schools.
"There is no agreement at this point on school governance," Assemblyman Steven Sanders of Manhattan said. "There are still some nettlesome issues that have to be discussed." 
Another impasse was over the Superfund, a state program that cleans up toxic waste sites. The governor wanted to provide $90 million for the fund and change the cleanup standards in some cases. The Democrats in control of the Assembly argued for a $200 million program with no change to the standards. 
In the end, the budget includes only $11 million to keep paying the Superfund staff for another year. This is the second year in a row the fund has not been replenished, and environmental officials have been unable to start cleaning up 800 hazardous waste sites.
"It's terrible," said Michael Livermore, a lobbyist for the New York Public Interest Research Group. "It's just stranding thousands of families."
So confused was the state of affairs late last night that aides to the governor and legislative leaders could not agree on the language for a news release outlining the basic details of the final agreement.
The Democrats who control the Assembly won a significant increase at the negotiating table for the New York City schools. Mr. Pataki's January proposal would have cut $40 million in state aid for the city schools. The city now will not only receive about $200 million in additional operating aid, but it will also get an additional one-time infusion of $200 million from the state to reimburse the city for old claims it failed to file on time.
"This is the best news New York City's schools have had in many months," Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said in a statement.
The talks over the final budget took place against a dismal economic backdrop; tax revenues in April were about $1.2 billion lower than the Pataki administration had expected.
To make up for that shortfall and pay for about $700 million in new spending, the administration and lawmakers are increasing taxes on cigarettes and cellphones, and raiding every pool of money the state has. They plan to take more than $560 million out of various state funds for special purposes and spend it on general purposes. They are also taking $200 million from the Environmental Protection Fund and $200 million from a fund set up to pay for health insurance for the poor.
In addition, the state intends to sell off abandoned property the state takes over, like bank accounts, car insurance refunds and security deposits, to gain about $300 million.
"I think we are scraping the bottom of a lot of barrels for money here, and unless the state's revenues improve significantly, next year's budget will be even more difficult," said Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat.

HEADLINE: States' Vast Budget Gaps Bring Higher Fees and Emergency Cuts 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 

 BODY:
Faced with a large, unexpected drop in income-tax revenue, states across the country are trying desperately to plug wide budget gaps in ways voters can abide in an election year.
 Some are raising cigarette taxes and various fees. Some are cutting spending on the edges or using bookkeeping devices to make the deficits go away. A few have taken drastic measures to avoid raising sales or income taxes or cutting popular programs like education. 
 Missouri, for example, is so short of cash that it has stopped sending out income-tax refunds. More than 400,000 taxpayers who filed returns on their 2001 income are owed nearly $170 million. Officials promise that the refunds will be mailed when the state's cash flow improves. 
Wisconsin is considering issuing bonds secured by the 30 years of annual payments from the national settlement with tobacco companies. The effect would be to spend all 30 years of the state's share of the tobacco money this year and next.
The National Conference of State Legislatures reported last month that at least 40 states and the District of Columbia were being forced this year to make emergency cuts in their budgets totaling $27 billion. 
Like other states, New York has had a serious shortfall in revenue -- $1.2 billion less in April tax receipts than had been expected -- largely because weakness in the stock market has resulted in smaller receipts from the capital gains tax. 
But New York is in better shape than most others because during the fat years, Gov. George E. Pataki squirreled away as much as $4 billion. He can now draw on that as he begins his race for re-election. In his latest budget, he sought increased spending on popular programs and avoided proposing a repeal of tax cuts set to take effect this year.
Still, the final budget on which New York legislative leaders wrapped up negotiations today does include increased fees or new surcharges on a variety of products and state services, and an expansion of the state cigarette tax to include cigars and chewing tobacco. Page B1. 
Circumstances here in Indiana are more severe, and more typical. Just three years ago, the state was sitting on a $2 billion surplus, about 10 percent of the whole state budget. Feeling flush, Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon and the legislature approved deep tax cuts and undertook an ambitious plan to raise school standards.
But times changed almost overnight. Indiana's deficit is now more than $1 billion, and the figure seems to grow with each recalculation. So this week, irritable at having to leave their jobs and families, and pessimistic about being able to resolve the crisis, legislators began meeting here in a rare special session.
Nowhere is the situation more dire than in California. On Tuesday, Gov. Gray Davis proposed closing a shortfall of $23.6 billion, one-third of the entire budget, by raising vehicle license fees and cigarette taxes and making steep reductions in health programs and aid to local governments.
The details of the problem and the solutions that officeholders are considering vary by state, but the basics are the same.
In the prosperity of the late 1990's, the states acted as if good times would always roll, slashing taxes for individuals and businesses and spending with abandon.
When the economy turned sour, revenue fell sharply, higher spending was locked into place, and the states, most of them required by their constitutions to run balanced budgets, found themselves in deep holes.
The problem is complicated by the elections this fall. Budget-cutting invariably requires bitter medicine, and few politicians are willing to risk re-election to administer it.
"In an election year," said Governor O'Bannon, who called the special session here, "you always get political policy mixed up with public policy."
New Jersey has one of the worst deficits of any state in percentage terms, 12 percent of the total budget, according to calculations by the conference of state legislatures. But New Jersey holds its elections for state offices in odd-numbered years, and that has eased the pressure on the new governor, James E. McGreevey. He is reducing the budgets of state agencies by 5 percent and cutting back on construction and maintenance projects.
Connecticut has managed to control its deficit with a 61-cent-a-pack increase in cigarette taxes, to $1.11 from 50 cents.
North Carolina raised income and sales taxes last year, but it is an exception. Few states are using general tax increases to try to recoup the $35 billion in tax cuts that were enacted in the eight years ended in 2000.
Spending reductions have been imposed almost everywhere. The conference of state legislatures reported that 17 states had cut aid to elementary and secondary education, or might do so. That aid is a big part of the budget in all states but usually one of the last places politicians look to save money.
Twenty-nine states are considering cuts in higher education, 25 in prisons and 22 in Medicaid, the conference found. At least 10 may lay off state employees.
But to a large extent, said Don Boyd, director of the Fiscal Studies Program at the Rockefeller Institute in Albany, states are resorting to gimmicks and procrastination, trying to sweep as much dust as possible under the rug and hoping that good times will return quickly and close the budget gap painlessly.
That is certainly the tendency here in Indiana. The only revenue increases even under consideration involve more gambling receipts and higher cigarette taxes. Governor O'Bannon has set aside some of his most ambitious plans, like state aid for preschool programs, but most of the cuts so far have involved bookkeeping devices like transfers from trust funds to the general fund and a reduction in emergency reserves. 
"The political will is not there to do what is necessary," said William J. Sheldrake, president of the Indiana Fiscal Policy Institute, a nonpartisan research center. 
Most authorities doubt that Indiana or other states will return soon to a time of plenty, given two serious structural problems. 
The first is that services, the dominant element of the economy in most states, are not taxed. For years, Florida, among other states, has considered taxing services, from haircuts to golf lessons, but those proposals have never gone far and are not likely to now.
The other structural problem is the huge rise in health expenditures, in large part a result of ever higher drug costs. Health care now accounts for 27 percent of all state spending, said Ray Scheppach, executive director of the National Governors' Association.
As the legislature convened here in Indianapolis on Tuesday, lobbyists were out in force, but the lawmakers' mood was grim. Governor O'Bannon, a Democrat, has said that if the legislature does not act in the special session, he will be forced to cut spending for education and other popular programs on his own and seek new sources of revenue. But he is not the kind of governor who strikes fear in his opponents, said Brian Howey, who publishes a nonpartisan political newsletter.
The Indiana House is controlled by Democrats, but the Senate by Republicans, and the chances of reaching a bipartisan agreement are remote, most lawmakers say.
"No question we're going to have a tough time getting anything worked out," said Representative William C. Cochran, a Democrat from the southeastern part of the state.
Representative Daniel A. Dumezich, a Republican from a suburb of Chicago and a tax lawyer, agreed. Like many others, he said the special session was "a major inconvenience" for the part-time lawmakers, who are paid $112 a day when they are in session and whose regular session ended for the year in March.
"I have a real job I have to attend to," he said.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: City Economy Shrinks 

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton (NYT) (Compiled by Yilu Zhao) 

 BODY:
 New York City's economy continued to shrink in the first quarter of 2002, and personal income tax payments plunged, according to data released yesterday by William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller. 
The gross city product, a measure of the overall economy, dropped by 2.6 percent, even as a similar measure of the national economy, the gross domestic product, grew by 5.8 percent. Personal income tax payments, which the comptroller's office uses as a guideline to measure New Yorkers' income, fell by 20 percent from last year. Included was a 12 percent drop in withholding taxes and a 38.9 percent drop in estimated tax payments. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Drug Shares and Hewlett Drag Down S.& P. and Dow

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell yesterday, led by drug shares, after Abbott Laboratories said that a plant failed inspection and Schering-Plough said that it was being investigated by the Food and Drug Administration.
 Hewlett-Packard helped drag down the Dow Jones industrial average after it said corporate customers were not spending enough to revive sales this year. 
 "You have to get the earnings to push the market higher," said David Fowler, president of Lincoln Capital Management, which oversees $35 billion in Chicago. 
The S.& P. 500 fell 6.21 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,091.07, with health care stocks accounting for half the loss. The Dow lost 54.46 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,243.68.
The Nasdaq composite index climbed for a third day, gaining 6.51 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,725.56. The index had not risen in three straight sessions since April 1.
Since stocks peaked in March 2000, "every rally has been a great selling opportunity," Mr. Fowler said.
"There is nothing in the market that I have seen that is giving me a tremendous amount of conviction about the sustainability" of any advance, said Matthew Johnson, head of cash trading at Lehman Brothers. Stocks fell last week even after a rally on Wednesday that was the biggest one-day gain in eight months.
Almost 1.4 billion shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, 5.8 percent more than the three-month daily average. Rising and falling stocks were about even on the Big Board and the Nasdaq.
Abbott Labs fell $4.84, to $46.90, after saying one of its plants failed an inspection in January. Three years ago, Abbott was fined $100 million and ordered to fix flaws at the same site, which makes medical tests.
Schering-Plough declined $3.49, to $25. The company, the maker of the top-selling allergy drug Claritin, disclosed in a filing that the F.D.A. was conducting a criminal investigation in Puerto Rico.
Pfizer, meanwhile, which acquired Warner-Lambert, is being investigated by the United States attorney's office in Boston. Warner-Lambert sales representatives met with patients and recommended drugs for unapproved uses, The New York Times said, citing court documents. Pfizer lost 75 cents, to $36.49.
Eli Lilly fell $2.19, to $63.51, and Merck lost 60 cents, to $56.90.
Hewlett-Packard retreated $1.15, to $19.35. The company, which merged with Compaq Computer earlier this month, said fiscal second-quarter sales slipped, missing the $11.1 billion estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Hewlett-Packard does not expect a "meaningful" improvement in demand until next year.
Oracle, the software maker, rose 38 cents, to $9.19, and Dell Computer, the biggest direct seller of personal computers, added 80 cents, to $27.70.
Bond prices rose as stocks fell. By late in the day, the price of the 10-year note climbed 11/32 , to 97 6/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.25 percent from 5.29 percent.
The 30-year bond rose 8/32 , to 95 1/32 . Its yield dropped to 5.73 percent from 5.75 percent.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Faults Pace of Downtown Recovery 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Andrew M. Cuomo criticized the pace and management of the effort to rebuild Lower Manhattan yesterday, and said the governor should take control to end bickering among rival state agencies. 
 And Mr. Cuomo said New York officials should play an aggressive role in determining precisely what type of development takes place at the World Trade Center site, rather than leaving it to the private market. 
 "This is the job of the governor," Mr. Cuomo, a Democratic candidate for governor, said at Cooper Union. "You cannot delegate this to a number of agencies and then have them compete with one another. There is no greater challenge to New York. And as governor, I would take responsibility." 
In a speech that jumped from the subject of rebuilding Lower Manhattan to ensuring the security of New York, Mr. Cuomo also expressed alarm about recent intelligence reports that terrorists may be planning an attack on a Northeast nuclear plant around July 4. Mr. Cuomo said the Indian Point power plant, in Westchester, should be closed immediately, asserting that safety outweighed any potential problems created by the loss of energy.
"This is a nuclear power plant which is in the closest proximity to the most densely populated area in the globe," Mr. Cuomo said. "No one can tell you to this day as we are seated here what would happen if a plane hit Indian Point."
He added: "That's enough for me. Shut down the plant." 
Mr. Cuomo's remarks seemed an attempt to reframe his criticism of Gov. George E. Pataki's performance in the weeks after the attack on the trade center. Mr. Cuomo had belittled Mr. Pataki, saying he had "held the coat" of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. 
Mr. Cuomo was widely criticized for his remarks, even by Democrats, and yesterday, he took pains to avoid criticizing the governor directly as he returned to what his aides said would be a central theme of his campaign: his contention that Mr. Pataki is doing an ineffective job in overseeing the recovery effort downtown.
Mr. Pataki's spokesman, Michael McKeon, rejected Mr. Cuomo's criticisms, saying: "The governor is going to continue to work in a nonpartisan way with Mike Bloomberg and other interested parties to make sure that Lower Manhattan and lower New York is stronger than it was on Sept. 10. We're confident that we are going to get the job done."
In his speech, Mr. Cuomo sought to distance himself from the positions taken by some planners that the government should simply reconstruct public facilities that were destroyed at ground zero -- in particular, roads and the mass transit system -- and let the private market largely dictate the extent of construction.
Mr. Cuomo argued that New York should take an aggressive role in setting the future of downtown, by seeking to anchor the area with a major project that establishes a character for downtown and encourages economic development.
"Rather than just allowing the private sector to evolve downtown Manhattan," Mr. Cuomo said, "rather than replacing what was -- the office buildings -- let's try a different approach, where government plays a more active role, where government says, 'We have an opportunity here to bring in a large-scale economic generator that will drive the development.' " 
As examples of a large-scale economic generator, Mr. Cuomo suggested relocating the World Bank downtown, giving the City Opera a home there or setting up an international medical research center. Mr. Cuomo, a former federal housing secretary, said those were just suggestions, and he declined to endorse any one idea.
Mr. Cuomo questioned the way Mr. Pataki had set up the rebuilding effort, noting in particular the public quarreling between two key agencies: the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the 16-acre trade center site, and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which Mr. Pataki created to oversee its development.
He noted that the two agencies "are vying for the driver's seat." 
"Many other public agencies are competing for the role," he said. "The results? Months of public bickering."
Mr. Cuomo's rival for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, also supports the immediate closing of Indian Point. Mr. Pataki does not, though Mr. McKeon said he had asked federal agencies to study the question in light of the recent threat of terrorism.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Seeks Approval To Buy a California Bank
Wal-Mart is seeking regulatory approval to buy a tiny California bank, saying it hopes a banking license will lower its processing costs for certain transactions.
 Wal-Mart could also offer financial services like savings accounts and certificates of deposit as well as home equity loans or auto financing. Page C9. 

I.B.M. Chief Confirms Job Cuts
In his first meeting with Wall Street analysts since becoming chief executive of I.B.M., Samuel J. Palmisano said the company would emerge from the downturn in the computer industry stronger than ever. But he also confirmed that I.B.M. would be cutting its work force by thousands to tighten its belt during the current slump. C4.

Kmart Posts Record Loss for 2001
Kmart said it lost $2.42 billion last year, the largest in its history, and that it would restate its quarterly data for most of the year. C5.

F.D.A. Inquiry of Schering-Plough
The Food and Drug Administration is conducting a criminal investigation that may focus on one or more products made by Schering-Plough at its factories in Puerto Rico. Its shares dropped 12 percent, to $25. C3.

Sony Picks Electronics Arts Games
Electronic Arts, the videogame publisher, has struck a deal to provide its games for Sony's new online effort. Electronic Arts said negotiations with Microsoft had stalled. C4.

WorldCom Taps a Line of Credit
WorldCom said it would tap a $2.7 billion credit line to ease concern temporarily over access to cash as it advances its efforts to obtain more financing. Market Place. C9.

Merrill Buys Time for a Settlement
Merrill Lynch has gained a week to try to each a settlement with Eliot L. Spitzer, the New York attorney general investigating conflicts of interest at the firm. C8.

CBS Keeps NBC in Mind for Fall
CBS announced a fall schedule that has been tailored to attack some of the strongholds of the ratings leader, NBC. Advertising. C5.

The winners and losers in the talks for the 2002-03 season are sorted out. C5.

Frankel Pleads Guilty in Federal Case
Martin R. Frankel, 47, who became an international fugitive after swindling a fortune in an insurance scheme, pleaded guilty to 23 counts of federal wire, racketeering and securities fraud. He faces a maximum sentence of 150 years in prison and $6.5 million in penalties. But he is likely to receive a reduced sentence in exchange for his plea. B1.

Metalworkers' Union Reaches Deal
After nearly two weeks of one-day strikes at scores of companies, Germany's giant metalworkers' union reached a deal with industry that will increase wages by 4 percent this year. World Business, Section W.

Data Show Economy Gains Traction
Industrial production rose 0.4 percent in April, the Federal Reserve said. Separately, the Labor Department said consumer prices increased 0.5 percent in April. The reports signaled the economy was gaining traction. C2.

Knocking the Dollar Off Its Perch
As the expansion shows signs of weakness, it is time to encourage a modest decline in the mighty dollar to stoke manufacturing sales. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. C2.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
I.B.M. Chief Says Focus Is on Gains in Productivity

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
In his first meeting with Wall Street analysts since becoming chief executive of International Business Machines, Samuel J. Palmisano declared yesterday that the company would emerge from the downturn in the computer industry stronger than ever. But he also confirmed that I.B.M. would be cutting its work force by thousands to tighten its belt during the current slump.
 Mr. Palmisano refused to detail the extent of the planned payroll trimming, but he seemed to suggest the numbers could be somewhat higher than recent reports. Last week, executives close to the company said I.B.M. would cut its work force in the first half of this year by roughly 9,000 employees, or fewer than 3 percent of its 320,000 employees worldwide. Most of the job cuts, these executives said, would be in the United States, where I.B.M. employs 160,000 people. 
 Mr. Palmisano said I.B.M. was steadily working to improve productivity and cut expenses by $1 billion or $2 billion a year. Reducing employment in some operations to mirror shifts in business, especially in the services business, has occurred even in good times, he said. That kind of attrition, he said, has typically amounted to 15,000 jobs a year.
But when the technology sector was buoyant, those cutbacks would be more than offset by additional hiring, especially in fast-growing parts of the services business, increasing I.B.M.'s total employment. Last year, I.B.M.'s revenues declined 3 percent and most analysts expect it to decline another 3 percent in 2002.
One analyst noted that if I.B.M. held steady its revenue per employee -- one measure of corporate productivity -- that would imply cutbacks of 20,000 workers. While agreeing with the overall analysis, Mr. Palmisano said the company's businesses vary, so simple head-count calculations can be misleading.
Still, he observed, "If we did not hire anybody, we'd be down 15,000."
Mr. Palmisano avoided being more specific, but hinted of an announcement soon. "You'll hear more about what we're doing to address those issues," he said. "That's pretty straightforward."
Mr. Palmisano, who became chief executive in March, replacing Louis V. Gerstner Jr., spent most of his hourlong appearance in New York discussing I.B.M.'s long-term strategy and the technology industry.
Mr. Palmisano made no specific predictions of when the industry might rebound, later this year or next year. But when it does, he said, the information technology business should grow at more than twice the rate of the economy, somewhat slower than in the late 1990's but still solid.
Mr. Palmisano compared the current period to the economic downturn at the start of the 1980's, when the personal computer industry really got under way, and to the early 1990's, when PC's linked in small networks, or client-server computing, had its start. Each time, he said, economic slowdowns forced companies to look for ways to use technology to lift productivity.
Today, Mr. Palmisano said, mainstream businesses understand that using Internet technology can help them save costs and increase productivity. I.B.M., he said, is well positioned to help companies use networked technology and is gaining market share in software, data-serving computers, storage and services.
"We don't like this economic environment, but we are seizing the opportunity it presents," Mr. Palmisano said. "I.B.M. is going to exit this downturn much stronger than we entered."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Samuel J. Palmisano yesterday met with analysts for the first time since becoming chief of I.B.M. (Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: Castro's Door: Both Open and Closed 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: HAVANA, May 15 

 BODY:
With President Fidel Castro sitting in the front row, Jimmy Carter chastised him Tuesday night about the failure of the Communist system to respect political rights. The Cuban nation watched on uncensored television. Mr. Castro said nothing.
 His reaction was as surprising as it was polite. Was the man who has ruled Cuba for 43 years, famed for proclaiming the triumphs of his revolution and the evils of his enemy to the north, about to embrace democracy? Or had Mr. Castro invited Mr. Carter for a five-day grand tour as part of yet another strategy of self-preservation that he had laid out to the last detail? 
 Mr. Castro's silence bespoke new pressures he is facing on many sides. He has alienated longtime allies in Latin America, who are increasingly frustrated with his lack of democratic reform. Mexico, perhaps the sturdiest friend of the revolution, recently voted against Cuba at the United Nations Human Rights Commission. The near-ouster in April of Hugo Chavez, the leftist president of Venezuela, showed Mr. Castro the weakness of his only other avowed supporter in the hemisphere. 
Mr. Castro is also bracing for a toughening of policy by the Bush administration, which promises to cut down even further on Cuba's income from tourism, trade and foreign investment. 
In this light, Mr. Castro has already gotten one major benefit from Mr. Carter's trip: the former American president's appeal to Washington to lift a four-decade embargo.
Allowing Mr. Carter to talk frankly about Cuba's faults may have caused Mr. Castro some embarrassment. But that was a price Mr. Castro seemed willing to pay to project an image of openness in an effort to sway opinion in the United States as some lawmakers push to ease restrictions on trade and travel.
"There are some who might be more inclined to go along with that in the wake of the Carter visit, and the fact Castro allowed him to speak to the Cuban people," said Wayne Smith, a senior fellow at the Center for International Policy and former head of the United States Interests Section here. But he added, "It's still a little difficult for me to believe that it happened."
Mr. Castro's gamble in choosing Mr. Carter to visit was carefully considered. Mr. Carter worked to improve relations with Cuba during his presidency. This week he praised the revolution's achievements in health and education and, as a bonus, disputed the Bush administration's claims that Cuba was conducting biological warfare research. 
Still, Mr. Castro would not have invited Mr. Carter had he not felt sufficiently in control; he knew that Mr. Carter, who made human rights a central issue of his presidency, would raise the topic here. 
Beyond Mr. Carter's visit, there is no sign that Mr. Castro is considering any immediate political opening. The state-run news media touted Mr. Carter's call for lifting the embargo, but made no mention of his criticism of the lack of freedom.
Mr. Castro's resistance to change may even increase if the administration proceeds with plans to clamp down on American travel and to enforce legal provisions allowing suits against foreign companies in Cuba that benefit from confiscated properties.
"He does not want to be seen as giving in to pressure," said George Vickers, Latin America director at the Open Society Institute. 
What Mr. Castro does not seem to have anticipated was Mr. Carter's extraordinary endorsement in front of the nation of a novel challenge to the Communist system. While claiming he would not interfere in Cuban politics, Mr. Carter pointedly mentioned Project Varela, a drive by rights advocates that amassed 11,000 signatures on a petition for a national referendum to obtain greater democratic freedoms. Varela's supporters see it as a peaceful attempt to change the system from within. 
The petitions were delivered to the National Assembly two days before Mr. Carter arrived. Cuban officials dismissed them as the creation of a small group backed by Washington and by Cuban exiles. Few Cubans knew anything about it until Mr. Carter's speech.
The Cuban government may still try to silence talk about Varela or find legal reasons to reject it. Cuban news accounts of Mr. Carter's speech included backhanded barbs from the handpicked audience about the project, but no mention of Mr. Carter's support.
Yet rights advocates described the mere mention of Varela in front of Mr. Castro as a transforming moment that will make it much harder to dismiss the domestic opposition.
"He is admitting that all of us need to change," said Oswaldo Paya, who led the petition drive, "that we all need to take steps: Castro, the North American government and all Cubans. He said we have all made errors and that we should put ourselves in the other's place and listen.
"But he also told us to remember there are rights that we have."
Mr. Paya said he was saddened that it took a foreign leader to bring his project to light. But he noted that of the many foreign politicians who have come here to meet with dissidents, Mr. Carter went a step further by showing a way out of the impasse between the government and its struggling opposition.
The prospects for a democratic opening could best be judged in the streets of Havana after his speech. A man watching a baseball game on a television at a food stand in the Vedado district nodded in approval when asked about the speech.
"He made proposals and spoke about freedom of expression," the man said, declining to give his name. As he spoke a police officer sidled up to him and stood silently.
"I don't know what to tell you," the man continued, changing tone. "Everything was on the surface. It did not go beyond the surface."
With the police officer still beside him, the man turned away and went back to watching the baseball game.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Continuing his tour of Cuba, Jimmy Carter stopped yesterday in Las Guasimas, a Havana district where residents build their homes with state help. He dined last night with Fidel Castro, and returns home tomorrow. (Associated Press)
